Ottawa, April 5th, 1935.

Gentlemen,-

Please forward to this Department a copy of your latest catalogue of educational supplies. The last catalogue that we received from your firm is No. 32 (1932-1933).

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The Geo. M. Hendry Co. Limited,
Toronto,
Ont.
Ottawa, April 5th, 1935.

Sir,

I should appreciate if you would forward to this Department, at your earliest convenience, a copy of your Circular No. 58 - books for High School Entrance Examinations.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Education,
Toronto, Ont.
Ottawa, May 29th, 1935.

Sir,

I should appreciate if you would place in stock, as soon as convenient, the following books:

- 300 Reading Exercises - Grade IV
- 1000 Pre-Primers "Two Little Indians"
- 1000 Work Books to accompany "Two Little Indians"
- 500 Canadian Spellers - Book I

The Reading Exercises and the Pre-Primers and Work Books can be secured from J. M. Dent & Sons and the Canadian Spellers from W. J. Gage & Company.

I am aware that you still have a number of the above books in stock but the additional supply will be required in order that we may be prepared to fill requisitions for the books required for the academic year 1935-36.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The King's Printer,
Ottawa.

August 26th, 1935

Mr. J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Superintendent,
Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have received your letter of August 19th and am enclosing copies of the courses of study followed in the Protestant elementary and high schools of this Province. The authorized textbooks are indicated under each subject.

This Department does not publish a list of supplementary reading books.

I am referring your letter to the Roman Catholic side of this Department for its attention.

Yours truly,

J. C. Sutherland
Assistant-Director of Protestant Education
Mr. Sutherland,
Supt. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Our representative, Mr. Milne, called on Mr. Snell and Mr. Hill and spoke to them of the following magazines:

- Nature Magazine $3.00
- Pictorial Education $3.50 or "with extra numbers 4.50
- Canadian Geographical Journal 3.00

Mr. Snell would like to have these magazines in the Indian Schools in his inspectorate, which I understand number about eighty.

The above publications are among the best of their kind and we shall be pleased to have your Department order these magazines. Please advise us immediately if you wish us to order for schools, beginning September issues and if you order them tell us whether you want them for twelve months or only the school months (September to June inclusive). A substantial discount will be allowed the Department, if you order all your magazine requirements at the one time.

Faithfully yours,

R.S. Macdonald
President.
Ottawa, August 28, 1935.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 27th instant, I beg to say that the magazines mentioned are not supplied by this Department to Indian schools. Under these circumstances, no order is being placed for the magazines requested by Rev. Mr. Snell.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

R. S. Macdonald, Esq.,

Aug 15/35

Dear Mr. Chelan,

I have your letter of recent date and shall do what I can to see that Mr. Carmitte is instructed in his duties when I suspect that school. In fact, I shall see to it that I spend most of the day on seeing to this matter for the time service is such that I couldn't get out anyway.

Now re the Manual & Suggestions in Catechetics; I have 60 bound volumes in cloth left and plenty of those in paper cover. The paper cover would be alright for ordinary teachers who use a textbook to be replaced regularly but the cloth cover is best for your purposes. How many do you think you could use? The best price I could give you is $1.50 each. It is only a 20¢ book. They are using them at a topbook now in 3 Canadian Seminaries and an 2 Canadian Summer schools for Teachers.

Yours sincerely,

J. M. Bennett

Should Inspector mail the books you want.
Ottawa, August 29th, 1935.

Sir,

I should appreciate if you would place in stock for this Department 50 copies of "Manual of Suggestions in Catechetics" cloth cover. This book can be secured from J. M. Scott, M. A., Inspector of Separate Schools, 47 Browning Ave., Toronto, Ont.

When you have received the above, please advise me in order that a requisition can be forwarded to you showing the schools to which we desire them sent.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The King's Printer,
Ottawa.

PP/0'M.
Quebec, August 28th, 1935.

Mr. J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Superintendent,
Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In compliance with your request of the 19th inst., I am forwarding you under separate cover a list of the text books authorized for use in the Catholic schools of this Province. I also enclose herewith a special list which we have prepared for English speaking classes.

Yours very truly,

[F/B]

For the Superintendent.
Ottawa, September 6, 1935.

Sir:

This Department would appreciate if you would place in stock 175 copies of "Teacher's Manual to accompany Canadian Catholic Corona Readers".

This can be secured from Ginn & Company, 1517 Mountain St., Montreal.

Please let me know when these are received, in order that I can forward you a requisition. We wish to send these books out as soon as they reach your office.

Your obedient servant,

Philip Phelan,
for Supt. of Indian Education.

The King's Printer,
Ottawa, Ont.

MR. BUSKARD,

Dear Sir,-

During the last few months, the Department has had several complaints regarding the chalk that has been supplied to Indian schools. In the majority of cases, those complaining did not mention the name of the manufacturer of the chalk with which they had been supplied. However, a letter was recently received from the teacher of the Morson Indian Day School, in which she writes as follows:

"I have been using 'Sanigene' Dustless Crayons made by Canada Crayon Co., Lindsay, Ont. I find that they are dusty. I find that the chalk made by the Company in Peterborough is not as dusty."

I thought you would like to have this information before you.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,

DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION
QUEBEC.

June 19th, 1936.

Advance notice regarding changes in the course of study and textbooks, of which fuller information will be given in the Supplement to the Memoranda. These changes, unless otherwise stated, will come into effect at the beginning of the session 1935-37.

1. The Permissive Course of Study is abolished in its entirety.

2. English:

a. The Imperial Readers and the Royal Crown Phonic Primers are removed from the course of study, leaving only, as authorized reading texts, the Elson Basic Readers of Pre-Primer and Primer in Grade I and the Elson Reader Book I and "Reading and Thinking" (Grade II) in Grade II.

b. The "Children's Fairy Book" is transferred from Grade III (Class II, Senior) to Grade II (Class II, Junior).

c. Grimm and Andersen: "Fairy Tales" is removed from the course in Grade III and is replaced by Barrie: "Peter Pan and Wendy" (Oxford).

d. Yonge: "A Book of Golden Deeds" is removed from the course in Grade VII and is replaced by Conan Doyle: "The White Company". (The publisher's name will be announced)

e. Kipling: "Puck of Pook's Hill" is removed from the course in Grade IX and is replaced by Kipling: "Kim", (Macmillan, St. Martin Classics Series).

f. Shakespeare: "Julius Caesar" is transferred from the course in Grade IX, to the course in Grade X, replacing Shakespeare: "Twelfth Night" which has been transferred from Grade X to Grade IX. As Julius Caesar will probably have been read by many students in Grade IX, the authorization of this book in Grade X begins in 1937-38.

g. Hillcoat: "Shorter Poems" is removed from the course in Grade X, and, in future, Powley: "One Hundred Years of English Poetry" will be apportioned between Grades X and XI, in a division made according to poets, which will be indicated in the Supplement to the Memoranda. The examination in Grade XI will be based only on the work assigned to that Grade.

h. In future only one examination paper will be set in English Language and Composition in Grades VI to IX instead of papers in each of these subjects as heretofore.

k. In consequence of the change mentioned under h, only 300 marks will be allotted to the subject of English instead of 400, in Grades VIII and IX. As a consequence, two extra subjects will be demanded from the optional list in Grade VIII and fewer optional subjects in Grade IX to make the total necessary for a certificate of 1000 marks in the grades specified.

3. Geography:

Certain changes have been made in the limits of this subject in Grades VI and VII, of which details will be given in the Supplement to the Memoranda.

The present edition of Dent's Canadian School Atlas is replaced by the new edition of this Atlas, at a list price of 60 cents.
4. History:

Jones: "The English People" is removed from the course in Grade VII, and is replaced by the Kingsway History of England, Book I. Book II of this text will be the authorized textbook in Grade VIII in place of the present syllabus.

5. Language:

"Easy Exercises in English", Third to Seventh Year, have been removed from the course of study in Grades III to VII, being replaced by the King's English Series, Books I to V.

Mason: "English Grammar" is removed from the course of study in Grades VIII and IX, and "Ontario High School Composition" from Grades IX to XI. The authorized textbooks in language in these grades VIII, IX and X are the King's English Series, Senior Books I, II and III. Dear Sir:

During the past few weeks the British Columbia Department of Education has issued a new Programme of Studies for Elementary Schools.

The above Programme is a much more detailed one than any issued in the past. Another change made now is that the various subjects are divided up among three Bulletins, making it necessary for those schools with Grades 1 to 6 inclusive to have all three Bulletins. Bulletin I covers such subjects as Health and Physical Education, and Language Arts including Language, Reading, Spelling, etc., Bulletin II deals mainly with History and Geography, Character Education, and the new Elementary Science course which takes the place of Nature, and Bulletin III deals with Arithmetic, Music, and Art in general.

While the above Bulletins are issued free to Provincial schools and Inspectors, and to Private schools, a charge of 15¢ for each Bulletin is made to teachers in Indian schools and to the Indian schools alone as far as I can learn as these come under the administration of the Dominion Government. Teachers of Indian schools calling on me during the past week or so have been advised to purchase copies of any Bulletins required on their own responsibility and from their own private funds.

It appears that some Indian schools have requested the Text Book Branch to supply copies of the required Bulletins and have not sent the necessary 15¢ for each Bulletin wanted. The Manager of the Text Book Branch, Department of Education has spoken to me this morning on the telephone with regard to this, as he does not wish to supply copies of the new Bulletins to the Indian schools individually. I told him that I should inform the Officials of the Schools' Branch of the matter and leave it to the Department in Ottawa to make any arrangements they thought best. The Manager of the Text Book Branch would like the Department of Indian Affairs to purchase the number of Bulletins required for our schools and to later distribute them and thus relieve the Text Book Branch of all further trouble in the matter.
For the information of the Department, I may say that each Day School or Division of a Residential School, will require at least Bulletins I, II, and III, and the Residential Schools, as well as a few Day Schools will in addition require a copy of the new Programme for Junior High Schools (Grades 7, 8, and 9.) About 100 copies each of the first three Bulletins would be required as well as about 25 copies of the Programme for Junior High Schools to be issued later.

If the Department of Indian Affairs decided to purchase the required Bulletins from the Text Book Branch, Department of Education, Victoria, and keep these in stock in Ottawa, I should be glad to recommend that teachers requisition for such Bulletins as they might require; and as I am leaving for Hazelton in a few days, I should be glad to receive any necessary instructions in care of the Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

Though the new Programme will go into effect in the Provincial schools tomorrow September 1st, I do not believe that a little delay will make any difference to our schools. I should however be glad to receive the instructions of the Department with regard to instructing the various teachers to include the new Bulletins on their next requisitions, should the Department consider this the best way to arrange for their distribution. If the Department could see its way to distributing the three Bulletins (I, II, & III) to each Day School and Residential School Division direct and as soon as they were received from Victoria it might be better.

As I understand from the Manager of the Text Book Branch that the Department of Indian Affairs has not been supplied with copies of the Bulletins so far issued, I am taking the liberty of forwarding one copy of each under separate cover. These have of course been purchased by me out of private funds, and no reimbursement is looked for.

In conclusion I would ask the Officials of the Schools' Branch to note that I have had no part in the preparation of the new Programme of Study, which has been mainly arranged by numerous committees in B.C., and that I am not in sympathy with much that is included in this course. In fact I have asked any of the teachers in Indian schools whom I have met lately, not to make any great change till we have had an opportunity to discuss the matter during one of the inspections. During the past few years we in the Indian schools of British Columbia have been using Texts supplied from Ottawa which are not used in Provincial schools, but have made distinct progress through the free use of Work Books, which I hope the Department will continue to supply to the schools on requisition, and I do not wish to see any retrograde step taken in the close following of the new Programme of Study, now published in Victoria. Teachers should of course study the new Programme with care and use any part which appears suitable for Indian classes, but I feel certain that the Department will agree with me that much that is now suggested could not be worked out in Indian schools even if professional men agreed that it was likely to be of advantage to Indian children.
with the specimen Bulletins of the Programme of Studies, I am also forwarding a copy of a suggested course in Reading which I have given to some of our teachers to help them in their work.

The new Highroads Readers are not arranged so that they can be read straight through, and teachers require help in selecting passages to be taken up at different times of the year. Mr. F.E. Anfield supplied the mimeographed copies from an original in my possession, and I am giving one to each teacher making use of the Highroads series. I have explained to these teachers that there is nothing official about the suggestions made in the Monthly Outline of Reading, and I am giving them a copy of a suggestion of a good way to divide up the year's work in Reading in each of the various Grades. Should the Department care to make use of the suggested outline in Indian schools in other Provinces, I may say that they are not copyrighted in any way.

The whole of the above is submitted with respect.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 18th September, No. 1-1-4, I may say that I have had a long interview this morning with the Officer-in-Charge of the Text Book Branch, Department of Education, Victoria.

I am informed that the charge for each of the three Bulletins making up the Provincial Programme of Studies has been raised from the 15¢ mentioned in the third paragraph of my letter of August 31st, No. 15/45942, to 35¢ for each Bulletin, with the exception of that for Junior High Schools or Grades 7, 8 and 9, which will cost $1.00 per copy.

I informed the Officer-in-Charge of the Text Book Branch that, owing to this increase in the charge made for each Bulletin, it would be necessary for me to refer the matter back to the Department for further consideration.

The issue of the needed Bulletins to our teachers is complicated by the fact that a number of Indian Schools and teachers have already purchased or were given gratis by mistake the copies of the Bulletins they require, and neither the Department of Education nor I have any record of the names of Schools and teachers so supplied. We, therefore, came to the following tentative agreement.

The teachers requiring copies of either Bulletins 1, 2 and 3, or that for Junior High Schools will request the same from the Text Book Branch, Department of Education, Victoria, B. C., as they are doing at present. The Officer-in-Charge of the Text Book Branch has arranged to put such applications on one side until they can be referred to me at the end of each month. The issue of such Bulletins as are absolutely necessary will then be authorized by me, and the actual material packed and forwarded, free of charge, to the teachers by the Text Book Branch. If the Department of Indian Affairs approves of the tentative arrangements thus made, the Department of Education, Victoria, is
willing to submit an account, in triplicate, for the total charge some time before the end of the present fiscal year.

It will be understood in Ottawa that it would be very difficult for me to arrange for the packing and forwarding of copies of the new Programme of Studies to the various teachers needing the same, and I would recommend that the Department accept the proposals of the Officer-in-Charge of the Text Book Branch as outlined above. The cost of postage will be added to the actual cost of the Bulletins when the account is submitted by the Provincial Department of Education.

Should the Department agree with the action I have taken in this matter, I would request that an Encumbrance Requisition for a total sum of $50.00 be issued to cover the cost of the Programmes of Studies and mailing charges. As the revised cost of the Bulletins is rather high, I shall do everything possible to reduce the number sent to Schools and teachers to an absolute minimum, but I am of the opinion that some 50 sets of these Bulletins will be required to supply the needs of the Indian Residential and Day Schools in British Columbia.

The Coureur de Bois and His Birthright

BY

J. Murray Gibbon
The Coureur de Bois and His Birthright

By J. Murray Gibbon, F.R.S.C.

(Read May Meeting, 1936)

Many have formed their idea of the coureurs de bois from Frontenac's classic memorandum to Colbert: "If one doesn't take care, they will become like the bandits of Naples and the buccaneers of St. Domingo." Francis Parkman's description in *The Old Régime in Canada* is also remembered:

"Out of the beaver trade rose a huge evil harmful to the growth and the morals of Canada. All that was most active and vigorous in the Colony took to the woods and escaped from the control of intendants, councils and priests, to the savage freedom of the wilderness. Not only were the possible profits great; but, in the pursuit of them, there was a fascinating element of adventure and danger. The intendant Duchesnay reported that eight hundred men out of a population of less than ten thousand souls had vanished from sight in the immensity of a boundless wilderness.

"It was a curious scene when a party of coureurs de bois returned from their rovings. Montreal was their harboring place, and the coureurs themselves much like the crew of a mutinous ship off after a long voyage. As long as their boats were landed, they set no bounds to their riot. Every house in the place, we are told, was turned into a drinking shop. The newcomers were be-dizened with a strange mixture of French and Indian finery, while still tame, with instincts more thoroughly savage, stalked about the streets as makes of a Pottawattamie or a Sioux. The number of taverns was prodigious, and gambling and drunkards filled the day and the night. When at last they were sober again, they sought absolution for their sins; nor could the priests venture to bear too hard on their unruly penitents, lest they should break wholly with the church and dispense thenceforth with her sacraments."

Parkman wove his highly coloured fabric from threads spun by priestly and secular writers of the seventeenth century. Baron de Lahontan, the brightest of the secular yarn-spinners, wrote:

"You would be amazed if you saw how lewd these Pedlers are when they return; how they Feast and Game, and how prodigal they are, not only in their Cloaths, but upon Women. Such of them as have not been so happy as to have wisdom to retire to their own Country, lose their Bachelors act just as our East India Men and Pirates do; want to do; for they lavish, eat, drink, and play all away as long as the Goods hold out; and when these are gone, they e'en sell their Embroidery, their Lace, and their Cloaths. This done, they are forc'd to go upon a new Voyage for Subsistence."

In his table of terms, Lahontan gives this definition:

"Coureurs de Bois, i.e., Forest Rangers, are French of Canadese, so called from employing their whole Life in the rough Exercise of transporting Merchan-
dise Goods to the Lakes of Canada, and to all the other Countries of that Continent, in order to Trade with the Savages: And in regard that they run in Canowa a thousand Leagues up the Country, notwithstanding the danger of the Sea and Enemies, I take it, they should rather be called Coureurs de Risques, than Coureurs de Bois."

Less vivid in language, but just as telling is the account written by Nicolas Perrot, himself a coureur de bois, who describes his profession as consisting of:

"Young men in their prime—some of good family, others simple habitants or the children of others who are not so well off—call themselves 'volunteers'—this term for profit is common to them all—Some carry their own merchandise to the savage—others rent it from merchants. Some carry on the business for individuals, others take a share of the risk with merchants. All their victuals consist of some biscuit, peas, corn and some small barrels of brandy. They are soon reduced to living off the hunting and fishing they find along their route... When that give out they are reduced to eating a kind of moss which they call 'tripe de roche'."

It was therefore the lure of adventure rather than the prospect of rich living that enticed them from the settlements.

The native finery affected by the French who adopted the forest or bush rangers' life was natural to those who were frequently adopted as members of the Indian tribes in whose country they hunted. Their paint, feathers, and buckskins were, in any case, as practical and just as colourful as the costume of French court or regiment which the new-comers may have brought with them from France. We read of French interpreters and hunters in the woods armed with swords, but well-aimed tomahawks would have been just as effective weapons. When Jean Nicolet, Champlain's interpreter, arrived among the Winnebagoes in Wisconsin "arrayed in a robe of Chinese damask, decorated with flowers and birds of many colours", his costume was in keeping with Indian taste, so that he was identified by the natives as a medicine man.

The other day, while reading the story of Esau and Jacob in the 27th Chapter of the Book of Genesis, I thought of certain parallels in the relation between the coureurs de bois and habitants of Canada. For the coureur de bois and habitant, like Esau and Jacob, were also twin brothers, the one coming on the heels of the other, the hunter first; the coureurs de bois created friction in the family by mating with Indian girls, just as Esau brought grief to Isaac and Rebekah by marrying a Hittite; the coureur de bois pleased the menfolk who, like Isaac, were fond of venison, while the habitant curried favour with the womenfolk by staying at home instead of going off on long hunting trips.

Several hundred Canadians who had neglected to clear the land allotted to them so that they could lead the life of a coureur de bois forfeited their concessions.

Yet the hunter was left not unhappy. I quote Isaac's blessing on Esau as translated by Dr. James Moffat:

"Far from rich soil on earth shall you live,
far from the dew of heaven on high;
You shall live by the sword, and serve your brother
But when you grow restive,
his yoke you shall break."

The coureur de bois first came into definite disfavour when Talon became intendant in 1665, and this fall from grace is claimed by certain historians as due to the free and easy morals of the officers and soldiers of the Carignan Regiment, a thousand of whom were sent that same year to New France by Louis XIV to preserve the colony, its settlements, and its fur-trade from the marauding Iroquois.

But the real father of the coureur de bois was Samuel de Champlain.

The record goes back to the winter of 1606 at Port Royal in Acadia, when Champlain established the Order of Great Chief so as to keep up the health and spirits of the garrison. It was the duty of each of the fifteen members of that Order to provide in turn, from his hunting and trading, food for the whole company, and that genial historian Marc Lescarbot, a member of the Order, certifies to its success. When Champlain turned from Acadia to Quebec, fur-trading was his first intent, and he himself spent much of his time in the woods. He planted a number of his followers among the Indians to qualify as interpreters, and of eight of these we know something, namely—Etienne Brûlé, Jean Richer, Jean Nicolet, Jacques Hertel, Thomas Godefroy, François Marguerie, Nicholas Marsolet, and Grenolle.

The life of an interpreter had its lure, for the savage had his own civilization. Jean Richer had this impressed upon him after living two years among the Nipissings. "Good!" said a Chief to him one day. "Now that you are beginning to speak our language, if only you did not grow a beard, you would have almost as much intelligence as our second best Indians."

Etienne Brûlé was the first white man to reach Lake Superior, and pioneered for France as far south as the Susquehanna, but seems to have been too devil-may-care for Champlain. The mental picture I have of him is that of the Jack or Knave of Hearts. His had been a hard schooling among the Iroquois, including torture by fire—hence his soubriquet of Brûlé or "the burnt one." His final tragedy was
to be killed and eaten by hitherto friendly Hurons. The Indian philosophy of cannibalism was that the consumer absorbed the heroic virtues of the consumed, and the fact that these Hurons went the length of eating Etienne Brûlé indicates that they at least found in him qualities which they admired.

As coureur de bois for Guillaume and Emery de Caën, of the Montmorency Company, Etienne Brûlé received a salary of 100 pistoles ($200) a year for inducing the Indians to come down from the Upper Country with furs. This was probably the standard rate of pay at that time. In 1621 this Company had about a dozen coureurs de bois in its employ.

Shortly after Champlain died, a census of Quebec made in 1636 shows that of the 86 colonists, 11 were interpreters, 7 were traders, and 20 were trappers, as compared to 23 settlers, of whom the best known was Louis Hébert.

The French did not have a monopoly of the idea that money could be made out of the fur-trade in North America. It was through beaver-skins that the Pilgrim Fathers cleared off their indebtedness to the London merchants who financed their venture. At first their trade was a coastal trade, but as the local supply of beavers diminished, they explored new sources up the rivers Kennebec and Penobscot. Like the French, the English were soon faced by the liquor problem in this Indian traffic. Captain Miles Standish had to run out of the country a certain Thomas Morton for selling fire-water as well as firearms to the natives, in addition to operating a gambling hall in Massachusetts Bay, appropriately named Merrymount.

Although there were some large clearings made along the shores of the St. Lawrence by small groups of settlers, the fur-trade offered more prospect of dividends for the Company of a Hundred Associates, which now held a monopoly over Canada.

Charles Huault de Montmagny, who succeeded Champlain as governor of Quebec, has been described as a famous Nimrod. In 1646, the Queen Mother as Regent granted him exclusive privilege of hunting on two islands of the St. Lawrence, Île-aux-Oies, a natural bird sanctuary, and Île-aux-Coudres, on which he tried to domesticate the moose. Every seigneur under the feudal system had or acquired by purchase the birthright of le droit de chasse, and as sixty seigneuries were granted during the régime of the Hundred Associates, that meant there were sixty possible purveyors of peltries from that source. One could not expect that the skins obtained in hunting would be used only for clothing or for wall decoration.

In 1645 the habitants themselves took over the whole fur-trading business of New France as a co-operative concern known as the Compagnie des Habitants. They undertook to deliver 1,000 lbs. weight of beaver-skins a year, with the result that virtually all the able-bodied men in Canada spent the winter in the woods. In order to regulate things, the Council, in 1648, enacted that "such settlers as were accustomed to the country might, if they chose, go to the districts inhabited by the Hurons under the leadership of a Captain appointed by the Council. They should serve as escorts for the Missionaries going to the Indian countries, as also for the Indians themselves who wished to come down to the French posts to trade their furs."

The missionaries were thus themselves responsible for the growth of bushranging. Their escorts in the Indian country were permitted to gain their living by hunting and trading in furs, as they received no remuneration from the missions.

A flying squadron of forty men was organized to guard the rivers, lakes and portages.

When one considers that along the lower St. Lawrence dense forest grew to the river's edge and that it took at least four years to clear enough land to make a farm on which a family could live, one cannot blame the settler for taking to the woods in search of venison as well as furs.

In 1646 Médard Chouart des Groseillers left the service of the Jesuits to go fur-trading in the Huron country, and twelve years later took into partnership his brother-in-law, Pierre-Esprit Radisson, who had spent two years in captivity among the Iroquois. This warrior race drove the Hurons from their hunting grounds, and commanded the routes to the West so effectively that in 1653 the French-Canadian fur-trade on the St. Lawrence came virtually to a standstill. The Iroquois traded with the Dutch at Orange (Albany) and with the English on the Atlantic seaboard, so that if these two coureurs de bois had not re-opened the route to the Great Lakes, the French settlements along the St. Lawrence would have starved to death.

No wonder that when they returned from the Upper Country in 1660 with 300 Algonquins and 200,000 francs worth of furs, Groseillers and Radisson were received at Quebec with salvoes of artillery. They plied their trade together from 1654 to 1663, when Governor Baron d'Avaugour mulcted them of more than half their cargo of furs. Thereafter came the strange sequence of intrigues which resulted in their helping the English to launch the great Company of Adventurers trading into Hudson's Bay.

The royal favour at last begun to shine from France on Canada
with some effect when Mazarin died and Louis XIV took the reins into his own hands. The interest of Le Roi Soleil was spurred by the English absorption of the Dutch colonies in 1664 which made Orange, the present Albany, a still more dangerous rival to Quebec in the fur-trade. In trading with the Indians, the English and Dutch had the advantage of being able to supply not only cheaper, but also a greater variety of merchandise. Supplies from France came to Canada only once a year, and did not include the wampum and the scarlet cloth which the Indians particularly favoured. Hence the temptation among even the French traders to send beaver-skins to Orange.

Conditions in France made it possible for Louis to spare soldiers, find peasants and mechanics willing to emigrate, and induce unmarried girls to brave the Atlantic in sailing ships for husbands. Ground down by taxes, corvées, and the impositions of a feudal system, peasants were already migrating to the cities or slipping across the frontiers. It was not hard to persuade the impoverished country gentleman to become a soldier of fortune in the El Dorado of furs. Families were large and surplus girls were plentiful. Some at least of the Indians were friendly, even though the Iroquois were allies of the English.

Colbert, who was Louis's adviser in these matters, was a typical bureaucrat with a bureaucrat's love of doing things by rule and regulation. He had already adopted in France the policy of inducing young men to marry by remission of taxes, with bounties to families of ten or more, provided none of the ten became celibate priests or nuns. Richelieu's charter to the Hundred Associates specifically had in view "the establishment of a powerful military Colony" and the development of the fur-trade. Colbert aimed to make Canada a colony breeding its own soldiers, concentrated in easily defended communities, with a system of parishes and villages imported from Old France. So far as the fur-trade was concerned, he desired to regulate this by concentrating markets in Montreal, Three Rivers, and Quebec to which the Indians could bring their peltries. The coureurs de bois were more modern in their method of getting business, going into the Indian country themselves as pedlars. They might be described as the go-getters of the fur-trade.

Maisonneuve's organization of a militia with flying squadrons for the island of Montreal had not proved sufficient to hold back the Iroquois, so in 1665 the Carignan Regiment, a thousand strong, with probably two hundred more from other regiments, was sent under the Marquis de Tracy to strengthen the royal domain in North America. By this time Maisonneuve had at his command in Montreal over a hundred blue-coated frontier fighters who had acquired skill in Indian warfare as coureurs de bois.

The use of brandy in buying furs from Indians has been blamed on the Carignan Regiment, but antedated their arrival in Canada. As early as 1644 Governor Montmagny issued an edict threatening severe penalties for such traffic, but the sailors on vessels arriving from France smuggled in the liquor which provided such profit. In 1657, Jean Aubuchon was fined, and in 1661 two men were shot and another lashed for this offence. It was to protest in person to the King against this liquor traffic that Bishop Laval, forbidden to excommunicate the offenders, sailed for France in 1662, when he procured the recall of Governor d'Avaugour. The Sovereign Council, posting its decrees against this traffic throughout the settlements, complained in 1664 that almost all the colonists had contravened its prohibitions, hence great disorder among the Indians. In using brandy as merchandise, the French were, however, only meeting the competition of Dutch and English rum, which was not only cheaper but was also more lasting as a stimulant.

Whereas the English and Dutch colonists in North America came out chiefly as families, the French after 1634 made the mistake of sending out single men first. Louis XIV, with Colbert to prompt the afterthought, endeavoured to remedy this with shiploads of brides, some at least of whom might well have driven the settlers to the woods, if not to drink. Mère Marie de l'Incarnation, who on the whole sympathized with the idea of sending out brides for the bachelors, said of one shipload of new arrivals in 1667 that they included "beaucoup de canaille de l'un et l'autre sexe."

An instance of forced marriage is the case of François le Noir dit Rolland, who had a trading-post near Lachine. Under the rule that bachelors would be debarred from hunting, fishing, trading with the Indians or entering the woods, Rolland was threatened with confiscation unless he undertook to marry within three weeks of the arrival of the next shipload of brides. The wedding duly took place in the presence of Governor Perrot of Montreal and his confères in the fur-trade, and Rolland proceeded to do such business in liquor with the Indians that Frontenac had to intervene.

Supplementing the brides shipped from France, Mère Marie de l'Incarnation endeavoured to provide the colonists with an alternative though limited supply from the Indian girls who were taught the amenities of French civilization at the Ursuline convent in Quebec. Mère Marie had no race prejudice, but even her model pupils had a
tendency to disappoint her by reverting to type. Those who slipped back to the wigwams she not inaptly termed "les petites coureuses de bois."

The military strengthening of the colony made the route to the West less perilous, and a period of exploration and development followed. Louis Jolliet, organist at Quebec, accompanied by Jean Peré, classified as a coureur de bois, was commissioned by Governor de Coureille to go on a fur-trading and copper-finding expedition to Lake Superior in 1688. In this year it was affirmed by the Sovereign Council that there was hardly a band of Indians that did not have some French coureurs de bois with them.

The most notable coureur de bois who now appeared upon the scene was Nicholas Perrot, originally an interpreter, whose influence on the Indians contributed greatly to the Western expansion of the French. He was the leading figure as well as the historian of the ceremony at Sault Ste. Marie on June 14, 1671, when M. de Saint-Lusson took possession of Lakes Huron and Superior in the name of Louis XIV, most Christian King of France and of Navarre.

Twelve other coureurs de bois are named by Nicholas Perrot as present at Sault Ste. Marie, but none of these twelve appear on the register of the Carignan Regiment. Of the 400 members of this regiment who remained in Canada following their disbanding in 1668 only about a hundred became coureurs de bois. It was, however, probably a hundred too many. In this year the trade in liquor with the Indians was formally thrown open to all French inhabitants of Canada.

Seventeen of the Carignan officers are definitely known to have become interested in the fur-trade. The one most censured was Major Balthazar de Flotte de la Frédère, who commanded the garrison of Montreal, 1666-7, and was outlawed from the colony three years later. Three others were in the service of François Perrot, Governor of Montreal, who established one fort under Lafrenaye de Brucy, and another under Gabriel de Berthé, Sieur de Chailly, on opposite shores of rapids of the Ottawa River, at the western end of the island of Montreal, where the Indian canoes coming down to the settlements were waylaid and the cream of their cargoes skimmed in exchange for a more potent liquid. Associated with Brucy was another ex-Carignan officer, Philippe de Carrion, Sieur de Fresnoy, while a brother officer, Michel Sidrac Duguay, built a trading-post close to that of Gabriel Berthé.

In 1671, Intendent Talon wrote to Colbert that the number of coureurs de bois must be reduced. Fur-bearing animals were too much hunted, the market for beaver was glutted, and the price of fur in consequence was decreasing. On that account, when Frontenac came to Quebec as governor in 1672, he had instructions from King Louis to suppress the coureurs de bois and transform the colony into a farming community, protected by a few strategic forts. His first injunction forbade the Canadians to leave their settlement with merchandise under any pretext whatever unless protected by formal authority. Limits were set within which those absent might return. All goods held in contravention of these orders would be held as contraband, and severe penalties inflicted.

A lover of pageantry and display, Frontenac found conveyance by canoe hardly worthy of the King's representative in Canada and conceived the idea, among other things, of condemning offending coureurs de bois to the galleys, the galleys in mind being a ship of state in which the governor could travel with dignity through his domain.

Shortly after his arrival, Frontenac was persuaded by Robert Cavelier de la Salle that the best way to prevent the Iroquois from cutting into the trade with the Algonquin Indians of the Upper Country was to build a fort at Cataraquai, the site of the present Kingston, on Lake Ontario. An imposing flotilla of gaily decorated bateaux, mounted with cannon, and four squadrons of canoes convoyed the Governor to Cataraquai, where he made it clear to the delegates of the five Iroquois Nations that he was there to do business, announcing: "You will find all sorts of refreshments and commodities, which I shall cause to be furnished to you at the cheapest rate possible."

In the following year, La Salle himself was placed in charge of the fort and used it as a base for trading, exploring, and hunting along the neighbouring lakeshore. Six of La Salle's coureurs de bois are recorded in a French history of the brandy party, who had indulged in a barbarous dance called Galopinay, in which the performers ran in a state of nature with a keg of brandy under the arm. This was at the Mississauga Indian Village of Teiaiagon, on the site of the present capital city of Ontario, and is described by Percy J. Robinson as "a rather modestly beginning for Toronto the Good."

François Perrot, governor of the island of Montreal, had accompanied Frontenac on this expedition, possibly to divert attention from his own surreptitious activities on the Ottawa. If so, the attempt failed, for Frontenac sent Jacques Bizard, lieutenant of his guard, to suppress Perrot's business at Brucy's fort on Ile Perrot. As his authority was outrageously flouted, Frontenac arrested Perrot when
he came to Quebec, and hanged Thomas, one of his coureurs de bois, in front of his window. The governor of Montreal left in indignation for Paris, only to kick his heels for three weeks in the Bastille. A number of coureurs de bois were rounded up, and Frontenac boasted that he had suppressed the traffic; but if his clerical critics can be believed, the Indians continued to be debauched with liquor.

While fulminating against the coureurs de bois, Frontenac helped to add to their number through the establishment of a Canadian militia. King Louis had too many wars in Europe to ship more soldiers to Canada. Colbert wrote in June, 1673: "His Majesty cannot give any assistance to Canada this year on account of the great and prodigious expense that he has been obliged to incur for the maintenance of more than 200,000 men and 100 ships and 25 galleys."

Frontenac, therefore, created soldiers on the spot out of the habitants, whom he organized as a militia under local captains. These were armed at their own expense with muskets, which they paid for in monthly instalments, with permission to use them for hunting till they were required for military service. All the habitant now required to do to become a regular coureur de bois was to make contact with a fur-trader who could supply him with brandy and goods to trade with the Indians.

Emigration from France to Canada ceased in this year, and in 1674 Colbert advised the intendant not to count any more on assistance from the King. The distress throughout France became so great that Madame de Sévigné wrote from Brittany in 1680, "I see only people without means, who sleep upon straw and who weep." Colbert, echoing King Louis's own opinions, was inclined to approve of the liquor traffic, writing rather sarcastically to Intendant Duchesneau not to abolish the sale of brandy to the Indians. Otherwise, he wrote, "we should run the risk not only of losing this commerce, but of forcing the Savages to do business with the English and the Dutch, who are heretics; and it would thus become impossible for us to keep them favourably disposed towards the one pure and true religion."

By this time Frontenac had come to realize that the coureurs de bois could provide him with welcome information as to the friendliness or otherwise of the various Indian tribes towards each other and towards the French.

When Pierre Moreau la Taupine, on returning from trading with the Ottawas, in 1679, was arrested by Intendant Duchesneau, he produced a licence from the governor permitting him to travel to the Ottawas with two comrades to carry out secret orders.

The Intendant Duchesneau, primed by the clergy, claimed that Frontenac was issuing licences to trade and hunt to his personal friends, and on his representations the governor was required by Colbert to summon all coureurs de bois, licensed or unlicensed, to return to the settlements. A conference of the leading colonists was summoned by royal edict to meet at Quebec in October, 1678, to consider the problem of liquor traffic with the Indians. La Salle was one of the delegates, and defended this traffic as necessary, claiming that the Indians were less given to drink than the French, and even less than the English of New York. The royal edicts issued in 1679 limited the hunting permits from January 15 to April 15 each winter, and holders of permits were prohibited from carrying liquor to the Indians, though the French of the settlements could continue to sell liquor to Indians on the spot. An amnesty to those in the woods who returned at once to the settlements was proclaimed, and permits issued by the governor were limited to 25.

La Salle, no doubt with the cognizance of Frontenac, evaded the regulations by sending out from Fort Frontenac coureurs with his own permits to trade with the Indians.

Nicholas Perrot claimed that the prohibitions only made matters worse: "The Canadians," he wrote, "seeing themselves deprived of these franchises, became disorderly, thinking they had been deceived. That was the reason why most of the youth of the country went off and came back only in secret, looking for merchandise while bringing skins that were sold by stealth. This trade opened the eyes of the merchants who found it very much to their advantage, and who advanced to them what was necessary for their journey. Some opposed the orders from above. So much so that these Canadians became like savages, whose license they copied so well that they forgot what they owed to the duty and discipline of France; and if I dare say it, of Christianity itself."

Lawless and half-savage, the coureur de bois might have become, yet not wholly "fit for treason, strategems and spoils", for he had the saving grace of genius in himself, and more than any other kept alive the folk-song of the seventeenth century. As he paddled his canoe through the forested waterways, he sang the chansons of his time, songs which were passed on to his successors, the voyageur and the raftman. These songs had little apparent relation to his own life. They were songs of princes and princesses, of well-saddled cavaliers, of prisoners in far-off Nantes, of roses which he never saw in the depth of the woods, of gardens with orange trees, of shepherdesses guarding sheep—not of beaver, or moose, or deer. But
the melodies were rhythmic and helped to keep oars and paddles in time. In only two of Gagnon's *Chansons populaires* are there suggestions of the life of the coureur himself—one ballad, the *Lament of Cadioux*, which narrates an incident of conflict with the Iroquois, and one *Tenouche*! *Ouihika* introducing an ancient Huron. The seventeenth-century drinking songs, of which several hundred have survived, were not inappropriate to one who bought so many beaver-skins with liquor. *Mallouk s'en va à l'en guerre*, a favourite song with the voyagers of the eighteenth century, was probably brought to Canada after the battle of Malplaquet by La Vérendrye.

Duchesneau, the Intendant, became virulent in his antagonism and accused Frontenac of conniving with the coureurs de bois, and having notorious offenders such as La Taupine in his service. René Robineau de Bécancour, Baron de Portneuf, who was grand voyer or minister of roads, and Louis Bolduc, the public prosecutor, were also accused by Duchesneau of surreptitious traffic.

Frontenac's attitude towards the coureurs de bois was evidently tempered by the necessity of exploiting new fur yielding territories in the West. Daniel Greysolon Du Lhut may have had something to do with this. Duchesneau accused Du Lhut of being one of the chiefs of the gangs "indifferent to all the royal ordinances whom the complicity of Frontenac had encouraged to practise with impunity their trade of coureurs de bois."

Yet Du Lhut was no gangster. Formerly an officer in the King's Body Guard, he came to Canada with private means, built one of the most substantial houses in Montreal, and then after four years started out with his brother La Tourette on an exploring expedition to Lake Superior. There he won the confidence of the Indians as a brave, fair-dealing man, and, in spite of the handicap of gout, the West became his stamping-ground. Duchesneau wished Frontenac to organize a military expedition against this leader of coureurs de bois, but Frontenac excused himself, explaining to Colbert the political danger of an expedition which would throw the bushrangers into the arms of the English. When Du Lhut returned from the West, after exploring the headwaters of the Mississippi, organizing a re-union of friendly Indians at Fond du Lac, on Lake Superior, and establishing western headquarters at Kaministiquia (site of the present Fort William), Frontenac technically imprisoned him in the Château St. Louis at Quebec to save him from the claws of the intendant.

Frontenac by this time realized that these western coureurs de bois could be organized as a legion of frontiersmen, skilled in Indian ways and Indian warfare, able to live off the land without draining the public treasury, adventurous spirits willing to fight so long as they were not forced to farm or fettered by bureaucrats and priests. The coureur de bois was Esau the hunter, not Jacob the stay-at-home goatherd. As a matter of fact, by the year 1681, according to Henri Lorin, the sanest of the French historians, "the country had as many farm workers as it needed, and the over-production of grain explains the number of coureurs de bois as much as the supposed dislike of the colonists for sedentary life."

Irritated by the quarrels of Governor Frontenac and Intendant Duchesneau, King Louis recalled them both, sending out Joseph Antoine Lefebvre de La Barre as governor and Chevalier Jacques de Meulles as intendant. If Frontenac had dipped his fingers in the fur-trade, La Barre was in it up to the armpits. In the words of Henri Lorin:

"The Governor, the Intendant, the Magistrates, the Officials, in a word, every one traded. Meulles admitted that, to pay the salaries of his secretaries, he had sold two congés which brought him each 700 livres. The Intendant of Three Rivers (de Varennes) traded at least once a fort, nearby his seat of command; the Intendant of Montreal far from blaming him, knowing that de Varennes had supported a family, and that he would not be able to live without a little contraband. The Governor alone could have prevented these abuses, but he himself was friendly to the coureurs de bois, and shared in their gains. He increased the congés to such an extent that the trade became ruined, and later declared that in this way he had neutralized the French War."

La Salle was out of favour. Fort Frontenac and its contents were taken over in the interests of his creditors; while Chevalier de Baugis and Olivier Morel, Sieur de la Durantaye, were sent to occupy his forts in the Illinois country. Nicholas Perrot was dispatched to Green Bay; Du Lhut received a congé to trade in the Sioux country, and had 30 coureurs de bois with him when he left Michilimakinac. René Le Gardeur, Sieur de Beauvais, with thirteen associates, received a permit to trade with the Illinois at the lower end of Lake Michigan. By the year 1684 the number of canoes in trade with regular congés amounted to 120 instead of the 25 stipulated in the ordinance of 1681.

The Court continued to hurl ordinances against contraband traffic, and La Barre, to cover his delinquencies, started a campaign against the Iroquois. Du Lhut, Perrot and Durantaye were summoned to bring reinforcements of coureurs de bois to join La Barre's expeditionary force at Niagara. Du Lhut brought 200 of these frontiersmen, only to be turned back by the news that a truce had been made with the Iroquois at La Famine.

The Marquis de Denonville, who succeeded La Barre as governor, is said by Vicar-General de Saint-Vallier to have "spent nearly all
his time in prayer and the reading of good books." According to the vivacious chronicle of Baron de La Hontan, Canada was no place for a gay life. "You have in Europe," he writes "at least the diversions of the Carnival, but here it is a perpetual Lent." Denonville's first reaction to the bushrangers was not favourable:

"You are aware, Monseigneur, that the coureurs de bois are a great evil, but you are not aware how great this evil is. It deprives the colony of its effective men; makes them useless, lawless, and incapable of discipline, and turns them into thieves and robbers, wearing the sword and decked out with lace, both they and their relations, who all affect to be gentlemen and ladies. As for cultivating the soil, they will not bear of it."

Incursions of English traders into French territory, however, compelled Denonville to modify his views. Du Lhut was sent in 1686 to restore the fort at Detroit and to establish a port which he named Fort Joseph, between Lake Erie and Lake Huron, to bar the English invaders, and this latter post was garrisoned at Du Lhut's own charges by coureurs de bois. La Durantaye was put in general command of western posts, and when in the following year Denonville decided to lead a campaign against the Iroquois, he called on La Durantaye to bring contingents of bushrangers organized by Du Lhut and Nicholas Perrot to join him at Niagara. These led the van of an expedition which proved fruitless, although La Durantaye and Du Lhut between them captured sixty English traders on the way. These English traders had been guided by a French coureur de bois, La Fontaine Marion, who was shot by Denonville for his pains.

Following this expedition, La Hontan went south with a detachment of soldiers to explore the country westward of Green Bay, and incidentally indicates the numbers and activities of the bushrangers in the Great Lakes territory. Michilimackinac and Sault Ste. Marie were busy centres of trade with the Indians, and he found thirty coureurs de bois working for Tonti, who maintained La Salle's old post at Crèvecoeur, in the Illinois country. Michilimackinac was headquarters for La Durantaye, whom Denonville had named "Commander of the Coureurs de bois that trade upon the Lakes and in the Southern Counties of Canada."

In 1688 Nicholas Perrot was sent with forty men to trade with the Sieux and take possession of the Upper Mississippi in the name of King Louis. Denonville evidently realized that such expansion was necessary for the maintenance of the fur-trade, but losing heart through the incursions of the Iroquois, nearer home, evacuated Fort Niagara and Fort Frontenac in the following year. Fortunately for the French dominion, he was recalled, and Frontenac once more was sent out as governor.

Frontenac came back to Canada none too soon, for the massacre of Lachine had placed the Island of Montreal at the mercy of the Iroquois, and vigorous action was required to restore communication with the western posts.

Philippe de Rigaud, Marquis of Vaudreuil, named lieutenant-governor of Montreal in the absence of Governor de Courcelles, had organized, in 1688, a hundred coureurs de bois on the island into a company which he called Musketeers. He himself had been a Colonel of the Musketeers in France. These men may have been the hundred coureurs de bois whom Frontenac on his arrival in Canada, sent under the command of Nicholas d'Aillebout, Sieur de Manthet, to re-establish Fort Frontenac on Lake Ontario. Thereafter Manthet, together with Jacques Le Moyne, Sieur de Sainte-Hélène, led over a hundred coureurs de bois on the western division of an expedition against the English colony of Corbier, six leagues from Orange. Following this expedition, these bushrangers were sent on another expedition to Lake Champlain. Their worth as frontier fighters was now thoroughly realized.

Du Lhut was sent to disperse a band of Iroquois who controlled the Ottawa fur-trade route at Lake of Two Mountains, and Louis de la Porte Louvigny was dispatched with Nicholas Perrot and 143 Canadians to relieve La Durantaye at Michilimackinac.

Three more years of border warfare with the English and Iroquois had to be waged before the trade-routes were safe for the fur brigades. In 1693 a huge flotilla of Indians with two hundred coureurs de bois who had been accumulating furs in the territory of the Great Lakes came down with rich cargoes to Montreal. There was great rejoicing at first, but the result was that the market for furs soon became glutted. In 1695 there were two million livres worth of beaver-skins unsold in stores. The number of coureurs was once more reduced. In 1696 control of the export was placed in the hands of a local company of 150 merchants, but even so there came to be such a surplus of beaver-skins that three-fourths of it was deliberately burned. In 1697 Frontenac had to issue orders that all the French in the woods must return to the Lower St. Lawrence before September of the following year, but Tonti arrived from Michilimackinac to report that the coureurs refused to come in.

By the year 1700, Michilimackinac had become the centre of the western fur-trade. Antoine de la Mothe-Cadillac was commandant, and the liquor traffic was countenanced to the extent that even the soldiers of the garrison were permitted to sell brandy to the Indians. The coureurs de bois occupied a street of log cabins roofed with cedar.
hark built along the shore of the bay, while the Hurons and Ottawas lived in adjoining villages surrounded by a triple palisade. In spite of the opposition of the Montreal merchants, La Mothe-Cadillac obtained authority from France to establish a new fort on the site of the present Detroit (1701). When he was transferred, in 1710, to Louisiana, his successor, Alfonse de Tonti, received instructions to return the French and Canadians at Michilimackinac to Montreal. Only twenty of these obeyed, while 84 descended the Mississippi with their furs and delivered them to Louisiana.

Another blow to the ascendancy of Montreal as a fur-market was struck when in 1717 Illinois was detached from New France and incorporated with Louisiana. Moreover, the English were seriously encroaching on French preserves. Albany offered a more lucrative market not only to the Great Lakes around Lake Ontario and Lake Erie, but also to those who came down from Lake Huron and beyond over the Toronto Carrying-Place, the short cut to and from the Western Lakes, which was rapidly replacing the old Ottawa-Lake-Nipissing-Rainy River route. Unlicensed coureurs de bois, knowing themselves outlawed, saw no reason why they should not trade with the English. A hundred years before, Etienne Brûlé had made this clear. When Champlain reproached him for taking services with Sir David Kirke, he replied that "since a comfortable future was not before him in France, the die was cast and he would live with the English."

In the North and Far West, the Hudson's Bay Company posts diverted a large share of the furs which might otherwise have come to Montreal.

Charles Marquis de Beauharnois, appointed governor of New France in 1728, realized the need of combating this menace and under his regime the posts along the St. Lawrence route were strengthened, while Pierre Gaultier de la Verendrye was supported in a series of expeditions which carried the fleur de lys by way of Rainy River and Lake of the Woods to Lake Winnipeg, the Assiniboine River, the Western Prairies and the fur country immediately tributary to Hudson Bay.

By this time the coureur de bois, or independent peddler, was giving place to the regularly engaged voyageur working for merchants who had secured congés. According to the records catalogued by E. Z. Massicotte for the Quebec Archives, the number of voyageurs employed in the western trade from 1731 to 1745 averaged nearly 300 a year, the peak being reached in 1741 with 380.

With the transfer of New France to Great Britain, Albany once more threatened the supremacy of Montreal, but the Scottish merchants who took over and developed the fur-trade along the St. Lawrence waterways made Montreal once more the centre of operations. These at first were hard times for Canadians of French extraction; yet those who accepted the British dominion remained loyal to the throne when the American colonies declared for Independence.

An interesting case is that of Charles-Michel de Langlade (1729-1800), a grandson of Pierre Mouet, Sieur de Moras, who had been an ensign in the Carignan Regiment. Augustin, the father of Charles Michel, assumed the name of l'Anglade, and became a fur-trader of Three Rivers. Charles-Michel was born at Michilimackinac, and in 1755 headed a band of coureurs de bois and Indians in an attack on Fort Duquesne, site of the present Pittsburgh. In 1759 he fought under Montcalm at the battle of the Plains of Abraham, but after the capture of Montreal returned to Michilimackinac, where he witnessed the massacre of the English garrison by Pontiac's Indians in 1763. In 1777 we find him serving with an Indian contingent under General Burgoyne against the colonials, and, when the revolutionary war ended he returned to Michilimackinac as a British subject.

Another interesting case is that of Jean-Baptiste Cadotte, originally a coureur de bois, who married an Indian of the Sauteur tribe, named Anastasia. While he was in charge of the fort at Sault Ste. Marie under the French régime, Cadotte is found in partnership with Alexander Henry at that point in 1765.

In reviewing the history of Canada during the eighteenth century, one realizes that the French-speaking fur-traders were now Canadians rather than French, and in this growth of a new nationality the coureur de bois played a notable part. Inter-marriage with Indians made the bushranger indifferent to European tradition, particularly as his ancestral France had been so stepfatherly. As merchants and as employers the British provided him with a better living, and under British rule he was not subject to unpaid corvées of the feudal system, while he was allowed the liberty of religion, if religion still controlled his conscience.

In the expansion of the white man's dominion towards the West, the half-breed progeny of the coureurs de bois served as a liaison with the Indian tribes. To that liaison is due the more peaceful penetration of the West in British North America than was the experience of the United States. To so many Americans, the only good Indian was a dead Indian, and this brutal attitude had its repercussion in the Indian wars and massacres which stain with blood the pages of American history in the nineteenth century.
The mentality of the coureur de bois was inherited by the voyageur working for the Hudson's Bay Company, and what that mentality was can best be illustrated from the account of his life given to Alexander Ross by one whom he calls a "superannuated son of the wilderness." This was a voyageur over seventy years of age who worked his passage by convoying Ross from Norway House to the Red River Settlement. "I have now," said he, "been forty-two years in this country. For twenty-four I was a hard canoe-boat; I required but little sleep, but sometimes got less than I required. No voyage was too long for me; all places were alike. My end of the canoe never touched the ground till I saw the end of it. Fifty songs a day were nothing to me. I could carry, paddle, walk and sing with any man I ever saw. During that period, I saved the lives of ten Bourgeois, and was always the favourite, because when others stopped to carry at a bad step and lost time, I pushed on—over rapids, over cascades, over chutes; all were the same to me. No water, no weather, ever stopped the paddle or the song. I have had twelve wives in the country; and was once possessed of fifty horses, and six running dogs, trimmed in the first style. I was then like a Bourgeois, rich and happy; no Bourgeois had better-dressed wives than I; no Indian Chief finer horses; no white man better-harnessed or swifter dogs. I beat all the Indians at the race, and no white man ever passed me in the chase. I wanted for nothing; and I spent all my earnings in the enjoyment of pleasure. Five hundred pounds, twice told, have passed through my hands; although now I have not a spare shirt to my back, nor a penny to buy one. Yet, were I young again, I should glory in commencing the same career again. I would willingly spend another half century in the same fields of enjoyment. There is no life so happy as a voyageur's life; none more independent—a place where a man enjoys so much variety and freedom as in the Indian country. Huzza! huzza! pour le pays sauvage!"1

1Alexander Ross, The fur-hunters of the far west (London, 1855), vol. 2, p. 235.

Dear Major MacKay:

In a letter 1-1-4 dated November 22nd 1938 from the Indian Affairs Branch authority was given to me to expend up to $20.00 during the fiscal year 1938-39 on the purchase, from the Text Book Branch, B.C. Department of Education, Victoria, of British Columbia Programmes of Study for such Indian schools as were in urgent need of such Programmes. I would request that in line with the procedure adopted during the past three or four years, I be given authority to arrange for the distribution of any urgently necessary Programmes during the present fiscal year 1939-40 at a cost of not more than $20.00.

With reference to Departmental letter 154-0-6 dated January 15, 1938 and previous authorizations, I would also request authority to purchase from the Text Book Branch Provincial Department of Education necessary testing material including B.C. Achievement Tests, All Canada Arithmetic Tests, and Otis Tests of Mental Ability for use in inspection work at Indian schools during the fiscal year 1939-40. The Department has on file copies of the testing material used and I may say that such material is of the greatest use to me. All material previously purchased has been used and authority is now requested to purchase tests up to a total cost of $20.00 during the present fiscal year.

At a number of Indian day schools teachers desire to supply their pupils with Report Forms, now called in B.C. Progress Cards, and in several districts Indian parents are very anxious that their children should have the same reports as pupils of Provincial Schools.

Dear Mr. Bustace:

With reference to your recent letter regarding the primer to follow "Two Little Indians" I have reviewed our file and enclose copy of my letter of May 9, 1938.

On re-reading this I find that it does not give a great deal of definite information.

You wrote me a letter dated July 27, 1938, explaining the reason for quoting a price for the new primer which would be considerably higher than that charged for "Two Little Indians". From the contents of this letter I realize why the price for the primer will be higher than for "Two Little Indians".

In the event of your proceeding with the new primer we will use it in Indian schools and the number of copies will be approximately the same as the number of "Two Little Indians" that were ordered. In this event I feel certain that your firm will deal fairly with us in the matter of price and if you have the books prepared we would like to have them available by the middle of June, 1940, in order that we could include them on our requisitions for the academic year 1940-41.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Mr. Phelan—

A few days ago we received an order from the Department of Public Printing and Stationery for 500 copies of the Joe and Ruth Work Book. We could fill only 100, as this cleaned us out of stock.

Now the question arises as to whether we are to reprint. We shall do so, of course, if it is your intention to keep this book on your list and to use it to the extent that your Department has been doing for so many years. We shall have to reprint 6,000 if we are to continue to supply at the net price that has obtained for some two or three years, and which represents a considerable discount from the original published price.

Would you kindly advise us, at your convenience, in this matter, for the convenience of all concerned?

Yours sincerely,

Dear Major MacKay:

In Departmental letter l-l-4, dated September 21, 1939, authority was given to me to expend up to $20 during the fiscal year 1939-40 on the purchase from the Text-Book Branch, B.C., Department of Education, Victoria, of British Columbia Programs of Study for such Indian schools as were in urgent need of such programs. The total expended under this authorization was only $7.55.

I would request that in line with the procedure adopted during the past four or five years I be given authority to arrange for the distribution of any necessary programs during the present fiscal year, 1940-41, at a cost of not more than $15.

Although authorization was given in the above quoted Departmental letter for the expenditure of $20 in the purchase of testing material, this sum was not actually spent, as a matter of economy.

There is an increasing number of candidates for promotion to high school each year and I find it necessary to supply the Provincial Inspectors of Schools with the marks obtained by our Grade 8 Indian pupils in certain tests, particularly the Otis Group Test in mental ability and the Dominion Achievement Test. My testing material is now completely used up and I would request authority to purchase from the Text-Book Branch, Provincial Department of Education, testing material found to be absolutely necessary, not to exceed a total cost of $20, during the present fiscal year.

If authorization is given by the Department for expenditure within the limits mentioned above, and I trust it will be, vouchers, with the necessary invoices attached, would be forwarded through you to the Department for settlement before the close of the present fiscal year in March 1941.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Dear Phil—

Please do not think me a nuisance, but there is just the chance that my former letter re the arrival of "Joe and Ruth Go to School" either did not reach you, or, if you are like me, it is one of the things that got misplaced. Miss Brett constantly reminds me of things that I have not done that I should have done, and when I try to find the letters, nine times out of ten there is the wildest confusion in an endeavour to find the "secret" hiding place!

Seriously, wouldn't you like your schools to begin work on the new book during the present term? Naturally, we would like to dispose of as many as possible in the current fiscal year, but your convenience will be ours.

Do you know, I've changed my opinions about the people of the land of my birth? In spite of their irritating ways under normal conditions, when it comes to unprecedented testing times they are good, aren't they? And in spite of the horrors, we cannot persuade any of our intimate friends and relatives to come over here, at least for the duration. They appear to "see it through with everyone else". No one can "liek" that spirit. At such times they appear to be greater fighters than the Irish, under normal conditions. But you're not an Irishman; like myself, you're a Canadian!

With kindest regards, I am

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

H.B./LB

Dear Phil:

Thanks very much for yours of yesterday File 1-1-4 re the Charts to accompany TWO LITTLE INDIANS.

There was no desire on our part to "high-pressure" you into taking the lot. Your previous letter did not specify any quantity; we asked for information regarding stock, so we gave you the whole works.

I think the regulations to which you allude, viz., not to over-stock, are sound, and we would be the last in the world to attempt to entice, induce or seduce you to evade them in the slightest on our account. Naturally, we would like to clear the "blocking" out right, but there is a limit to our desires in such matters, under existing conditions. But don't think that this is a permanent virtue; for when this present "block" is over, we shall resort to all the cunning and skill (if any!) at our command along the lines with which, I fear, you are all too familiar.

On Mr. Phelan's return to the office I discussed very carefully with him the question of books, etc., supplied to our Indian schools.

For your information I attach copy of circular letters issued on April 15, 1940, March 15, 1941, December 3, 1941 and March 25, 1942. You will note from these that since the outbreak of the war we have endeavoured to supply only those books and articles that are absolutely necessary to successfully conduct our schools.

You will no doubt be interested to know that for the fiscal year 1941-42 the total expenditure for all classroom supplies, with the exception of desks, was $36,764.00. This amount covered not only the original cost of books and other classroom supplies, but also included the cost of transporting them to each school. The amount also included not only the books, scribblers, drawing books, pencils and other like equipment supplied for the individual pupil, but the cost of such general classroom supplies as chairs, blackboard brushes and other requisites for classrooms. The total average attendance at all schools during the same fiscal year was 13,935. Consequently, the average pupil cost of supplying all texts, etc., to which I have just referred above was $2.75. I feel that this is an extremely reasonable figure and, from my experience, compares very favourably with expenditures made by provincial departments of education in those provinces where free school books are supplied by the provincial government. In a recent conversation with you you made some mention of supplying plasticine. As you are aware, this is a moulding unit. It develops a creative mind and gives the child an opportunity to render his ideas concrete. It is ideal to bring in the elements of mechanical drawing. As a result of what I have just stated, the use of plasticine is strongly recommended by educationalists.

R.A. Hey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Allan,

I think you know that the manuscript for *The Beaver* and the *Muskrat* has been finally approved, and that we are now at work producing the book. We plan to incorporate *The Story of Mary Meeking*, which you were kind enough to hand to me. Do we have permission to use this material, or will it be necessary to write a formal letter to your friend asking for such permission? I hope it will not be necessary to write such a letter, because I suppose the mail service in the north country is slow, but we shall be guided by what you say. If we do have to write, would you please give me the name of your friend?

Another point which we should be clear on is the matter of the tables of the breeding of beaver. We are taking this information and the general idea of the little illustrations of beaver, kits, and yearlings from the little Hudson Bay booklet. I suppose this material is really the copyright of the Hudson Bay Company, and that we should ask their permission, even though it might be argued that the figures are simply statistical facts. We shall not copy their drawings, but follow the same general plan. I shall be grateful if you will tell me the proper man to write to in the Hudson Bay Company and his address.

We are anxious to make fast progress on our book, and so shall appreciate it if you are able to reply immediately.

Cordially yours,

[Signature]
