Dear Phil,

As you will see from the dummy enclosed with this letter, we are making progress on The Beaver and the Muskrat. We have had an artist spend quite some time on the cover, because the cover of a book is an important thing. We have tried out your suggestion of having simply a drawing of a beaver and a muskrat on the cover and no lettering. However, this did not look well, particularly since it is not possible in a thin book of this nature to print anything on the shelf back. We, therefore, modified your idea, and I think you will be pleased with the sketch which we have finally had made. Incidentally, this is only a preliminary sketch and not a final drawing.

We think we shall probably have a large drawing made, and print it on the inside cover and first page of the book — on what we call the end leaves, which in the case of this dummy are India colour paper. This is an effective device to add attractiveness to a book. On the first two pages you will find a pencilled rectangle, which marks the limits of the type page. On several pages we plan to have marginal sketches as shown in the dummy. In addition, we shall of course have numerous photographs.

The cover on this book is a little too inflexible. We are thinking of using something which is a little springier and which will not crack as readily as this cover. You will note the cloth reinforcing strip down the back of the book. This adds greatly to the strength.

I am disturbed about the way our costs are mounting up. The chief trouble is the smallness of the edition which we can print. It is my understanding that you would take about 2,500 of these books immediately, and that you would agree to take a total of 2,500 later on. This means that the cost of the art work and the engraving must be spread over this small number of books. Since we are making a deluxe book, this runs the cost up to approximately 50¢ a copy. Will this be satisfactory to you?

In our original talks, I suggested a price of around 40¢, but at that time I thought we could adapt the book for sale in non-Indian schools. You will recall that this plan did not seem feasible from your point of view, and so we look for only a nominal sale outside the Indian schools.

In normal times we could have probably made a small edition such as this much cheaper, for it used to be possible to get job lots of paper and to get an artist who could
fit in a small job like this between other larger jobs, and give us a good price rather than be idle for a week or so. Then, too, the printers were always clamouring for work, and would frequently quote a low price for a special job of this nature. That is all a thing of the past, and everyone is so busy that to tell the truth they don't want to be bothered with small jobs. By leaving out the printed end papers, the marginal illustrations, and so on, we could get a much lower price, but when all is said and done the amount of money involved is not very large, and I feel, in view of the importance of the book to your conservation programme, we should make it just as good looking as possible.

When you reply to this letter, will you please return this dummy? Incidentally, I should like to hear from you by return, if possible, so that we can order the paper and give the artist the final go-ahead signal.

Cordially yours,

[Signature]

J.

To Teachers of Indian Day Schools:

With reference to your requisition for classroom supplies for the academic year 1943-44, it has been decided to follow the same procedure as in the past two years.

Consequently you should forward to the Department, not later than May 1st, 1943, a requisition for materials required in 1943-44. By so doing, it will enable the officials of this Branch and the officials of the Government Stationery Office to have requisitions completed and shipped before the date of the re-opening of Indian day schools.

Owing to present conditions every endeavour must be made to keep expenditure as low as possible. It is not our intention to deprive any school of the necessary texts, etc., but for the duration of the war it is hoped that those preparing requisitions will do so with the thought in mind that only the necessary text-books, etc., are ordered. It will not be possible to consider supplying any large assortment of kindergarten materials, such as folding paper, number builders, etc. Therefore, if requests are received for large quantities of these articles, this Branch will only supply what is considered necessary. In addition, it will be impossible to secure, for the duration of the war, the following articles:

- Erasers,
- Rubber Bands,
- Pencil Sharpeners,
- Reeds,
- Pen Nibs,
- Hectograph Refill
- Blotting Paper, 19 x 24.

The teachers should note that water colours in boxes are extremely difficult to secure and, consequently, it has been decided that, for the duration of the war, the Department will only supply water colour refills in Red, Blue and Yellow.

I feel certain that you will cooperate with us in the above regard. ONLY ONE COPY OF THE REQUISITION IS NECESSARY.

Dear Sister,

Mr. Phelan of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has written me today asking me to send you a copy of the Workbook for Happy Days, since you are thinking of introducing the New Canadian Catholic Corona Readers into your school.

It gives us great pleasure to comply with Mr. Phelan's request, and we are sending you this book today. However, it is not clear from his letter if you are familiar with the revised series of readers, and so we are sending you, with our compliments, a complete set of the books published so far, namely, Happy Days, Playscripts, Paths of Grace, Tales to Tell, Stories for Every Day, Treasure Trove, Fact and Fancy, and the Manual to accompany Happy Days.

Wide Horizons, the last book of the series (for grade eight) is presently in press, and will be published about the beginning of August. We shall be glad to send you a copy of this book also as soon as it is ready.

Probably you are familiar with the old Canadian Catholic Corona Readers, and so we are sure you will be much interested in looking over the new books, which without any question are the finest and most scientifically prepared series of readers, Catholic or secular, which have been published in Canada so far.

I would draw your attention to the extremely careful vocabulary control in the books for the first three grades. You will find some references to this in the descriptions of Happy Days, Playscripts, and Paths of Grace on the second and third pages of the enclosed memorandum, as well as on the last pages of each of the books mentioned and on pages 63, 64, and 65 of the Teachers' Manual.

No other Canadian series even approaches this vocabulary control, which is in accord with the most modern pedagogical thought and naturally makes for greater ease in reading and, consequently, more rapid progress in the primary grades.
Sister Sheila

We have been most careful in the preparation of this series to include no material which is unsuitable for Indian schools. You will find, for example, in the stories of Canadian history that we have no references to blood thirsty savages.

Each book is bound in a different colour and has a distinctive title and cover design. The cloth used is waterproof, so that the books may readily be kept clean by the use of a sponge and a mild soap.

If there is any further information you would like to have, please be sure to write to us.

Perhaps I should add that the New Canadian Catholic Corena Readers have been authorized for use in the separate schools of Saskatchewan, Ontario, and Quebec, the only Canadian provinces in which readers for separate schools are authorized by the departments of education. In addition, the readers are authorized for use in all the Catholic schools of Newfoundland. You will see, therefore, that practically every Catholic school in Canada uses these fine new books.

Cordially yours,

[Signature]

September 1945

Mr. Phillip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Phillip:

We are in a quandary. We are out of print of TWO LITTLE INDIANS and according to reliable information from England the cost of the reprint would make it necessary for us to charge you in the neighborhood of 30 cents instead of 20 cents as in the past, and at that we would have to print 10,000 copies.

The point is that we could not reprint without an assurance from you that we could safely do so, as the bulk of the orders in the past four years for this book have come from your department.

I know that on the face of it you must think that a jump from twenty to thirty cents is out of all reason, but based on London's charges I can assure you it isn't.

Whilst I am on the subject, is there any hope of you being able to reduce our stock of JOE AND RUTH GO TO SCHOOL? You will remember that we printed a large quantity after consultation with you, in order to keep the price down to a reasonable figure. We still have nearly 10,000 copies in stock. Incidentally, we sold only 176 in 1945, which means that you weren't able to use them during the last school year.

Is there any chance of you being able to substitute JOE AND RUTH GO TO SCHOOL for TWO LITTLE INDIANS? By the way, even if we placed the order at once, London advises us that they could not ship TWO LITTLE INDIANS before January of next year.

It goes without saying that we shall reprint TWO LITTLE INDIANS if you wish us to do so and if, of course, you will undertake to absorb an edition of 10,000 within the period that it has taken us to dispose of the last 10,000 printing, viz., 2½ years.

I hope we will be able to realize that we are not trying to "hold you up" or to "high-pressure" you in any way. If you feel

P.S.
Ottawa,
September 18, 1943.

Dear Henry:

I regret that I have not replied sooner to your recent letter regarding "Two Little Indians". In view of all the circumstances I do not think it would be advisable to reprint this book at the present time. I have noted your reference to "Joe and Ruth Go to School". We will substitute this for "Two Little Indians" and in this way I hope that during the current academic year we will reduce your stock of the latter book considerably.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Philip Phalen,

Dear Phil:

Thanks very much for yours of the 16th. File 1-1-4. I am not a bit surprised, of course, that you do not think it would be advisable to reprint TWO LITTLE INDIANS at the present time. Frankly I agree with those who are unfamiliar with the facts, such an increase would suggest profiteering. Therefore, I for one would rather do without the business than take the risk of being suspected of such conduct at any time, let alone times like these.

It is very pleasing to know that in the meantime you will substitute JOE AND RUTH GO TO SCHOOL. There is no doubt but that this book will serve the purpose reasonably well until such time as it will be commercially possible for all of us to reprint TWO LITTLE INDIANS.

Again many thanks, and with kindest regards, I am

Yours sincerely,

MEMORANDUM:

MR. HOEY

Re: Readers and Supplementary Readers

Inspectors and teachers have occasionally criticized the books sent from this office to Indian Schools. Undoubtedly, the frequent changes of Inspectors has made it difficult to satisfy changing opinion. However, the choice and distribution of books for Indian Schools could be more systematic hence more efficient and less liable to criticism. May I submit the following as a starting point for discussion:

Readers:

The following chart summarises the readers used in the Provinces:

1. Maritimes: The Corona Readers. All the Indian Schools in these Provinces are under the direction of Roman Catholics.

2. Quebec: Treasury Readers. Two sets are authorized in this province. The Elson Basic Readers and the Treasury Readers.

3. Ontario: The Treasury Readers.

4. All the Western Provinces: Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia authorize the Highroads to Reading.

5. All the Catholic Schools use the Corona Reader.

It will be noticed from the above that the Highroads to Reading are used in the majority of the Provinces. It might be remarked that the Treasury Readers and the Highroads to Reading are very much alike if not identical.

The above mentioned Readers are used for Grades one to grades six inclusive. In grades seven and eight two texts are used:

1. Canada Book of Prose and Verse authorized in Nova Scotia, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia.

2. Life and Literature authorized in Quebec, Ontario, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia.
It is not necessary to give the history of the "Highroads to Reading" as the background of this series is well known. Teacher's manual and workbooks, which are a decided advantage, are published with this series.

It would appear from the above that the following suggestions might be considered:

1. The Department should choose the "Highroads to Reading and the Corona Readers as the authorized Readers for Indian Schools.

2. Due to examination requirements both texts for seventh and eighth grade should be authorized. The demand for these grades is very limited.

3. Indian Schools located in the Provinces that authorized different Readers than the Highroads to Reading should be supplied with copies of the Readers authorized for those provinces, these readers to be used as supplementary readers.

Supplementary Readers:

The purchase and distribution of Supplementary readers, at least in the primary grades, should be continuous as regards their vocabulary. By this is meant that the pre-primer vocabulary forms the basis for the primer. The enriched primer vocabulary is now used as the basis for the first book, and so on. It follows that these books should be supplied in complete series.

A careful examination of the supplementary readers authorized for the different Provinces will reveal that the Provinces have chosen the same readers. The selection of these readers besides being a judicious choice would obviate a great deal of the criticism.

Permit me to suggest that the representatives of the Publishing Companies be asked to submit a list of their books to this Office two weeks before they display them in the city. This procedure would permit us to make a more judicious choice.

Library Books:

Library books for Indian Schools should be very simple. A child will take pleasure in reading a book that is below its level. The reading of a book at the pupil's age level entails a great deal of application. A pupil will do this if he must do it, but as the reading of library books is usually left to the discretion of the pupil generally he is not ready to make this effort. This is probably more so for Indian children. This principle should be kept in mind when library books are selected for Indian Schools.

I would like to make the same suggestion for the choice of Library Books as I have made for the selection of Supplementary Readers, that Publishing Companies be asked to also submit lists of their Library Books.
The Department aims to encourage the activity movement of education. Library books, therefore, should be selected with this aim in view.

These suggestions are made so that free discussions will discover means to eliminate all criticism that might have some justification.

Respectfully submitted, November 23, 1943.

It is not a big book, being some sixty pages. It has many illustrations, which is all to the good; these are in brown and white, not red and blue and yellow and green which is a pity. But it has a place in Canadian libraries because it is the first book ever prepared for Indian children.

Readers for the little folk who are just approaching the mystery of reading in our schools have now something quite exciting to affairs, perhaps still with the cat on the mat, but it is a fluffy bit of cat, and the mat is in colors. There are little girls and boys dandling about on mats and chairs and trees and little cats. Altogether it is quite fun finding out what it is all about.

But the funny little black-eyed, black-haired, dark-skinned, children didn't lose much of their stolidity when gazing on these pictures. They didn't mean much or anything to them, and perhaps they forget that Indians and white people might be surprised to learn, often find us boring or, dreadful thought, ridiculous. So Indian children might finally yield to the assaults upon their intelligence and learn to read about cats on mats, but they certainly were never enthusiastic about them.

Now beavers and muskrats are different. Beavers and muskrats are something one knows about, and they are interesting animals, building dams, and cutting down trees, and spending time all for nothing about on mats. The new Indian School reader tells all about them.

November 7, 1944.

To the Trustees, Teachers & School Secretaries of Tyendinaga:

You are invited to attend a meeting of the trustees, and teachers of Tyendinaga township, to be held in Belrose Hall, on Wednesday November 15, at 8:00 p.m.

The meeting has been arranged with the idea of forming a Library Association for the benefit of the Tyendinaga Schools. Will the members of each school board please come prepared to pay the fee of $1.00 per section, should the Association be formed, and should you wish to become a member of the library group.

An interesting programme is being planned. Among the speakers will be Reeve J. Forestell, Miss C. Delaney of the Belleville Public Library, Mr. Brooks Allen, B.Ed., President of the South Hastings Educational Association and Mr. R. H. MacKlem, School Inspector for South Hastings. Time will be allowed for discussion and it is hoped that every trustee will come and give us the benefit of his suggestions to make Tyendinaga Schools the best in the Province.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Enclosed you will find a copy of our new enlarged edition of Nature Activities, a practical, usable handbook for teachers. As you read it through you will see that it contains leadership help, instructions for making exhibits and collections, nature handicrafts, and hundreds of seasonal activity suggestions.

Years of study and research have gone into the production of this fine booklet. In it the advice of experts in nature education is presented in concentrated form so that each page is a fruitful source of help and ideas.

Marie Gauillette, Girl Scout leader and author of "Leader's NatureGuide", and Betty Price, author of the National Recreation Association book "Adventuring in Nature", are both outstanding in nature leadership. J. A. Partridge, principal of North Bay Normal School and author of several textbooks on natural science, offers activity suggestions based on his many years of experience in Canadian education. D. H. Farwell, teacher of science and art, has based his drawings on the curricula of all nine provinces, and has kept them simple so that they may easily be transferred to the blackboard.

Since Canadian Nature was first published in 1939 we have presented in it much splendid material on the teaching of natural science. After four years so many new subscribers had been added to our list that we decided to embody the best of these suggestions into a self-contained booklet of 32 pages. Thus Nature Activities was born. Since it was first published in 1943 four editions, totalling 15,000 copies, have been printed.

In this new edition of double the size, by careful selection and condensation of text and illustrations, we feel that we have perfected a book which is worthy of inclusion in every school library. Every teacher who is confronted with the task of teaching natural science should have access to Nature Activities. It is invaluable.

Nature Activities sells regularly for 50¢. It is worth several times that price. When purchased in quantities of 50 or more copies, it costs only 30¢.

May we suggest that you consider the possibility of supplying a copy of Nature Activities at this low price, to each school under your jurisdiction?
Dr. Harold W. McGill - 2

Only $105.00 would place Nature Activities as a permanent reference source in 350 schools.

When you have examined this booklet carefully we are sure that you will agree with us that it has a real contribution to make to the educational welfare of your province. We trust that you will see your way clear to supply a copy to each school library.

Dear Sirs:

Several weeks ago your traveller visited Ottawa and at that time one of our officials reviewed his books and intimated to him that we would order a number of them. Subsequently the order for the books we require was placed with your firm by the Department of Public Printing and Stationery. Please note that we do not order books direct for our Indian schools, but the order is placed with the Department of Public Printing and Stationery.

Instead of shipping the books to the Department of Public Printing & Stationery, who had placed the order with you, your shipper addressed them to us. This has caused a great deal of confusion and has necessitated extra work, which would have been avoided if your firm had followed the instructions given in the order and shipped the books to the Department from whom you received the order.

I trust that you will carefully note the contents of this letter and, in future, when an order is placed with you by the Department of Public Printing & Stationery, you will send the articles to that Department and not to this Department even though you are aware that the shipment is ultimately intended for us.

On Saturday last I had a phone call from the Department of Public Printing & Stationery, in which they stated that they had received an invoice from you and that the number of certain books invoiced was much larger than the number received. I refer in this letter to the following:

- Glass Book - Pryor
Glass Book - Pryor 100 invoiced - 71 received
Story of Clay 100 - 60 -
Salmon 100 - 76 -
Story of Copper 100 - 70 -
Book of Stones 100 - 99 -
Trip on Many Waters 100 - 25 -
Romance of Rubber 100 - 99 -
Repe Splicing 100 - 73 -

I presume that your shipment was short, but the discrepancy mentioned above has caused us extra trouble, telephone calls, etc.

I simply bring the above matter to your attention, and any correspondence regarding the books that are short should be addressed to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery and not to this Department.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Thank you indeed for your letter of July 3rd. We regret our delay in replying but the head of our Library Department returned yesterday from her holidays and it was necessary to discuss this matter with her before definite information could be sent.

We are writing today to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery in relation to the shortage on the order and believe that by this time the shortage has been adjusted. However, as you suggest correspondence regarding this matter will be conducted with the Department of Public Printing and Stationery.

May we, however, apologize to you for the difficulty that we have caused to your department and to yourself. This difficulty has indeed been inexcusable and has been caused by neglect on our part. This neglect has been brought to the attention of the head of our department and measures are being taken so that similar difficulties will not recur in the future.

We can only assure you of our concern over this shipment and our assurance more thorough attention in the future. May I again thank you for your courtesy in writing.

Cordially yours,

Dear Col. Neary:

It was pleasant calling on you last week together with the other officials in your department. This is the first visit I have made to Ottawa in several years and I would like to thank you for your very cordial reception.

There are three main topics which I should like to review briefly with you, namely, readers for the catholic schools, health texts, and arithmetic workbooks. I sent you yesterday sample copies of the books we discussed in each of these fields.

You will have received by now, I think, a complete set of the new Corona Readers, Grades 1 to 8, and the Faith and Freedom Readers for the first two grades. I am attaching to this letter a copy of our current order form which we distribute to the separate schools in Ontario, and this will enable you to compare the prices of the Corona Readers and the corresponding Faith and Freedom Readers. I think you will agree after looking these over and examining the books concerned that 'we get what we pay for'. In the first two grades the Corona Readers offer an adequate program in basal reading. However, if a more extensive approach is necessary at this level then the Faith and Freedom program is necessary. You will be interested, perhaps, in learning of the action taken by the Catholic School Trustees of the province of Saskatchewan at their recent convention. Evidently this body has spent a good deal of time thrashing out the question of Catholic texts, and just today they received a report of their official recommendations. They have chosen Faith and Freedom readers for Grades 1 and 2 and are then continuing with the Corona Readers from Grades 3 to 8. On the other hand, however, the Ontario Separate Schools, which is a much larger group, is well satisfied with the Corona Readers from Grades 1 through to 8, and are continuing with them. I am giving you this information with the hope that it will be of some help to you knowing what is being done in these two important provinces.
On the back of the enclosed form you will find listed the new Beacon Charts which I believe are available in most of your schools. Under Faith and Freedom you will find listed the David and Ann book (wall-size chart). This is an enlarged reproduction of the first twenty-eight pages of the pre-primer THIS IS OUR HOME.

The present primary number texts series used in our schools is the "Canadian Individual Arithmetics", Books A, B and C. The publishers of this series, Ginn and Company, have replaced it with another series, "Jolly Numbers".

I have completed a survey of the textbooks authorized or recommended for primary number work in the nine provinces. I attach a copy of my findings.

This series I now recommend is authorized for pupils' use, in the whole or in part in Nova Scotia, Quebec, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and British Columbia. Newfoundland has the publishers preparing a modified series to be known as the "Caribou Arithmetics" for use there.

The most satisfactory part of the series for our schools are the Teacher's Manuals. I have studied these carefully with Mr. Doucet and we are agreed that they are excellent teaching texts. They take up the teaching materials of the pupils' books page by page and deal with the purpose, motivation and procedure of each lesson. They should prove a most useful guide to our teachers. Two of the provinces have adopted
the use of these books as manuals for teachers in training.

I do not feel that we need to provide the accompanying Wall Charts and Flash Cards. Complete details as to how the teacher can make these are given in the Teacher's Manuals.

Dear Sir:

This is in reply to your inquiry of July 16 relative to health texts. We have recognized the need of health material specifically prepared for Indian children, but have not to date been able to do anything about it.

From the series available we have chosen and approved for use the following:

American Health Series, by Wilson Pryor and others, published by Bobbs-Merrill.

The New Health and Growth Series, by Charter, Smiley, Stranger, published by Macmillan.

The Safe and Healthy Living Series, by Andreas, Goldberger and others, published by Ginn and Co.

Instructions have been given to field personnel indicating the desirability of using these texts with discretion, recognizing the incongruity of teaching which centers about modern appliances not available in the primitive home and community. We have asked teachers to make such adaptations as seem appropriate, and to omit material which has no application in the lives of their children. Much of our health teaching centers about the life activities within the school itself.

Our problem is further complicated by the wide variation among Indian groups. Some tribes have lived close to white civilization for so long that they present the same problems found in any rural population. Others are living in extreme isolation in primitive surroundings. This explains why it has seemed wise to leave the matter of adaptation to local workers.

This we recognize is far from adequate. Teachers need much more assistance than is now available for health teaching.
We shall be holding a curriculum conference with workers in the Navaho area during the month of August. At that time we expect to consider the three series of books listed and to go over them together, making suggestions for modifications for the Navaho children. Director of Education W. W. Beatty anticipates suggesting to the publishers the preparation of a modified edition for use among Indians. Although publishers in general are hesitant to consider such special editions owing to their fear that the number of texts sold will not compensate them for the expense involved, we are hopeful that it may be possible to interest them in such a project. Your interest in the same problem is significant at this time.

I am writing our printers, asking them to send you two copies of the Indian Service book list which you request. I shall be glad to hear from you further, and will keep you informed if we make any progress.

Very sincerely yours,

Edna A. Gerken
Supervisor of Health Education

Mr. Huby,

The Health Text for Use in Indian Schools.

I have now completed my survey on health texts which are authorized or recommended by the various provincial Departments of Education. I have also written to the Education Branch of the United States Indian Service and I attach a copy of a letter which I received in answer.

Throughout the selection of this series I have worked in close co-operation with Doctor Moore and Doctor Falconer who agree that the series which I have now recommended is the best available at present for use in our schools. I have also contacted the officials of the Department of National Health and Welfare who apparently have not at present any survey made of health text books.

The series which I have selected is SAFE AND HEALTHY LIVING. The chief editor is Doctor Andres, editor of the School and Health Department in "Hygeia". My survey shows that two or more of this series are authorized texts for New Brunswick, Quebec, Manitoba and Saskatchewan. It is also recommended for use in the provinces of Prince Edward Island, Ontario and British Columbia.

The following texts are enclosed for your consideration:

| Grade   | Title                                      | Price |
|---------|--------------------------------------------|-------|
| Grade 1 | Spice and Span (for teacher's use only)    | .80   |
| Grade 2 | Health Parade (for teacher's use only)     | .80   |
| Grade 3 | Growing Big and Strong (for teacher's use only) | .83   |
| Grade 4 | Safety Every Day (for teacher's use only)  | .83   |
| Grade 5-6| Health, Safety and Success (for teacher's use) | .76   |
| Grade 7-8| Your Health and Safety (for teacher's use) | .80   |

From an educational point of view these books are well organized on cyclical units. This will be especially beneficial in our one-room day schools. It will mean that the teachers will be able to teach two grades together by staggering the material. The same units recur in each book throughout the series, but become progressively more difficult as the grades advance. The final feature, which will be a great help to our teachers, is the test which occurs at the end of each unit.
Conclusion:

1. I would recommend the adoption of the SAFETY AND HEALTHY LIVING series for use in our Indian schools.

2. For this year, I would only recommend that it be adopted on a limited scale for pupil's use. I would suggest its adoption, therefore, as a text book only for grades five to eight.

3. I would like to further discuss with Doctor Moore and yourself a proposal that the Department give a series of cash prizes in tests based on these texts. I will discuss the details of my idea with you at a later date.

4. It will be necessary to draw to the attention of our teachers that local adaptations of this text book material will be necessary.

APPENDIX B

INTERPROVINCIAL COMMITTEE ON SCHOOL READERS

In March 1944, there was established a Committee of representatives of the four Western Departments of Education to discuss problems relating to the use of Basic and Supplementary Readers in elementary grades and the possibility of providing suitable readers at a reasonable cost.

At the first meeting this Committee stated that the Highroads Series was not suitable to their needs. It agreed to recommend for experimental use the following sets of Readers and to consider reports of them at the next meeting of the Committee:

- Easy Growth in Reading,
- Reading for Interest,
- New Work-Play,
- Curriculum Foundation Series.

At the second meeting the Committee expressed the following needs:

1. For general purpose as the basic series for Grades 1, 2 and 3, preference was given to the Curriculum Foundation Series.

2. For special use for quicker pupils, it recommends the New Work-Play Series.

3. For slower pupils, it considers that the Easy Growth Series was best.

At the time, the Committee found that it was not able to make a definite recommendation on readers for Grades 3 to 6.

This book sells at $2.50 per copy in the U.S.A. and Canada, and we are glad to offer it to you at $1.00 net, in quantities of 100 or more. A sample copy will be gladly sent on request. We urge you by all means to consider this important item.

Mr. Hey:

Natural Science through the Seasons -

There has been a considerable demand on the part of our teachers for a reference book in Natural Science. I have recently studied several books of this nature and would like to recommend for your attention the textbook which I attach.

The author is the Principal of the Provincial Normal School at North Bay. The Ontario Department of Education officials are very enthusiastic about this book. It is especially designed for the teacher of the one-room day school in the country. The stress throughout is laid on the encouragement of active attitudes of observation and inquiry, an understanding of the natural phenomena in our environment, and the inspiring of a healthy enjoyable means of spending one's leisure time.

Every effort is made to encourage pupil activities. As you glance through the book you will note suggestions for terraria, vivaria, aquariums (page 28), the beautification of school grounds (page 67, page 76, page 103, page 413, page 418), the feeding of birds (page 182, page 191 and page 355), conservation of animal life and forest life (page 97, page 187, page 279, page 459, etc.)

The book is very practical and contains little that could not be put into actual use by an enterprising teacher in most of our Indian schools. To a child raised in the country, natural science as outlined in this book should do much to create an active interest in school. I have always found that a schoolroom which is attractive can do much to stimulate the child to want to attend such a school. By the use of items such as classroom
hatcheries, the little Indian child can be brought to realize that in our schools they learn not only Reading and Writing but a practical knowledge of the world around them.

The cost of this book is $2.75 less the usual discount. I would recommend that we stock this book and inform our teachers so that they can requisition for it for use in our Indian schools.

Dear Mr. Neary:

When I was in Ottawa you asked for some information regarding Reverend Father O'Brien, who is the editor of the Catholic Edition of the NEW BASIC READERS. I have already written to Chicago for some information, but on checking a listing that I have here in some Scott Foresman material, I find a very fine comment on Father O'Brien, and I quote as follows:

O'BRIEN, Rev. John A. (Cathedral Basic Readers)

Received training in Spalding Institute, Peoria, Illinois; graduated from St. Viator College, Bourbonnais, Illinois; was ordained - Holy Cross College, Worcester, Massachusetts; majored in work for Catholic Education in the Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C. Appointed Superintendent of Schools in Peoria Diocese and Chaplain to Catholic students at University of Illinois. Did research in silent reading at University of Illinois and University of Chicago. Was one of first to use slides and movies to show eye movement. Founded Newman Club and inspired awarding of Newman medal for outstanding citizenship work. Prominent in lecture field. Is now Professor of Philosophy of Religion at University of Notre Dame. Author of Evolution and Religion, Silent Reading, The Church and Birth Control, The White Way, The Faith of Millions, et al. Contributor to The Sunday Visitor.

No doubt you will wish to pass this information on to some of the Catholic authorities in Ottawa, and if we have anything further from Chicago that differs from the above, you will be kept fully advised.

Very sincerely yours,

F.R. Strowbridge.

We have received from the publishers copies of several new catechisms and are anxious to find out if these are better than the texts presently being supplied by the Department. Within the near future you will receive copies of the following Catechisms:

Insofar as "My First Communion Catechism" is concerned, we would like to have a report as to whether this is suitable in its content and reading word comprehension for Indian children. We would like you to use these two texts with separate groups of students and report upon their suitability for use by Indian children.

We have received from the publishers copies of several new catechisms and are anxious to find out if these are better than the texts presently being supplied by the Department. Within the near future you will receive copies of the following Catechisms:

1. My First Communion Catechism,
2. Father McGuire's New Baltimore Catechism, No. I,
3. Baltimore Catechism, No. I - Study Lessons (Dr. Horan).

Insofar as "My First Communion Catechism" is concerned, we would like to have a report as to whether this is suitable in its content and reading word comprehension for Indian children. Would you, therefore, try this text with a number of your younger children and let us have your comments upon it in June?

The other two Catechisms are separate revisions of the Baltimore Catechism No. I. In each case they are illustrated and are complete with study exercises and reading practices. We would like you to use these two texts with separate groups of students and report upon their suitability for use by Indian children.

It may be that you are using, or know of another catechism which would be more suitable than any of the above three. In such case, the Department would appreciate your letting us know the name of the text.

Sincerely,

Rev. Sister Mary Sheila, Bernard F. Neary,
Principal, Supt. of Welfare and Training,
St. Catherine's Indian Day School, DUNCAN, B.C.

Dear Mr. Neary,

Thank you for your letter of December 16th. We are surprised to learn that the CANADIAN CATHOLIC CORONA READERS for grades one and two are not satisfactory to the Catholic teachers since this is the first complaint we have had. This series is extremely popular throughout Canada.

However, since the teachers are requesting more up-to-date readers for grades one and two, we suggest that you substitute the FAITH AND FREEDOM READERS. This excellent series of basal readers for Catholic schools was directly inspired by the Apostolic letter of Pope Pius XII to the American Bishops in which he urged a restatement of the traditional Christian teaching regarding the nature of man and society. In response, the American Bishops initiated a movement for the instruction in the fundamental nature of democracy and of Christian social living. They turned to The Catholic University of America to forward such a movement and as a result the FAITH AND FREEDOM series was published.

The method of the series has been painstakingly worked out to provide the maximum encouragement and growth for the child who is learning to read. Vocabulary is carefully controlled through the early grades and detailed suggestions to the teacher outline a steady increase in power to read.

The books themselves are unusually attractive, with beautiful illustrations and lively, original stories. They have provided the best answer yet to the problems of teaching reading expertly while conveying a purposeful message. For your information, I list below the readers, workbooks, and teachers' manuals for grades one and two -
Our First Book - a reading-readiness book
Here We Come - preparatory Pre-Primer
This is Our Home - basal Pre-Primer
Workbook for This is Our Home
Here We Are Again - absorption Pre-Primer
This is Our Family - Primer
Workbook for This is Our Family
These Are Our Friends - Book One
Workbook for These Are Our Friends
These Are Our Neighbors - Book Two

Teaching First-Grade Reading I - manual for readiness and Pre-Primer period
Teaching First-Grade Reading II - manual for Primer
Teaching First-Grade Reading III - manual for Book One
Teaching Second-Grade Reading - manual for Book Two

We are sending you examination copies of the above books with our compliments. OUR FIRST BOOK and THIS IS OUR FAMILY are at present out of stock but copies of these two titles will go forward to you in a few weeks.

Here Come David and Ann - a Wall Chart to accompany Here We Come

Word, Phrase, and Picture Cards for the Pre-Primer and Primer

We are sure you will agree, after you have had an opportunity to examine the books we are sending you, that the Catholic teachers will enjoy using these attractive, up-to-date readers.

Yours sincerely,

GINN AND COMPANY

Dear Sir:

In the June issue of the Bulletin we have listed all the library books which are now in stock on your shelves.

Professor of Education and Associate Director of Supervised Teaching at the University of California, Berkeley, and a well-known reading expert examines the reading program in the elementary school. Children Learn to Read

GINN AND COMPANY

DAVID H. RUSSELL

Children Learn to Read

"Reading achievements seem closely related to both general school success and to personality adjustments. An activity of such continuing importance in the lives of children and teachers cannot be examined too often or too critically," says Dr. Russell in the Preface to Children Learn to Read.

In this book he thoughtfully examines research and good practice and applies them to the reading problems of a modern elementary school, with emphasis always on child development.

In two ways this book goes beyond most published discussions of reading. First, it gives the teacher a better understanding of her task by suggesting the sociological, historical, and psychological backgrounds of reading instruction. Second, it emphasizes the developmental or vertical nature of growth in reading abilities, thus giving the teacher greater insight into the child's reading achievements in relation to his total development.

Part I of Children Learn to Read, as is logical, concerns itself chiefly with the background material mentioned above. Part II presents an overview of the whole program of reading instruction and gives typical aims and activities at various levels. Part III makes clear that reading, far from being a simple process, is a complex of various abilities which grow, not by hard-and-fast levels, but continuously from infancy at least through the junior college. It shows how the development of reading abilities reflects other phases of the child's maturing. Vocabulary, reading interests, creative reading competences, individual differences, and evaluation are discussed here.

Children Learn to Read gives a precise, clear, and unified picture of how children develop reading abilities. It renders signal service to reading and education by illuminating the close and vital relationship between child development and reading.

Dear Sir:

Yesterday, I spent some considerable time with Mr. Joly at the Stationery Branch on York Street. I was impressed with the new organization and feel that when the system is in effect, our teachers and principals will get their books in faster time than at present.

I made a careful check of the books on the shelves and I was naturally perturbed at the short supply. I immediately made an estimate of the requirements up to the end of December, 1949. Please find attached this list of books with the code numbers from your stock catalogue.

It is of course possible that some of these books have already been ordered but have not yet been delivered by the suppliers. Therefore, you can have the orders checked and can reduce the quantities shown accordingly.

I would suggest that the suppliers be contacted to fill your outstanding orders as soon as possible. I am most anxious that all requisitions placed by me up to July 21, 1949, be filled as fully as possible and sent to the schools before the opening date of September 6, 1949.

If Mr. July or yourself require further information, please do not hesitate to call me at Local 4465 or Mr. Tyack, who has charge of all requisitions and orders, at Local 7663.

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

Mr. M.J. McLean, President, McLean's Merchandize Sales Limited was in town on September 28th soliciting business for books and reading materials he is handling.

Among other things, he interested me in a set of Richard's Topical Encyclopedias. These books were originally planned as a 20 volume set for use in schools retailing at $15.00 a set. Through some miscalculation they overprinted eight volumes each dealing with a different topic as shown on the attached circular. Each volume carries an index for the volume and there is no reference from one volume to another, making each book complete in itself.

The binding, quality of paper, illustrations, vocabulary material etc., are exactly the same as in the Book of Knowledge. Mr. McLean tells me that the Department of Education for Saskatchewan and Quebec have purchased these sets. The price of $15.00 for each set of eight volumes is very reasonable.

In view of the fact that many of our residential schools have a set of the Book of Knowledge and the Grolier Encyclopedia, I would respectfully recommend that Mr. Driscoll be requested to place in stock ten sets of these Encyclopedias.

M.F. Track.
Richard's Topical Encyclopedia

Vol. 1 - Science - Geology, the story of the Earth, Astronomy, the story of the heavens; Meteorology, the story of the weather; Physics, the laws of the Universe; Electricity; Chemistry.

Vol. 2 - Science - The Animal Kingdom; Birds of all kinds and all countries; Mammals; Animals of all kinds, both wild and domesticated.

Vol. 3 - Science - Prehistoric Life, the record of the rocks, the dawn of life; Zoology, the Animal Kingdom; the story of Life, Centipedes, Insects, Spiders, Amphibians, Reptiles.

Vol. 4 - Basic Industries - Clothing, Food Plants, Plant Products, Meat, Minerals and Metals; Petroleum, Precious Stones, Textiles and origins of fashions, their history, growth, production and use.

Vol. 5 - Applied Science - Communication; Language, Newspaper, Postal Service, Radio and Television, Transportation primitive and modern, Sea, Rail, Automotive and Air. Invention and Applied Science; weights and measures, heat, light, explosives, water supply, x-ray, mathematics, machinery, etc.

Vol. 6 - Art and Biography - The Crafts; the manufacture of Glass, Rugs, Furniture, Lace, Silverware, etc. The History of Music, the development of music and instruments, the great composers from the Renaissance to the present time; biographies of great historical figures from ancient days to the present day, including rulers, military figures, composers, writers, etc.

Vol. 7 - Biography - Further biographies of Philosophers - Greek, Roman, Italian, French, German, English and American literary figures; Scientists, Explorers and religious leaders.

Vol. 8 - Leisure Time Activities - Projects for recreation and vocational guidance; manual training for boys and girls, drawing, needlecraft, domestic science, magic, indoor and outdoor games. 124 Fairy and Classical Mythology tales retold for children; all of the principal major sports from baseball to track and field, including boy and girl scout activities and camping.

Dear Mr. Query:

On my latest inspection of Indian day schools in Ontario and the Maritimes, I have been approached by the Catholic teachers in our schools about the Corona Readers. They informed me that they are not satisfied with these readers and would rather use the readers authorized by the Provincial Departments of Education. They pointed out that there is little catechism in the Corona Readers and any that there may be can be taught from the catechism books.

I have made a study of these readers and am convinced that the idea is a sound one. However, as you have a large stock of Corona readers, I do not wish to discontinue issuing these readers but will continue to supply them to our schools when the teachers request them.

I would suggest that you discontinue stocking any more of these readers and cancel all outstanding orders. Should requests for these readers exceed your stock, it will be in order for you to make individual purchases for each requisition. The Corona Readers series include:

Dear Sirs:

I have your letter of January 17th and a copy of Volume 6 of The Home University Encyclopedia.

We have given the book a careful study and feel that it has much to be desired. Although it would appear from the face page that the edition was revised in 1946, on going through the book it is found that the information was not brought up to date, (e.g.) Hamilton, Halifax, Goering, etc.

The volume we received has a considerable number of pages on which no printing appears making the whole book defective.

This encyclopedia may be useful for United States schools but cannot comply with our requirements.

I am returning the sample copy in order that you may find the defects.

DIRECTOR

"Second Year Woodwork"

I am pleased to draw to your attention the attached Manual Training text which has been written by our Supervisor of Vocational Training. This book is the second of its kind as "First Year Woodwork" was published about six months ago.

The first year book is now in use in Indian Day and Residential schools and is of course on the market for use in provincial schools. You will note that Mr. Doucet has divided the work into "projects". Each project is described in a job sheet and the materials, tools, and procedures are carefully outlined.

You will find tests at regular intervals and other important items such as stock bills, progress record cards, etc. Many of the sketches are Mr. Doucet's own work and of course all the text has been prepared by him.

I also attach two forms which accompany the book. One is entitled "Student Record Sheet" and the other "Complete Stock Bill Sheet". These are for use in schools in which there is a Manual Training instructor employed.

Quarterly Return
Quarter Ending March 31st, 1950.

It has been impressed on the Principals of Residential Schools that the quarterly return should be prepared at the end of each quarter and forwarded promptly to the Department through the office of your Superintendent.

However, many Principals evidently delay preparation of the return, as many of the returns do not reach the Indian Affairs Branch until 4 or 5 weeks following the end of the quarter, and in several instances, the Branch has found it necessary to write Principals regarding a delayed return.

In future, we expect that each and every Principal will forward the quarterly return immediately following the close of the quarter.

This year we are particularly anxious to have the March quarter return reach us promptly, and therefore, we will expect this return to reach Ottawa not later than April 15th, 1950.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

The Indian in Canada by E.C. Woodley

I have just completed reading the above-noted manuscript and cannot be too sure as to the purpose it can be put to, if any, in our schools.

The material included is far from complete as there are enormous possibilities for covering more subjects such as culture, mode of living, religion, contributions to the White man, etc. Many of the subjects are covered but not as fully as required for school children, as not only facts are required, but these have to be elaborated to make the reading both interesting and educational.

The style is most unsuitable for school children. Mr. Woodley treats the subject matter as if he were writing a Chemistry book or Arithmetic book for he is stating facts after facts. To make a history book readable and valuable one must introduce short stories, incidents, comparisons, etc. A history book ought to be written like a novel rather than an assembly of facts.

I am attaching a list of notes picked up from time to time while reading the manuscript.

I think the book has possibilities as there has been a great deal of research made on the material, but it would have to be entirely rewritten to suit our pupils' requirements.

M.F. Track.
1. Lack of variety of types of seat work problems such as True, False, Matching, Filling blanks, completion sentences.

Notes on the Use of the Phonograph

1. Purpose:
The machine and records are supplied for use by the teacher in a planned programme. As the battery-pack has a limited number of hours of life, and replacement is inconvenient and expensive, the use of the apparatus must be rationed and spread over the school term. It is not, therefore, a device for amusement at recesses and before and after school.

2. Use-history:
On a line in the Register in the "Name of Pupil" column write "Radio-phonograph" and on days when the apparatus is used record the number of minutes of hook-up time under the day and date. A study of this log will permit anticipation of the date when the battery-pack will be worn out.

3. Subjects of instruction:
The apparatus is intended primarily to assist with the teaching of English (or French). It is hoped also that it will reinforce those teachers who are not naturally musical, and thus add to the attractiveness of the schoolroom.

4. Using the records:
Each record is to be used with a definite plan. Before embarking on a programme of instruction the teacher should play over all the records in the absence of the pupils and select the one which is to be the basis of the first selection of lessons. The pupils must first become familiar with the melody. Having learned the melody they must then learn to sing the words to the melody. At this stage the teacher must be alert to stop the music if necessary and drill on pronunciation of the words. By the third or fourth day the more advanced pupils may be ready to read the words from the blackboard. By the end of the week such pupils should be ready to copy out the words correctly in their song-writing books. Thereafter they should be required to write the stanzas with complete accuracy from memory and to recite them orally from memory with due regard for correctness of pronunciation. From time to time they should, of course, sing in unison with the apparatus. Mastery of the song requires that they sing it without the apparatus, at the same time conserving electricity. A programme of this sort may be expected to give a majority of the pupils mastery of the language and melody of one song in a week. Some of the songs supplied may take longer, especially if the teacher includes in the term "mastery" a reasonable degree of efficiency in any dramatization or singing game associated with the song e.g., "London Bridge". Or the teacher may invent action to accompany the song. It is expected that teachers will devise various routines to go with "Ten Little Indians" and that groups of the children rather...
than the school as a whole will required to master these routines in addition to the language and melody. Teachers are reminded that properly spaced repetition of the lessons will permit mastery to be achieved more efficiently than an occasional long lesson. Two fifteen minute lessons a day for one week might be considered as an initial standard. As we are proceeding on an experimental basis the experience of teachers and any data or suggestions based on that experience will be helpful.

Dear Mike,

Knowing that you are on the lookout for library books—at a good price—I am sending you two series which I believe will be satisfactory. One is a series of Bible Stories which are being widely sold to both Protestants and Catholics. In fact both Landy and Desmarais and Robitaille are among the best buyers of these series. We also sell them to the British and Foreign Bible Society, Ryerson, and General Board of Religious Education. Gentlemen:

Attached is a copy of the latest Grosset & Dunlap catalogue.

In the month of February we announced certain price changes that were to be effective on March 1st, and at that time informed you that any orders received by us before the first of March would be honoured at the current prices.

In this announcement, we told you there was a possibility that Series Books such as BOBBING TAILS, HARRY BOX, etc., were to be increased in price from 75¢ to 85¢ in the United States, and there was a great possibility that they would be increased over the $1.00 Canadian list price. However, fortunately, with the co-operation of Grosset & Dunlap, Inc., who, as well as ourselves, made a sacrifice profitwise, we were able to hold this price to the $1.00 Canadian list.

As you no doubt are aware, on the new Canadian Budget which was announced on April 11th, Sales Tax was increased from 6½ to 10½, which virtually means that our costs on importing books from the United States have increased 3½ on the cumulative import costs.

It is now our intention not to raise the prices generally in order to regain some of our additional import costs, but to change one price only, which we do not feel will affect the sales on this Grosset & Dunlap line. As of July 1st, all books listed in this catalogue at $1.39 will be increased to $1.49, and in this way we hope to save, at least for the time being, increasing any other prices.

We will honour any orders postmarked not later than June 30th for $1.39 books at the $1.39 price. We ask you to go through this catalogue carefully and try to anticipate your Fall requirements. The only stipulation we make is that the books ordered, must be for immediate shipment, as we could not begin to warehouse stocks for later shipments.

We would appreciate in turn your co-operation on this price change and do hope you will take advantage in ordering immediately.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Telephones in Education Division

   Extension Mr. C.A.F. Clark

   Extension Outer Office

The above arrangement was decided on a temporary basis when the Branch moved into this building and the position of Assistant Superintendent of Education was vacant.

Mr. Davey makes calls and receives calls from the Director and other officials, consequently it is necessary to have the lines clear and available when required.
As the extension serves two officials now, it will be necessary to secure a "Main Station" to replace the extension. If a "Main Station" is provided it is suggested that the extension from 7683 be discontinued. It is proposed, therefore, that two extensions be replaced by one "Main Station".

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With further reference to our correspondence of July 11 and July 16, the 120 copies of Easter Time ordered by the Queen's Printer on April 22, on their order number A 31901, I regret to have to report the following information which is quoted direct from a letter sent to me from the original publisher of the text.

"Please pardon my delay in replying to your letter of July 16 in which you inquire about your two orders for Easter Time which have not been filled."

"When we first decided to reprint this book when our stock ran low, we thought to make a slight revision in it, but after going over it we have decided to remake it entirely, with new illustrations throughout and new format. Therefore, it will be some little time before this book can be reissued in its new form. The artist is still working on the new illustrations, so I doubt that we can have this book very much before two or three more months."--Signed: Gladys Hendrickson.

In view of the facts contained in the above information, under separate cover, I am forwarding you complimentary copies of the following titles in hope that you may find a suitable substitute.
The Open Road - $.80
The Little Road - $.55
Good Times in Winter - $.45
Jack O'Lantern Twins - $.55
The Dairy Farm - $.65

Open Road, and Little Road are in the same series as Wide Road and Broad Road which were ordered by you in March.

Good Times in the Winter is contained in the same series as Good Times at the Farm, in the City, and if you wish complimentary copies of these other titles, please advise me and I will be only too glad to comply with your request.

Please accept my sincere apologies for this inconvenience which is being caused you as we do all in our power to satisfy our customers.

Cordially yours,

Doreen Thompson,

Dear Sir:

In our letter of July 5, 1951, the Department of Public Printing and Stationery was requested to stock ink powder, blue, quart size available from A.J. Reeves Company, Toronto, Ontario. It was pointed out at that time that the cost of Reeves ink was fifteen cents a packet while the ink which we have been receiving sold at forty-three cents. As the school ink handled by Reeves was considered satisfactory and as the price was considerably lower it was decided to use this type of ink.

It is noted that Reeves ink was provided to our schools for some time but later we began to receive the more expensive ink which is packed in glass containers. It is felt that the reason for issuing the more expensive ink was due to the fact that both the Reeves ink and the more expensive ink was listed under stock #4074.

It would be appreciated if in the future all orders for ink for schools be purchased from Reeves Company and a stock number given for the ink used for our schools.

Please advise the stock number designated for this yardstick.

I am forwarding you an additional copy of this letter and it would be appreciated if you would return a copy with the stock numbers indicated on it.

Yours sincerely,

THE ROMANCE OF CANADA

HISTORY

History becomes fascinating romance when reduced to glowing facts. Fact, in the first place, is essential or history means nothing. And one fact, given its proper setting and told with inspiration, is the essence of history, its vitalizing quality. The early days of Acadians, the French Régime, the pioneers of Upper Canada, the opening of the Great Northwest, the Hudson's Bay Company and hundreds of other pioneer and adventurous enterprises tell the whole story of Canada in vivid language.

Geography has become so important nowadays that it takes its place as a distinct department in leading universities. Then, what so important as a knowledge of the geography of your own country? That does not mean just a map knowledge. It includes pen-pictures, aerial views, panoramic displays, visualizations of great natural beauty, great enterprises, great achievements such as can be obtained only in this reference library.

TRAVEL

The Department of Railways and Canals has established a branch to look after the ever-growing importance of travel and the influx of tourists to Canada. But how much does the average Canadian know about the topographical features and attractions of his own country? Everybody cannot travel. Still everybody with the assistance of the illustrations, pen-pictures and general information diffused through these fascinating pages gains a generous enthusiastic knowledge of the gentle to overpowering attractiveness of Canadian natural scenery all the way from Cape Breton to Alaska and the Yukon.

This is still a subject of vital importance, notwithstanding the general impression that all our vast territories have been completely explored. The lure of the unknown, longing for the unknown things to be seen at the end of strange roads and strange waters. What can be more interesting than to read of the explorations of Cartier, LaSalle, Marquette, MacKenzie, Thompson, Radisson and the many others who ventured the rapids of our rivers, the long treks over rugged country, the dangers of the Red Man, etc.

COMMERCE

Your daily newspaper gives you glimpses, which you notice casually and usually forget, of what is taking place and has already been done in building up our Dominion and placing it among the great trading countries of the world. But how much do we actually know? To impart this information is but one of the functions of this outstanding National reference library. For articles by experts in all lines of endeavor are found in its pages, articles on subjects which affect every man, woman and child in the country.

The call of the great out-of-doors. To feel the thrill of the woods with their scents of trees and flowers! Why not go prepared? Why not know beforehand many things about our forests, our wild animals, birds, fishes, wild flowers, butterflies, insects? These subjects are expertly treated and beautifully illustrated. This wild life feature is a joy in itself, and it is of especial value and extra charm to children.

NATURE STUDY

Nothing is truer than the old saying that Truth is Stranger than Fiction. Then what so true as strange adventures of all kinds that have befallen Canadians in all walks of life from the early days of the Red Man's supremacy even to the present time dominance of the White? All this is graphically outlined.

Dear Sir:

In the past we have provided our Indian day and residential schools with "Justrite" white chalk. As you are aware this chalk is packed in boxes of 144 sticks. We have had some complaints from teachers and school inspectors indicating that the white chalk is not suitable where classrooms have a tendency to be dark. It has been decided to provide "yellow site protective chalk" to these schools. It is proposed to provide both the white chalk and the site protective chalk in the future.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

With reference to the proposed establishment of a new type of Day School on certain of the reserves in the North West where such an institution might be of use, I have to say that Mr. Ogilvie made rough plans of the building which would give proper accommodation and which would cost, furnished from eight to nine thousand dollars. This building would accommodate the School Teacher and his wife and a trained nurse on the following scale:-

Basement throughout, with furnace and cold storage chambers, vegetable cellar, etc.

Ground Floor:- School room, Dining Room, work room, kitchen, Dispensary.

Second Floor:- Sitting Room, Dining Room, 2 Bed Rooms, Nurse's Bedroom, small infirmary for sick children.

The scale of pay and expenses for running such an institution might be calculated as follows:-

School Teacher & wife, in cash, $500.00
Two Rations, 130.00
Free House, 200.00
Nurse, in cash, 400.00
1 Ration, 60.00
Medicines & medical supply for Nurse, 200.00
Free quarters, 100.00

Forward, $1890.00
Carried Forward, $1880.00

Food for pupils, to provide a meal in the middle of the day for an average attendance of 30 @ 5¢ per dish - 216 days, $224.00

Fuel, Ice & Unforeseen, $196.00

Cost on May 17th, $2000.00

In comparison, a Boarding School might be calculated to cost about as follows:

Building to accommodate 30 pupils & staff, $30,000.00

Per capita grant, 30 pupils at $150., $3,900.00

$33,900.00

The cost of food for the pupils is placed at $224.00. It should be less than that, as a garden should produce a quantity of vegetables once the scheme is started. The beef would be obtained from the ration house. As only the poorer part would be used in making soup, the cost for meat would not be large. The other staple for the meal would be bread, with molasses occasionally. The duties of the Teacher's wife (who might be called Field Matron) would be to teach the Indian women ordinary domestic economy; how to make good bread, to cook meat, etc., and to keep their houses clean. The nurse's duties would be house to house visitation looking after the sick, disinfection, isolation of tubercular patients etc.

St. Albert, Alta., Aug. 11, 1911

My Honorable Sir,

Allow me to make a few remarks on the occasion of the inspection recently made by Mr. Chene, of the Indian Boarding schools in this diocese.

Of course I have no opinion to offer concerning the appointment of Mr. Chene, whom I had the opportunity to meet at Gleichen, and who gave every indication of being a gentleman in every way. But I must say that I have been a little surprised to find that we had not been informed of his appointment and of his authority to deal in the matter of the Indian Boarding schools. We knew that Mr. Hanna is also inspector of these Indian schools, but in place of Mr. Hanna, another gentleman comes and states that he is inspector for said schools.

Mr. Chene has left some recommendations and specifications as to improvements and repairs. I do not mean to deal with these recommendations for the present, as I have not had the opportunity of studying them, as yet; but I simply ask if we are expected to act immediately on these recommendations, without waiting for the sanction and approbation of the Department. Such has not been the policy of the Department in the past, and I would like to be enlightened on this point. This is the only motive that prompted me to write this letter, as I specially deplored any intention to appear, in any way, Mr. Chene's appointment and his suggestions.

And I have the honour to remain, My Honorable Sir,

IMPRESSIONS OF THE INTERVIEW
BETWEEN THE CHURCH REPRESENTATIVES AND THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL
APRIL 13, 1922.

Dr. Chown, General Superintendent of the Methodist Church, who introduced the delegation, mentioned the State's obligation arising out of the treaties with the Indian people of Canada.

Canon Gould, of the Church of England in Canada, spoke at some length of the urgent need for funds for the erection of residential schools.

Father Guy, of the Roman Catholic Church, enlarged upon the remarks of the previous speaker and made the suggestion that Indian trust funds be applied in a more extensive way to the problem of Indian education.

Dr. Edmison, of the Presbyterian Church, explained the financial condition of his organization, and asked the Government to recommend taking over the responsibilities in connection with buildings and equipment. He requested a new school for Cecilia Jeffrey, on a site to be chosen, and suggested that the Government take over the Presbyterian residential school property in the near future.

Dr. Manning, of the Methodist Church, commented on the unity among the various societies doing Indian work, and asked that there be included in the Supplementary Estimates for 1922-23 the several requests already made to the Department. He referred to the immediate needs of the Methodist Church at Edmonton, Coqualeetza and Muncey.

The Hon. Charles Stewart, Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, in reply, stated that there was great need at the present time of economy in connection with state expenditures. He mentioned that, if his efforts to obtain funds for new residential school buildings were abortive this year, the Department would at least keep the old buildings in repair during the interim before such time as funds could be provided. He stated that the possibility and advisability of taking Indian trust funds on loan for the purpose of erecting residential schools had been, and would continue to be, a matter of serious consideration. Mr. Stewart realized the unique position of the unfinished plant at Edmonton, and stated that this particular school and its needs would receive due attention.
Dr. Edmison thanked the Minister for his interest in the work and promised that no undue pressure, in connection with new buildings, would be brought to bear at this time. He was personally gratified that the Minister had admitted the principle that the state should assume the responsibility for buildings in connection with residential schools, and was pleased that the Government was prepared, even this year, to do the repairing that would be found necessary from time to time.

Canon Gould inquired if the Government would make any distinction between church-owned and state-owned property in connection with the temporary programme of upkeep.

The Hon. Mr. Stewart, in reply to Canon Gould's question, stated that the Department would endeavour to keep the church-owned buildings in state of good repair, until such time as new buildings could be provided.

Dr. Chown thanked the Minister for the hearing and for his evident interest in the education of the Indian people.
Ottawa, May 12, 1922.

Re: Ownership Indian Residential Schools.

There are 75 Indian residential schools under the auspices of this Department. This figure includes 2 institutions (Edmonton and Elkhorn) at which there are, at present, no Indian children. 43 of these residential schools are owned by the Churches and 32 by the State.

Roman Catholic.

There are 40 residential schools under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. 27 of these institutions are owned by the Church authorities. The Oblate Order owns 22 of these Roman Catholic church-owned boarding schools.

The schools marked (1) are modern, up to date buildings, in good condition and are adequate for the purpose of Indian education. The Provincial of the Oblate Order in Winnipeg (Father Beys) has urgently requested that these 4 properties be purchased. In the Supplementary Estimates for 1922-23 there is an item of $48,000 to provide for the purchase of the Kenora Boarding School, after an adjusting
of the valuation. If this amount is voted, the principle involved, i.e., the gradual acquisition of all residential school buildings owned by the churches, will be acknowledged; and from time to time, as parliament provides funds, the other 3 institutions marked (1) and the 2 schools in British Columbia marked (2) could be purchased. These 2 institutions in British Columbia and a third one, the Squamish Boarding School, owned by the Sisters of the Holy Infant (R.C.) have been offered to the Government at a valuation (not stated) by the Church authorities in the Western Province. Beauval Boarding School, Sask., marked (2), has been named by the Oblates as the last school the purchase of which is desired.

I wish to refer to the possibility of future requests on the part of the Roman Catholic Church that the State purchase the other church-owned residential schools. Those marked (4) are north of the main lines of communication and could be considered largely missionary activities for some years. The institutions marked (5) are either in poor condition or are not modern and would likely be turned over to the State from time to time, at practically no cost. As you are aware, it has hitherto been the policy of the Department to supply modern, up-to-date buildings in place of the original residential schools erected with church funds which, owing to lapse of time and the development of the work, become dilapidated and inadequate. At the time of the transfer, the monetary consideration is generally nil.

5 Roman Catholic church-owned institutions have not been listed above. This Department would never purchase the Fort William Orphanage, Ont., or the St. Albert Boarding School, Alta., as these are primarily convents for the education of white children. The Squamish Boarding School, B. C. should not be considered, as the property is entirely inadequate for Indian residential school purposes. The Christie Industrial School, B. C. is modern, and the possibility of taking it over, at a valuation, must be considered. The last named institution is owned by the Basilian Order. The Spanish Industrial School, Ont., a large, modern institution belonging to the Jesuit Order, is worth about $150,000, and I believe, may be offered to the State.

Church of England.

There are 21 residential schools under the auspices of the Church of England. 10 of these are not owned by the State. When the time comes to take over these institutions, the monetary consideration will be nil, because of the poor condition of the buildings or their situation.

Methodist.

7 residential schools are under the Methodist Church. 2 of these are church-owned, and would likely be offered to the Department, gratis, when we are able to re-build.

Presbyterian.

7 Indian residential schools are under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church. 4 of these are church-owned. 3 are modern and well designed for the purposes of Indian education, and we will be asked to purchase these in the future. One is dilapidated, and we would pay nothing to the Church when we decide to re-build.
