DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, Oct. 2, 1932.

Sir:-

In the past, this Department has experienced some difficulty in the matter of paying accounts for equipment purchased for Indian residential schools. There are certain regulations governing the expenditure of public funds, and it will assist our officers if principals of Indian schools and church officials will remember the following instructions.

The Department's authority must be obtained for expenditures that are to be met other than from the school per capita grant. Requests should be forwarded through the office of the local Indian agent, so that his recommendation can be attached. It is quite in order for the principal to secure the assistance of the church authorities in the case of major expenditures, but the original request should come through the Department's officials in the field.

The requirements of the Purchasing Commission must be kept in mind. If authority to purchase locally is granted, the principal or agent should secure competitive prices for all material over $15. If manufactured articles are desired, this Department will ask the Purchasing Commission for the business houses that should be asked to quote. The principal, when requesting equipment, should intimate the type desired by referring to a price list or catalogue of some Canadian firm. The Purchasing Commission emphasizes the importance of buying, as far as possible, goods that are manufactured in Canada.

When the business has been awarded to a firm the bill should not be paid by the principal, unless it is his intention to finance the purchase out of per capita earnings. The account, in duplicate, should be given by the principal, not to a church representative, but to the Indian agent, or direct to the Department in the case of some residential schools not in Indian agencies. Our agent will certify the accounts if they are in order, and this Department will send a cheque to the firm that has supplied the equipment. When authority has been granted to purchase locally, a memo must be attached showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted, and whether the goods selected were manufactured in Canada or otherwise.

Your attention to the above requirements will assist this Department in its effort to administer the Vote for Indian Education in a satisfactory manner.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Circular

CANADA/Ottawa, January 16th., 1923.

Sir,

I have to inform you that the Purchasing Commission of Canada has recently ruled that requisitions in future for all purchases exceeding $100.00 are to be submitted to it before action is taken, except in emergency cases when time will not permit of doing so. Such cases, however, should be rare, as generally, requirements can and should be foreseen, and the regulations complied with. When such emergency purchases have to be made all possible competition should be obtained and full records kept of those who were asked to quote; also their replies. This information together with a proper description of articles on which prices were obtained to be submitted with the accounts.

It must be understood that Canadian made goods are to be purchased where possible and the lowest tenders are to be accepted. When the lowest tender is not accepted, a full explanation should be made.

When a requisition is referred to the Department for authority to purchase and a list of names from whom to call for tenders, a full description of the article or goods required should be given, and if possible, a catalogue reference as a guide to those tendering. Requisitions should always give the name of the nearest City, Town, or Village, to the Reserve where it is proposed making the purchases.

An abstract, in duplicate, of all Tenders received should accompany all accounts.

These regulations will not apply to authorized purchases, the account for which does not exceed $100.00, which may be made without further reference to the Department, after obtaining competitive prices, but to such an account an abstract in duplicate of the tenders received should be attached for the information of the Purchasing Commission, to whom all accounts for are submitted before payment can be made.

Competitive prices need not be obtained for purchases the value of which do not exceed $15.00 but the account should bear a certificate to the effect that the purchases have been made to the best possible advantage and that the prices are fair and reasonable. It is the desire of the Purchasing Commission that this business shall be divided as much as possible and when there is more than one store in the Town where the purchases are made. What is meant by this is, that should you make a purchase one week at a certain store in the Town where you do business, the next purchase should be made at another store, if the goods can be purchased to advantage. In this way the Government's business will be equally divided amongst interested Merchants throughout the year. The accounts for these as well as all other purchases should be forwarded in duplicate, direct to the Department monthly, and not allowed to accumulate for months.

Purchases of Live Stock and Seed Grain are exempt from these regulations; also purchases of Beef, Hay, and wood, when made from Indians.
These regulations cover all purchases made by any officials of the Department whether on behalf of the Department or for Indians and irrespective of the Fund from which payment is to be made.

You are therefore required to carefully observe these regulations and acknowledge receipt of this letter.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

In an application recently received by me for the issue of a cheque for the amount of $45,000 for the purchase of the Kamora Boarding School from the Rev. Oblate Fathers, it was stated that that amount was included in your estimates for the current year. As no such specific amount was voted for that purpose, I infer that it was included in your general vote for Indian Education, and I also understand that the same vote was supposed to include an amount of $75,000 towards the erection of a new school in the vicinity of Edmonton.

Your total expenditure under the head of Indian Education appears to me to be naturally divisible into two heads, viz: (1) the maintenance of existing schools and (2) the acquisition of school buildings either by purchase or by erection by the department. As these two classes of expenditure are of an entirely different nature, might I suggest that it would be advisable in future, when preparing your estimates, to ask separate amounts for the maintenance of the schools and for the erection or purchase of new schools.

Ottawa, April 17, 1924.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I wish to add to my letter of yesterday's date, with reference to the building programme for Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta. As you were informed, communications will be addressed to you, concerning the individual school buildings. To obviate the necessity of mentioning in each letter the regulations which should guide you in your purchases and supervision, I am drawing to your attention the following:

In no case should tenders be called for a building or for any installation. As you are aware, before a contract can be let, an Order in Council has to be secured. The different buildings should be erected under proper supervision, by day labour. For building activity at residential schools, as much of the work as possible should be done by the older boys, under the supervision of the staff. The pupils will then benefit by the practical instruction and the expenditure will be kept as low as possible.

If any items for material such as lumber or brick are $1,000 or over, please submit to the Department a requisition listing the quantity, quality and where the material is required. The Department Purchasing Agent, in conjunction with the Government Contracts Supervision Committee, will then arrange for the purchase and delivery. Where the proposed expenditure for material is under $1,000, you should invite sealed tenders from the best available source of supply. Such tenders shall be safeguarded and opened on the due date by two of your officers. The lowest tender in conformity with the specifications shall be accepted, unless good and sufficient reasons for departure from this procedure can be given. When you are submitting the properly certified

M. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
accounts, in duplicate, in favour of the firms given the business, you should support them with Abstract of Tender forms showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted.

Time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for all the labour employed. Indian labour should be engaged whenever practicable and not more than the current wage allowed in the case of expert tradesmen.

It will be satisfactory if you wish to arrange for the payment of the labour locally, but all accounts for materials should be forwarded to the Department for payment. It would be well to use the services of agents and principals wherever possible as supervisors, without remuneration.

The amounts allowed for each building should not be exceeded and do not hesitate to effect a saving if the work can be satisfactorily completed.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Relying to your letter of the 17th instant with reference to the building programme for Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta and particularly with regard to the regulations which should be followed in reference to the purchase of material and supervision, I note what you say with regard to getting the work done by day labor and I am glad that there will be no contract covering the whole including labor, material and so forth, but I do not see how we can possibly carry on the work unless we give the actual labor out by contract, for as you know, this work will be carried on in remote parts where we have no officer who can daily supervise the work, keep time tables, and see that there is no loafing. In fact, I believe that nothing will be gained at all if we have to send laborers and a foreman out to do the job without being in a position to have them checked up daily by an officer of our Department, and I would not be prepared to certify vouchers for time sent in unless I was sure that the services, as shown on the time sheet, had been rendered.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Could we follow the practice which was adopted last year in connection with the buildings which were erected on Piaqots and Muscowpetung reserves. What we did in these cases was to get out bills of material for the different buildings, submit the list to all the lumber companies and buy from the lowest tenderer.

With regard to labor we invited various carpenters, men whom we knew, to come to this office, examine the plans and give us a price for the labor only. By doing this we were relieved of the responsibility of keeping time tables, employing carpenters to work under a foreman—which is no easy job—arranging for board of men and setting men transported to and from the job. In fact it cannot be done in many cases. It seems to me it would be very simple and can be arranged, but I want to have your approval before starting any work. I may say that we followed this plan in connection with building the office and warehouse and altering the various buildings at Broadview last year, the office at Put'Appelle Agency also nine houses and nine barns in the Piaqots and Muscowpetungs Reserves for Indians. By carrying out this method we affected a saving of at least 20% on the labour alone not counting what was saved by purchasing material.

There is one other matter I wish to draw to your attention with reference to the buildings at the File Hills School. Could the purchase of material be divided so as to bring the separate tenders under $1000.00? I ask this as I foresee trouble if there is any delay in getting material that is purchased in British Columbia, or other points in car lots which is likely to take months, and having men on the job waiting for the material, it would not do.
I find the various lumber companies which supply material from their yards submit just as close prices in competition as people who ship from the mills in British Columbia.

We have a large building programme and the season is short. In order to get the work done, I would ask to have the regulations made as workable as possible. I would be glad to know if you are in accord with the plan followed during the past two years, as set forth in this letter.

Yours very truly,

Section 9 of the Public Works Act provides that the Minister of Public Works shall have the management, charge and direction of the following properties belonging to Canada: (a) The public buildings.

Section 10 provides that nothing in section 9 shall be deemed to confer upon the Minister of Public Works the management, charge or direction of such public works as are, (b) by or under the authority of this Act or of any other Act of the Parliament of Canada, placed under the control and management of any other minister or department.

Section 35 provides that the Governor-in-Council may at any time transfer the management, charge and direction of any public work, or any power, duty or function with respect to any work or class of works, which is assigned to, or vested by statute in, any minister or department, to any other minister or department.

As I have been unable to find anything in the Indian Act which can be interpreted as conferring upon the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs the management, charge or direction of the buildings erected for or occupied by the Department of Indian Affairs, I am of the opinion that under Section 9 the management, etc., of such buildings is with the Minister of Public Works unless formally transferred to the Superintendent General by the Governor in Council in accordance with section 35.

On March 23rd, 1923, I wrote you suggesting that in future, when preparing your estimates, you ask for separate

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
for separate votes, (1) for the maintenance of existing schools and (2) for the erection or purchase of new schools; to which letter you replied on March 26th that careful consideration would be given to that suggestion. I find, however, on examining the estimates submitted to parliament for the current fiscal year that my suggestion was not acted upon.

As there thus appears to be no statutory authority for your department making any expenditure on account of the erection or maintenance of the buildings and as no formal transfer under the provisions of section 35 appears at any time to have been made I am of the opinion that the practice of your department of making such expenditure is contrary to the provisions of the Public Works Act, and I have to ask that you seek to obtain the necessary authority to permit of your incurring such expenditure in future.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Geo. [signature]

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to report that it is the established practice of the Department of Indian Affairs to undertake the erection, maintenance, repair, control and management of buildings required in the service of the Department, where funds are available therefor from Parliamentary Appropriations for Indian Affairs. The Auditor-General has drawn the attention of the Department to the fact that Section 9 of the Public Works Act provides that the Minister of Public Works shall have the management, charge and direction of public buildings, which in the absence of other statutory authority can only be transferred to another Department by Order of Your Excellency in Council, pursuant to the provisions of Section 35 of the said Act.

As it is considered to be convenient and desirable that the erection, maintenance, repair, control and management of such buildings should continue to be conducted by the Department of Indian Affairs the undersigned has the honour to recommend that such power, duty and function be transferred to and vested in the said Department of Indian Affairs, pursuant to the provisions of the aforesaid Section 35 of the Public Works Act.

Honourable Charles Stewart,

I have been giving attention to the division of the amount available in the estimate this year for the erection of new residential school buildings. The amount provided is $255,000.00, which I have proposed to spend as follows:

Completion and furnishing of the Guy Roman Catholic Residential School, Sturgeon Landing ............. $95,000.00

Peigan Church of England School ........................................... 50,000.00
Lytton School, Anglican .................................................. 30,000.00
Onion Lake Roman Catholic School, Sask. ......................... 30,000.00

My reasons for making these recommendations are as follows:

Guy Roman Catholic Residential School.

This school was begun last year, and $29,086.40 was spent in the erection of a unit consisting of the boiler room and boilers, kitchen, powerhouse, laundry, store rooms, chapel, and necessary incidentals. It is essential that the work should be continuous and that the building should be finished during the present season.

Peigan Residential Schools.

It is considered of first importance to furnish new buildings for these schools. The present buildings which were constructed years ago by the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches are dilapidated and insanitary, and cannot longer be used.

Onion Lake Roman Catholic Residential School.

$30,000.00 will be provided to begin the erection of this building. It has been urged upon us by the ecclesiastical authorities and by our own officers. In deciding this matter I had to consider the claims of the school which we know is required on the Keeseekoose reserve, in the Pelly Agency, Sask. These two schools are in different provinces of the Oblate Order. We were prepared two
years ago to provide for the Keesekoose school, but the Church authorities urged us to give precedence to a new school at McIntosh, in the province of Ontario, and to postpone the erection of a new school at the Keesekoose reserve. We have been very liberal with this eastern province of the Oblates, and have purchased all the Church-owned schools in the province within the jurisdiction of the Provincial who is now the Very Rev. J.B. Beys, so that the postponement of the erection of the Keesekoose building until next year cannot be considered a great hardship. In Father Blanchin's provincial district we have not spent very much money, and Archbishop O'Leary is pressing for a more liberal provision for the education of the Indians in his archdiocese.

Ottawa, June 14, 1926.

Dear Mr. Graham:

From time to time there is being directed to you, under separate cover, authority for building activity, replacements and repairs at Indian schools. I am writing this general letter so that instructions concerning purchasing, engagement of labour, etc., will not have to be repeated. Competitive prices should be secured before awarding any business, and when accounts are being presented, they should be supported by memoranda showing those asked to quote and the prices quoted. When it is necessary to engage labour, time sheets in duplicate, showing the receipts of the men, should be attached to vouchers.

The Department expects the management of Indian residential schools to do freighting, rough labour and assist in every way without payment. The older boys and the staff at these institutions should be used as much as possible.

The Appropriation for Indian Education is extremely limited this year and I am particularly desirous that this summer's expenditures shall be as low as possible. Whenever it is not necessary to expend the amount allowed, the Department will be very pleased to learn that you have been able to effect a saving. If you are in doubt as to the urgency of any of the improvements, please let me know and careful enquiry will be made before the expenditure is undertaken.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

To Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

The recent tragic fire at the Beauval School, resulting in a serious loss of life, prompts me to write concerning the necessity of constant care, if the fire hazard to life and property is to be minimized. If you are not satisfied with the present fire escape facilities at your school, I should be grateful if you would let the Department have a report.

Exits to fire escapes should open out, and, if they are sealed in any manner, it should be possible for even a young pupil to break through with a chair or boot. In each dormitory where small children sleep, an elder trusted pupil or a member of the staff should have his or her bed near the fire escape exit, and it should be that person's immediate duty, in the event of any alarm whatsoever, to prepare and guard the way to the fire escape.

Fire drill from the dormitories should be practised at least once a month. At such drills, the children and staff should actually complete their exit via the fire escapes and the practice should not be considered ended until every individual is out of the building.

The Principal should satisfy himself that there are a sufficient number of hand fire extinguishers at strategic places in the building and that those which require recharging from time to time are ready for effective use.

If there is no regular night watchman at your school, a member of the staff must make a thorough inspection of the building at ten o'clock and again at midnight; and there should be an hour's patrol following the laying of fires in the early morning.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the use of an electric washer at the Thunderchild Indian Residential School. While our officers agree that practically no damage will be caused by such a small attachment, the fact remains that our experience at Indian residential schools indicates that we cannot expect that electrical attachments will always be used with the necessary intelligence on the part of those responsible for the power plant. This has led to the general rule that they shall not be used and I cannot agree to any exceptions. Whenever you or your inspectors find that toasters, irons, percolators, heaters, etc., are in use where we generate our own electricity at schools, you should see that the practice ceases. I have, also, to request that you will direct that the pump at the new St. Phillip's School will be operated by a gasoline engine.

You may be surprised to learn that, approximately, $27,000 per annum is expended on the replacement of batteries alone at Indian residential schools. This charge on our appropriation is quite heavy and nothing which might increase this expenditure should be allowed.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

REGINA, SASK., September 29th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

It has been brought to my attention that at some of our residential schools the means of exit from the buildings, in cases of emergency, are in some instances difficult of access and the doors leading to the fire escapes are kept locked.

In view of the fact that the Principals of our schools are carrying a great responsibility in having so many children under their care, I would like to impress upon you the importance of having the buildings provided with adequate fire escapes which should have easy means of access. The doors or windows leading to the outside fire escapes should be provided with easily operated fastenings and should open out to prevent crowding and should not be kept locked, particularly in the dormitories during the hours when they are occupied by the children. Fire protection equipment should receive frequent inspections to make sure that it is efficiently operating at all times. The pupils should be given fire drill exercises at regular intervals that they may know exactly what to do in an emergency, even if left to their own resources. On no account should exits to the fire escapes be covered or nailed up. It is expected that you will co-operate in reducing the danger of loss of life by fire.

If the equipment for fire protection or quick evacuation of the building, in case of fire, is not, in your opinion, adequate at your school, I would be glad to receive a report from you pointing out in what particular you consider it inadequate.

Yours truly,

W. H. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Elliott:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, enclosing copy of communication from Mrs. Ethel Abram, of Muncey, in which she asks that the Department assist in providing hot lunches for the children attending the Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School. I may say that at the present time this question is under consideration, and a few days ago, Mr. Indian Agent McCookin was asked for a recommendation. You will understand that, if we provide a hot lunch for this school, four others in the same Agency will have to be considered, and it is just possible that many other schools in the province will be affected.

There is no question of the advisability of a hot lunch for school children. However, when the parents are able to provide it, there is doubt concerning the expediency of having it done by the Department. After all, one of our chief aims is to make the Indian independent. I have found the best solution is to ask the parents to give the children a little solid food for the noon hour, which is supplemented by soup, cocoa or milk, provided by the Department and prepared by the older girls under the supervision of the teacher.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

The unusually small amount now remaining in the Indian Education Appropriation for the current fiscal year has made imperative a study of the expenditure to ascertain the reasons. I am satisfied that there has been overexpenditure in connection with current expenses, but an effort to arrive at conclusions in this connection would be very unsatisfactory unless postponed until the end of the fiscal year, when all payments have been made. It is comparatively easy to analyze the expenditure for main buildings at Indian residential schools, and, after a preliminary study, I have been able to draw certain conclusions.

A year ago, three new main buildings were under construction - Shubenacadie, Cecilia Jeffrey and Alert Bay. There were included in the Main Estimates for the current year items to complete and furnish these buildings and for the establishment of the school generally. These amounts were determined in November, 1928, and in March, when it was found that the building programme was not as far advanced as was anticipated, you will remember that the effort to secure a supplementary estimate was abortive. The following figures are approximately correct:

| Cecilia Jeffrey | 15,000. | 60,000.                  | 45,000.       |
| Alert Bay       | 70,000. | 166,500.                 | 96,500.       |
| Total           |         |                          | $198,000.     |

The Department's inability to proceed with the Birtle and Blue Quills new main buildings this fiscal year has led us to authorize unprovided expenditures. The following table shows the main overexpenditures:

| Old Sun       | $40,000.| $93,500.                  | $53,500.      |
| Pine Creek    | 3,000.  | 19,000.                   | 16,000.       |
| Edmonton      | 2,000.  | 13,500.                   | 11,500.       |
| Beauval       | 25,000. | 29,500.                   | 4,500.        |
| Guy           | 3,000.  | 5,000.                    | 2,000.        |
| St. Bruno's   | 24,000. | 30,000.                   | 6,000.        |
| Kenora        | 4,500.  | 10,000.                   | 5,500.        |
| Kamloops      |         | 2,500.                    | 2,500.        |
| Ahousaht      |         | 5,500.                    | 5,500.        |
| Christie      |         | 4,500.                    | 4,500.        |

The overexpenditure for new buildings and improvements at Indian residential schools has amounted to $309,500. Against this, there is a saving of approximately $134,500 because of Birtle and Blue Quills appropriations, or a net unprovided expenditure of approximately $175,000.

This is undoubtedly the main reason for the present financial position - the causes leading to it being: 1. Our inability to secure a supplementary estimate at the beginning of the current fiscal year to complete Shubenacadie, Cecilia Jeffrey and Alert Bay; 2. Underestimating the cost of establishing new residential schools. It should be stated here that the estimates concerning main buildings have been more accurate than the estimates concerning water supply and sewage disposal, furnishings, outbuildings and extras to main buildings; 3. The rather free authorization of unprovided expenditure because of the unused Birtle and Blue Quills appropriations.

To remedy the present situation, I wish to recommend - 1. That the original proposal for financing the Old Suns re-establishment be followed, i.e., $40,000 only from the current appropriation and the balance from Band Funds, which will be reimbursed at a later date; 2. That an effort be made to secure a supplementary estimate for the current fiscal year for the completion of Shubenacadie, Cecilia Jeffrey and Alert Bay. All three schools can now be considered established, and further expenditure for any needed outbuildings, etc., can be provided in future estimates.

A refund from Band Funds of $53,500 on account of the Old Suns building (or whatever amount has been expended over and above $40,000 at the time of the refund) plus a supplementary estimate of $198,000 will relieve the situation to the extent of $251,500, making a total available from January first to March 31st of $617,500, which is more than the average amount available for the period during the last 8 years.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. Scott:

Our contract supplies such as Blankets, Tweeds, Serge, etc., are inspected either at Ottawa or at point of manufacture before being shipped, by a qualified Inspector employed at Ottawa at intervals. Altogether the time occupied in this work would not exceed one month duration at the most.

As regards such contract supplies as Flour and Bacon which are delivered direct to the Indian Agencies in the Prairie Provinces, they are subject to inspection by the Indian Agent who reports before accepting them, if he considers they are not equal in quality to the specifications of the contract and forwards samples which are inspected here, and if necessary the contractors are communicated with.

Before awarding contracts for Tea, Soap, etc., which are delivered at Regina, and distributed from there, samples are submitted to the Government Analysts at Ottawa to determine whether they are equal to what is called for. After delivery at Regina samples are sent here for inspection again.

This system of inspection has been in vogue for many years with satisfactory result, is inexpensive and safeguarding.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Buskard -

I have given careful consideration to your memorandum of October 21st, with reference to the inspection of contract supplies. I think I should note the last sentence quoted from your correspondent's letter:

"Some such system as this would also be an assurance to the principal of the school, and who could then check the invoices and receipts with confidence."

Your correspondent is labouring under a misapprehension if he thinks the Government is responsible for supplies for residential schools. These supplies of food, clothing, etc., are purchased by the management of the schools and paid for from a per capita grant allowed by the Department. In the bulk these purchases, covering all our schools, amount to fairly large quantities, but we are not in any way responsible.

With regard to the inspection of other supplies, the delivery of blankets, tweeds, serges and clothing generally is inspected either at Ottawa or at the point of manufacture by a qualified inspector employed at intervals. We would, of course, obtain from you the name of an inspector for this work.

In connection with such staples as flour and bacon, notice is given in the tender forms that "flour to be equal to Second Patent, to be fresh ground, etc."; and "all Bacon must be very fat, of the best quality 'Canadian Short Clear' without bone, sides to weigh from 45 to 50 lbs., etc." These supplies are delivered direct to the Indian agencies and the Indian agents
inspect before accepting them.

Grocery supplies of tea and soap are delivered at Regina and distributed there. We set a price of 50¢ a pound for tea and ask for samples which are submitted to the Government Analyst at Ottawa for a report on quality.

Taking all the circumstances into consideration I do not think we could advantageously adopt the system suggested.

Duncan Scott

Dear Mr. Scott:

I recently reported to you that the fire escapes leading from the dormitories at the McKay Boarding School, The Pas Agency, were locked, and pointed out that this was a very serious matter. It would be a very serious situation if a fire occurred, the fire escape locked, and the key in the hands of some member of the staff who was not handy to the door. The children would naturally run for the door where the fire escape was located, they would pile up, and there would be a repetition of what has occurred at schools in the north. Inspector Hamilton recently visited the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, and I was surprised to learn, when reading his report, that he found the fire escapes at this school locked and the keys in the hands of the matron.

To Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

The Department again wishes to urge those in authority at Indian residential schools to give constant and intelligent thought to the danger of fire. Fire escapes must be efficient, kept in repair, free from snow or ice and unlocked exits to them must open out. In dormitories which contain space for a supervisor, the best arrangement is to have the fire escape exit in the supervisor's room. If this is not possible, an older trusted pupil should have his or her bed near the exit and it should be that person's immediate duty, in the event of any alarm whatsoever, to prepare and guard the way to the fire escape. In dormitories where small children sleep, a member of the staff or a trusted older pupil must have their bed.

Fire drill from the dormitories must be practised at least every week in September, October and November and once each month throughout the rest of the year. At these fire drills, the children and the staff should actually complete their exit via the fire escapes and the practice must not be considered ended until every person is out of the building.

Principals should satisfy themselves that there are a sufficient number of hand fire extinguishers at strategic places in the building and that those which require recharging from time to time are ready for effective use. All members of the staff and the older pupils should receive instruction in the use of this fire fighting equipment.

At some older schools, windows open on the fire escapes.* If these are kept sealed in any manner, it should be possible for the officer or trusted pupil responsible for opening the window. Every night before retiring, this officer or pupil must test the window by raising it to insure easy operation if necessary during the night. In the event of an alarm at night and there is any difficulty with a window, the one in charge of that exit must clear out glass and sash with a strong chair which shall be always in a convenient place.

At a few Indian residential schools, it is found really necessary to keep locked the doors leading to fire escape. It is only in special circumstances
that the Department can countenance this practice. Where this dangerous habit is imposed by conditions, principals of schools must intelligently accept the risk they are incurring, and, in addition to the regular precautions there must be two members of the staff provided with a key for each dormitory. Both shall proceed immediately to the dormitory exit and supervise the evacuation of the room. Even this is not sufficient precaution. A third key to the door must be provided and placed in a little glass-fronted box, hung conveniently. A small inexpensive hammer must be attached so that the glass can be broken readily.

At all Indian residential schools where the interior of the building is of frame construction, there must be a thoroughly reliable night watchman, who will constantly patrol the building during the night. In the case of semi-fireproof and fireproof buildings where there is a night watchman, a member of the staff must make a thorough inspection of the building at 10 o'clock and again at midnight; and there should be an hour's patrol following the laying of fires in the early morning.

All members of the staff and those responsible pupils who have specific duties during fire drill or in the event of fire must have strict instructions as to what action they should take. The school should be thoroughly organized for escape in the event of fire and at all drills the fire escapes themselves must be used. Pupils must realize that the fire escape is the exit in emergencies. Several lives have been lost at our institutions in the past because pupils rushed to their regular stairs. Any principal who is not satisfied with the fire escape and fire prevention facilities should report immediately to the Department.

Dear Mr. Scott:

In my opinion, placing the responsibility with the Principal will have little or no effect.

I shall be glad to have the Department take the stand that the doors to the fire escapes should be kept unlocked at all times. If this can be done at one school, it can be done at another. Leaving a key in the hands of a grown-up pupil or member of the staff will not, in my opinion, be safe. This member of the staff

In larger schools where the ladder type of fire escape is installed, have repeatedly referred to the difficulty they have experienced in training the younger pupils especially, to make use of the same. Mr. Williams:

Re Salary Deduction Act, 1932.

The Treasury Board under date of June 9th, 1932, issued regulations regarding the Salary Deduction Act, 1932 from which the following is an extract:

"1. Deductions of 10% shall be made from all payments which are remuneration, regardless of their amount or designation, whether such payments be in cash or in kind, or be paid at annual, monthly, weekly, hourly, or other rates, or be based on fixed or prevailing rates, or authorized by statute, by order in Council, by the civil Service Commission, or by other competent authority."

"2. The deduction shall apply whether the compensation be in the form of wages, commissions, fees, allowances, extra pay, overtime pay, or in any other form, so long as the same constitutes remuneration for services in virtue of any employment in the public service of Canada as distinguished from such employment arising out of a specific contractual relationship. Conversely, regardless of designation, mode of authorization, or rate, payments made for abnormal living costs, travel or other similar purposes shall not be subject to the deduction."

This means that in addition to the regular full time employees who are paid at monthly or annual rates, it is intended that the provisions of the Act be applied to casual labour, skilled and unskilled, which may be employed from time to time at prevailing hourly rates. This matter has been seriously considered by the Auditor General and the Comptroller of the Treasury who feel that the spirit of the Act will be complied with re casual labour so long as the rates paid this fiscal year are at least 10% lower than the rates paid for similar classes of labour during the past year.

I beg to request, therefore, that the personnel who may have occasion to employ casual labour be instructed accordingly and to certify on all pay lists for casual labour that the rates paid are at least 10% below those paid last year or failing this to make a deduction of 10%.

N. C. Allen,
Representative of the Treasury.

Memorandum:

MR. BURKARD,

With reference to your memorandum of the 30th ultimo, with copy of portion of a letter addressed to the Minister by the Chief of the Fire Department at Kenora, Ont., regarding fire prevention and fire equipment at Indian residential schools, I attach hereto copy of a circular forwarded to the Principals of all the Indian residential schools as well as Indian agents and church representatives.

There are fire escapes and fire extinguishers at each of the schools, and, in quite a number of the schools, fire hose, which can be attached to the school water supply. As you will observe from the circular, the principals were instructed to carry out regular fire drill and to see that all fire extinguishers and other equipment are kept in a satisfactory condition, ready for effective use. In the cases of the schools recently burned, there was ample fire equipment, if same was in good condition. All agents are instructed that, during their visit to a school, they are to see that the fire extinguishers are properly charged and that fire drill is regularly held.

We spend a considerable amount each year in supplying new fire extinguishers and refills for old extinguishers, fire hose and in improving and adding fire escape facilities. The principals are continually being impressed with the importance and necessity of keeping fire equipment in good condition and ready for use. Should the equipment at any school be not properly looked after, it is entirely due to neglect on the part of the principal and staff.

Night watchmen are engaged at residential schools where the interior of the building is of frame construction and a fire hazard. Watchman's clocks have been supplied and it is necessary that the watchman makes hourly rounds during the night.

The reports of our agents and inspectors, regarding fire equipment, are carefully checked and any requests for refills or additional extinguishers or other fire equipment are promptly met. It has been the endeavour of the Schools Branch to take every step possible to see that adequate fire protection appliances are supplied. The principals must be held responsible, in view of the frequent instructions given, if all fire equipment is not properly looked after.

### Explanation of Increases

There is an increase of $160,990.00 in the Per Capita Grants to Residential Schools. This is accounted for by the increased accommodation in the new Birtle, Brandon, Muscowequan's, Blue Quills and Old Sun's Schools and by increases in pupilage granted to the following schools that have the necessary accommodation: Shubenacadie, Mohawk, Sioux Lookout, St. Albert, Alert Bay and Kamloops. Further, everywhere in Canada, Indian Residential Schools are now earning...
their full Per Capita Grant and it is no longer possible to vote the item at 94% or 95% of the possible earnings.

Salaries at Day Schools are practically the same as last year.

Assistance to Graduates shows an increase of $8,000.00. Demands to assist with high school and vocational training are constantly increasing.

Medical Attention - Residential Schools is increased by $8,000.00. This branch of the Department's service has been better organized with the result that more physical defects have been brought to the Department's attention.

Classroom Equipment shows an increase of $4,000.00. The Department has found it advisable to place in the hands of Indian pupils better and more varied texts and other instruments.

The item for Repairs and Equipment at Residential Schools is increased $8,000.00. Several institutions which will eventually need replacement must be kept in repair until funds can be provided for new buildings.

Additions and Outbuildings at Residential Schools is practically the same as last year.

In the past, the Appropriation for Indian Education has been confined to regular and foreseen expenditures. No provision has been made for emergencies, such as loss by fire, and, as a result, the Appropriation has become exhausted before the end of the fiscal year. This Miscellaneous item, which is approximately 2.8% of the Vote, is required to care for unforeseen and emergent needs.

ALBANY MISSION, Ont. (R. C.)

The Oblate Order, with the help of the Department, is erecting a new school on James Bay. The total cost will be approximately $60,000, and the Department is asked to grant $25,000 toward the undertaking. $15,000 has been given during the past 2 years and the final grant amounts to $10,000.

GARIBOO, B. C. (R. C.)

At this large and important school in central British Columbia, the water supply has been doubtful as to quantity and bad as to quality. The Dominion Water Power Branch has recommended a new system which will provide not only domestic supply but fire protection. The cost, including alterations to plumbing, is $32,000.

GARCROSS, Yukon, (C. E.)

This small school is greatly handicapped by lack of necessary facilities. The provision of a small addition has been postponed as long as possible. The cost will be $10,000.

BEAUVILLE, Sask. (R. C.)

The church authorities have erected a new fireproof building, at a cost of $135,000. The Department has already granted $50,000 for the purpose and there is now required $85,000.

SHINGWAUK HOME, Ont. (C. E.)

The main building at this school was erected in 1874 and is now both unsanitary and beyond repairing. In addition there is a serious fire hazard and it is proposed to rebuild on the same site, at a cost of $165,000.

LESSER SLAVE LAKE, Alta. (C. E.)

A new building is urgently required to replace three small and dilapidated Church of England schools in this area. To commence building $100,000.

SANDY BAY, Man. (R. C.)

At this school, it is impractical to arrange for proper water supply and sewage disposal. The building is not worth extensive repairs and it should be replaced on a new site. To commence building $100,000.

OLD SUN, Alta. (C. E.)

In 1930, the Department borrowed $80,000 from Band Funds, so that the school could be rebuilt immediately. It is proposed to make reimbursement $80,000.

**EXPLANATION OF INCREASES**

There is an increase of $27,395 in the Per Capita Grants to Residential Schools, which is accounted for by the proposed reopening of the Beauval School and slight increases in the pupilage of the Fort.
William and Moose Port Schools in Ontario; the Edmonton, St. Bernard's, Vermilion and Wabasca R. C. Schools in Alberta; and at Kuper Island and St. George's in British Columbia.

The item for Repairs and Equipment - Residential Schools is increased by $19,000. Last year, very little was expended on this work, with the result that there are many repairs and much painting to be done.

New Day Schools shows an increase of $26,100. During the past year, there was practically no building activity, but there are certain day schools where replacement and improvement is absolutely necessary.

Additions and Outbuildings - Residential Schools shows an increase of $68,505. At many schools, outbuildings are needed so that the work can proceed in a proper manner. Indian children cannot be trained for farm life without having barns and other buildings for live stock, granaries, root houses, etc.

These increases are offset by the decrease of $141,000 in Residential School New Main Buildings, none of which are included in this Estimate.

ESTABLISHING ALLOCMENTS OF APPROPRIATIONS AND COMMITMENT CONTROL.

Sections 26 and 29 of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act, 1931, provide for the establishment of a system of control over all Departmental Commitments which will be exercised by the Comptroller of the Treasury. The purpose of this control is to guard against the over-committing of appropriations. The introduction of this system involves:

1. Establishing a break-down of each appropriation into allotments for the different classes of expenditure provided for.

2. Setting up a system of commitment control over all appropriations that will enable the Comptroller to guard against authorising the incurrence of expenditures by Departmental Officers, that would overdraft an appropriation.

MAIN ALLOCMENTS OF APPROPRIATIONS.

1. The purpose of allotments is to assist Administrative Officers and the Comptroller in keeping commitments within the limits of appropriations. The extent to which appropriations may require to be sub-divided into allotments will depend on the nature and relative amount of the expenditures provided for and the break-down deemed necessary to ensure adequate control.

2. The classification of appropriations provided for Section 26 should be established by Administrative Officers of Departments working in conjunction with the Accounting Officers and other representatives of the Treasury, at or before the beginning of each fiscal year and should be designed to fulfil the purpose referred to in the next preceding Section. The allotments so agreed upon should be approved by the Treasury Board and should not be varied except by authority of the Board.
3.- An example of the allotments that may be established for certain appropriations, follows:

- Allotment for Salaries.
- Allotment for Travel Expenses.
- Allotment for Printing and Stationery.
- Allotment for Supplies and Materials.
- Allotment for Miscellaneous Expenses.
- Unallotted balance of Appropriation.

4.- It is important that the allotment for miscellaneous expenses shall be as small as possible. While materials and supplies may in some instances be covered by a single allotment, in every case where particular items of supplies are indispensable to the service concerned, or form a substantial part of the total required under this head, such items shall be covered by separate allotments.

5.- In establishing these allotments it is deemed advisable to retain a part of each appropriation as an unallotted balance. This balance may be used to supplement allotments already made or for the establishment of additional allotments. However, before any part of an unallotted balance may be used, the proper Administrative Officer of the Department concerned, must apply to the Comptroller for the required allotment of it. The Comptroller will submit the application to the Treasury Board together with his recommendation. If the application is approved by the Board, the allotment certificate will be issued and the Department advised. In the event of Departments applying for the transfer of an amount from one allotment to another, the same procedure will be followed.

6.- If an Administrative Officer, in applying for the allotment or transfer described in the preceding paragraph, represents to the Comptroller that the amount is urgently
and immediately required, the Treasury Board might authorise the Comptroller, in his discretion, to grant a temporary allotment and authorise commitments chargeable thereto, pending approval by the Treasury Board.

7.- A separate ledger account should be maintained for each allotment of an appropriation. It should show the amount allotted, commitments entered into, commitments liquidated, unliquidated balance of commitments, expenditures made, refunds and the unencumbered balance of the allotment.

SUB-ALLOTMENTS.

8.- It will be necessary in certain instances to divide the main allotments described above, into sub-allotments, in order that the Comptroller may be in a position to furnish the Administrative Officers with the information they require. These sub-allotments should be established by the Administrative Officers and the Comptroller working in conjunction with each other. The Administrative Officer may, with the concurrence of the Comptroller, change the sub-allotments after they have been established, without reference to the Treasury Board.

COMMITMENT CONTROL.

9.- The Act provides under Section 29, that no obligation of any nature shall be incurred unless the Comptroller has certified that there is an unencumbered balance of an appropriation available to which the expenditure may be charged. This provision calls for the establishment of a system of control over all Departmental commitments. In order that Administrative Officers may not be unduly hampered in the performance of their duties, the Treasury Board may, by regulation, authorise the Comptroller to modify
the application of control over commitments when he is satisfied that conditions warrant such modification.

10.- The procedure to be followed in charging commitments to the appropriation allotments and authorising Administrative Officers of the Department to incur the obligations, is outlined hereunder.

SALARIES AND WAGES.

11.- Where an appropriation provides for salaries and wages, it is intended that an allotment shall be made for this purpose. This allotment should be charged with commitments in the following manner:

12.- Charges to be made at the first of each fiscal year.
   (a) The total salaries and wages for the year of those employed on the 1st of April.
   (b) The total salaries and wages for the year of regular seasonal employees who may be employed after the first of the year.

13.- The information required by the Comptroller to establish these charges should be furnished by Administrative Officers in such form as the Comptroller may direct. One copy of the statement submitted shall be certified by the Comptroller and returned to the Department as authority for the commitment.

14.- Charges to be made from time to time throughout the year as commitments.
   (a) The salaries and wages of additional employees for the period of employment or to the end of the fiscal year (except regular seasonal help and casual employment) shall be charged as a commitment when the Administrative Head is advised by the Comptroller that there is an available balance in the appropriation allotment concerned.
   (b) Where a proposed promotion, reclassification or other change in status will result in an additional charge against an allotment for the year current,
the Department must obtain a certificate from the Comptroller that there is an available balance in the appropriation allotment concerned, and the amount thereof shall thenceforth become a commitment.

(c) Casual or special employment and pay for overtime work shall be provided for by blanket authorizations, issued to the Administrative Officers by the Comptroller in such amounts as he may deem necessary. When these authorizations are issued the amounts shall be charged to the appropriation allotments concerned, as commitments.

15.- The procedure outlined above for maintaining commitment control over allotments for salaries and wages will apply in general to allotments for the following:

Living and other allowances at stated rates.
Pensions that are voted annually.
Pay and Allowances.

Obligations incurred prior to the first of the year.

16.- Obligations incurred by Departments prior to April 1st, whether by contract, agreement, purchase order or otherwise, that are not fully liquidated before the close of the current fiscal year, must be reported to the Comptroller by the Administrative Officers. The amounts, which it is stated will come in course of payment during the ensuing year, shall be charged to the appropriation allotments concerned as commitments. These statements shall be rendered in duplicate in such form as the Comptroller directs. One copy when approved shall be certified and returned to the Administrative Officers concerned.

Contracts and Agreements in General (Except for Unit Prices.)

17.- All contracts for supplies, materials, equipment, construction and services, (except contracts for unit prices) must bear the certificate of the Comptroller that there is a balance available in the appropriation allotment concerned, before they are entered into. The amount coming in course of payment during the fiscal year whether actual or estimated shall be charged as a commitment when the certificate is issued.
PURCHASE OF SUPPLIES, MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT
(Other than those covered by Contracts referred to above.)

18.- Purchase orders must be used for the acquisition of supplies, materials and equipment, unless otherwise provided for in the regulations. The order shall be prepared by the proper Officer, signed by the Deputy Head or other duly authorized Officer of the Department and submitted to the Comptroller for certificate that there is a balance available in the appropriation allotment concerned. One copy of the order shall be retained and the remaining copies returned to the Administrative Officer concerned. The actual or estimate amount of the order shall be charged to the appropriation allotment concerned, as a commitment, when the certificate is issued.

SUPPLIES AND MISCELLANEOUS EXPENSES.

Where the Comptroller is satisfied that it is impracticable for Administrative Officers to obtain specific certificates for certain classes of expenditure he may issue blanket authorities to incur such expenses. These authorities should be referred to as Treasury Warrants and shall be charged as commitments when issued. The Comptroller may, in his discretion, issue these warrants for:

(a) the estimated requirements from month to month or for

(b) the amount of the allotment or sub-allotment established for a particular class of expenditure.

20.- This system may be used to provide for expenditures such as,-

Certain food and forage supplies,
Medical supplies for hospitals,
Special services such as medical and nursing services,
Pay and Allowance treatment compensation,
Telegrams, cables and wireless messages,
Long distance telephone calls,
Freight, express, cartage, etc.,
Travel expenses not covered by accountable advances
Sundry and unforeseen expenses.
21.- The Comptroller may authorize Departments in general to incur incidental or unforeseen expenses not exceeding $10.00 at any one time, that cannot be conveniently covered by the usual certificate.

ACCOUNTABLE ADVANCES.

22.- Accountable cash advances shall be made by the Comptroller on application from the Deputy Head or his duly authorized representative, if there is a balance of an allotment available to which such advances may properly be charged. These advances shall be charged as commitment when made and shall be accounted for in accordance with regulations of the Treasury Board, or in the absence of such regulations, as directed by the Comptroller. The advances may be made for such purposes as -

- Petty cash requirements.
- Travelling Expenses.
- Expenses of field parties.
- Disbursing officers in general.

23.- Adjustment of Commitment Charges.

When owing to any cause a commitment is reduced or increased the required adjustment shall be made from returns furnished by the Administrative Officer. These returns shall be submitted in such form and at such time as the Comptroller directs.
March 16, 1932.

Memorandum:

MR. PAGET,

Pursuant to instructions you have received from the Comptroller of the Treasury, I wish to make some comments and to ask for certain blanket authority for expenditures in connection with the 1932-33 Appropriation for Indian Education, which may be called Allotment No. 9, Vote 201. This allotment has already been divided into sub-allotments, and you will note that there is no unallotted balance. To provide such balance would be extremely difficult, as each sub-allotment is reduced to a minimum. However, after reading the instructions from the Comptroller, I am satisfied that the retention of an unallotted balance within an allotment is not necessary, as the Comptroller is empowered to authorize an administrative officer to change sub-allotments without reference to the Treasury Board. In fact, at present I am inclined to recommend that Allotment 9, Indian Education, be not subdivided into sub-allotments. It is extremely desirable that all expenditure at any one school, whether for grants, salaries, repairs, equipment, or even new buildings, be shown in one ledger account. This greatly simplifies cost accounting. If the Comptroller insists on sub-allotments in this allotment, then I should be grateful for an opportunity of making a new classification.

With reference to commitment control, I believe some modification is warranted because of the nature of the expenditure and the conditions which obtain in Indian educational work. The procedure outlined by the Comptroller for maintaining commitment control over allotments for salaries will be entirely suitable for 1 - per capita grants, 2 - day school salaries, and 3 - tuition grants. At the beginning of each fiscal year, the allotment could be charged with the full amounts and a certificate issued.

In connection with the construction of new buildings, the procedure indicated by the Comptroller will, of course, be satisfactory. For all other expenditures from this allotment (Nos. 4 to 10 and 13 as listed hereunder), it is impracticable to obtain specific certificates. The first intimation the Department has concerning a great number

of expenditures
of expenditures in the presentation, by Indian agents, or school principals, of the actual accounts. To indicate the detailed nature of the expenditure, I might state that, last fiscal year, $916 cheques were issued against the Appropriation for Indian Education. Less than $200 of these were for grants, salaries and the construction of buildings; leaving about $700 payments of amounts under $75 or $80. I have to recommend, for these miscellaneous expenditures, that blanket authorities or treasury warrants for the year be issued.

For the Comptroller's information, I briefly explain the nature of the expenditures for Indian Education, Allotment No. 2, Vote 201. It should be remembered that, if he insists on sub-allotments, I should like to suggest another classification.

1. Per Capita Grants for Residential Schools - $1,239,492.

286 full time and 20 part-time teachers at 264 schools. Salaries are cut 10% for the coming fiscal year.

Approximately 375 Indian children are attending public schools, orphanages, high schools or colleges. A few graduates are assisted to establish themselves. Grants for these purposes are made.

In two provinces, the Department has an Inspector of Indian Schools, but elsewhere in Canada we enlist the cooperation of the Provincial Departments of Education for this service.

In the past, all textbooks, scribblers and stationery used at Indian schools has been ordered in small quantities from the King's Printer. I am seriously considering ordering in quantity and stocking in our own Department. This would reduce the requisitions, which must be dealt with by several officers, to a minimum. I am also prepared to recommend that special authority be given to this Department to purchase scribblers, exercise books and readers locally. This would save all requisitioning and transportation costs. There is very small margin on this class of school equipment and it would be in the interests of economy, from the standpoints of time, labour and money, if we could authorize schools to purchase themselves. Ottawa, June 16th, 1933.

U. C. Benson, Esq.,
Acting Secretary,
Treasury Board,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have discussed the statement of "Suggested Reductions" in the appropriations of the Department of Indian Affairs with the administrative officials of that Department, and am satisfied that the following represent the maximum reductions which can safely be made without seriously affecting the administration of the several services concerned.

Civil Government Salaries .................. $ 4,614.
Contingencies, on account Miscellaneous Expenditure... $600.

General Vote for Administration of Indian Affairs -
Administration Allotment .................... $ 30,000.
Indian Education ................................ $8,000.
Medical Services .............................. $6,000.
Aids to Indians ............................... $20,000.

$111,600.

While the reductions proposed to be made by the Department of Indian Affairs appear to be small in comparison with the amounts suggested in your memorandum, it might be pointed out that the appropriations of this department have already been reduced by $1,650,000, or approximately 20-1/2% since 1930-31. The consequence is that only the most urgent and essential services are provided for.
I cannot see any prospect of effecting any further reductions or savings in cost of personnel other than the amount shown for civil government salaries. The outside establishment of this department, owing to the nature of its functions, comprises over 100 small units ranging in strength from one to six employees. It is, therefore, not practicable to make reductions in the staff.

The proposed saving to be effected in administration expenses, can only be accomplished by curtailing or postponing expenditures on government owned buildings and exercising the strictest economy in miscellaneous items of expenditure. This allotment was drastically cut last year with the result that charges for maintenance of and repairs to government property could not be incurred.

The Per Capita Grants to Residential Schools have already been reduced by 10% so that any further reduction in this particular class of expenditure is, in my opinion, neither desirable nor advisable. Substantial amounts were struck out of the current estimates for Education before they were submitted to the Treasury Board so that the total reduction from 1932-33, including the amount now proposed, will be $350,000.

The amount estimated for the current year for Medical Services is $25,000 less than last year. A further reduction of $16,000 is proposed. This class of expenditure is being kept down to a minimum consistent with reasonable health conditions. No provision is made to meet the additional expenses of unforeseen epidemics and the consequent costs of increased hospitalization. Even now requests for hospital treatment are being refused owing to lack of funds. It is considered that any arbitrary restriction of expenditure would mean a definite reduction in the activities and usefulness of the Medical Branch.

Last year the expenditure on account of aids to Indians (including relief of destitute) was $955,000, while for the current year only $800,000 has been provided. Therefore, a saving of $155,000 must be effected to keep within the appropriation. A further reduction of $40,000 is proposed, but the saving should not be effected unless absolutely necessary especially in view of the trend of less unemployable nature of this class of expenditure and conditions existing generally throughout the country.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM:

NEW DAY SCHOOL BUILDINGS - ESTIMATES, 1935-36

CORNWALL ISLAND, EAST - New school building with teacher's living quarters - $4,500.

Requests have been made during the past four years for the establishment of a day school on the east end of Cornwall Island, St. Regis Indian agency. There are approximately 40 children for whom no school facilities are provided and who do not attend any school. The present school is situated at the west end of the island - a distance of approximately five miles from where the Indians at the east end of the island reside. An officer of the Department, who visited the reserve in August, last, states that the Indians are anxious for the children to have the advantage of an education but they were unable to have them attend the day school on the west end of the island, owing to the distance. He says this situation is causing unfavourable comment amongst the adjoining white municipalities. The need of school facilities is urgent.

Cornwall Island is located in an angle between the boundaries of the province of Ontario and Quebec and the State of New York.

WIKWEMIKONG - Addition to school building, to provide increased living accommodation for teachers - $1,000.

A new 2-roomed school building has recently been completed and classes opened therein on the first instant. At the rear, a very narrow part is partitioned off for living quarters for two teachers. There is insufficient accommodation. It will be necessary to extend the building to provide increased accommodation. No doubt, it will be possible to obtain certain of the material from the old school building, which is to be demolished. The providing of more space for the teachers' living quarters is absolutely necessary.

This school is located in the village of Wikwemikong, on the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve, Manitoulin Island, Ont.

LETTAGAMI - To assist in erection of school building with rooms attached for living accommodation of teacher . . . . . . 750.

A request has been received from the Anglican missionary, strongly supported by the local Indian Agent, for school facilities for the Indians residing on this reserve - No. 71, in the Chapleau Indian Agency, province of Ontario. The
Indians of the Band have become fairly well established, and the move towards a school would encourage them to remain on the reserve instead of wandering all over the north country, as they have been in the habit of doing for the past number of years. If a small school was erected and a suitable teacher engaged, the children could remain on the reserve while the parents are away trapping. There are 25 children of school age. In the erection of a building, the Indians have agreed to do a great deal of the work, themselves, voluntarily, and they propose that a log building be erected, but lumber for flooring and other purposes will be required, together with windows, doors, etc. - which will cost about $750. At present, the children on this reserve are receiving no education.

ELSAS - To assist in erection of school building with living accommodation for teacher - $1,200.

On this reserve - No. 83, on Kapuskasing Lake, in the Chapleau Indian Agency, there are 15 children of school age at the present time, but the number will be increased as soon as the Indians are assured that their children will be able to attend school. The Indians would gladly labour, voluntarily, in the erection of a building doing the work under a competent foreman who would have to be engaged for the purpose. There is no timber suitable for building purposes. The building would be of frame construction and the material will have to be supplied. The probable cost will be about $1,200. There are no educational facilities provided for the Indian children on this reserve.

RABBIT ISLAND - To erect a school building with teacher's living quarters - $4,000.

The Rabbit Island settlement is located some 7 miles north of the present Wikwemikong Indian Day School and is on the Manitoulin Island Unceded reserve. On this section of the reserve, there are 34 children of school age. The lack of school facilities in this section has necessitated a number of families deserting their farms to live in the village of Wikwemikong. The Indians have been requesting a school for some years, in order that they could live on their farms and at the same time have their children receive an education.

SAGAMOOG - To erect a school building with teacher's living quarters - $4,000.

On several of the reserves, there are Indian children who have never attended school - no facilities being provided. During the past four years, no new day school buildings have been erected and few repairs to existing school buildings. The Estimates for 1935-36 include provision for the erection of seven new day school buildings, on reserves where the Indian children have never attended school; also to replace old and dilapidated buildings on three reserves and carry out repairs to several other buildings. The erection of the new day school buildings will provide school facilities for approximately 350 children. Full particulars are given in the memorandum attached to the Estimates.
