MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

The Estimates for Indian Education for the coming fiscal year, 1935-36, are in course of preparation. Requests have been received from the under-mentioned Indian Residential Schools that grants be provided for an increase in pupilage, as follows:

| School          | Present | Requested | Increase | P. C. Grant | Amount |
|-----------------|---------|-----------|----------|-------------|--------|
| KENORA (R.C.)   | 76      | 82        | / 6      | $165. 8     | 990.   |
| SPANISH (R.C.)  | 230     | 250       | / 20     | 160.        | 3,200. |
| SHINGWAUK (C.E.)| 100     | 125       | / 25     | 160.        | 4,000. |
| Pure Creek A.C. | 90      | 100       | / 10     | 160.        | 1,600. |
| BRANDON (E.G.)  | 165     | 170       | / 5      | 170.        | 856.   |
| ROUND HALL (C.O.)| 75      | 80        | / 5      | 160.        | 800.   |
| Morley (U.C.)   | 70      | 100       | / 30     | 165.        | 4,950. |
| ST. BERNARD'S (R.C.) | 75    | 100       | / 10     | 175.        | 4,375. |
| WABASCA (R.C.)  | 100     | 125       | / 10     | 160.        | 4,500. |
| HESTER BAY (C.E.)| 200    | 210       | / 10     | 180.        | 1,800. |
| IJAC (R.C.)     | 150     | 165       | / 10     | 170.        | 2,550. |
| ST. MARY'S (R.C.)| 125    | 200       | / 25     | 170.        | 3,400. |

TOTAL: - $40,955.00

Less 15% - $6,142.75

Increase required - $34,812.25

$22,049

The following are the reasons for the increases in pupilage at each of the above named schools:

KENORA
Grant is now provided for 76 pupils at $165 per capita, (less 15%). It was necessary to admit six extra orphan and neglected children. This school is located near the Cecilia Jeffrey (Presbyterian) Residential School, which is allowed
for 145 pupils. There are more Catholic children in the Kenora agency than the Kenora Residential School can accommodate. The number for which an increase in grant is now requested, viz.: 82 pupils, is the full number the school can accommodate. The six extra pupils now in residence over the number provided for in our Estimates were taken in by the Principal at the request of the Department, as they were neglected children. I beg to recommend that grant be provided for 6 extra pupils.

SPANISH (R.C.)

Grant is requested for an increase of 20 pupils. At present, grant is provided for 230 pupils at $160 per capita. There are now 250 children enrolled. This is the only Roman Catholic Residential School in Ontario, east of Sault Ste. Marie. There are many urgent requests to provide for orphan and neglected children from Caughnawaga, St. Regis and the reserves, in Quebec. It has been necessary to place them in this school and allow grant as supernumerary pupils. There is ample accommodation, and I would request that provision be made in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year for an increase of 20 in the pupilage. There is ample accommodation for 250 children at this school.

SHINGWAUK HOME (C. of E.)

A new residential school building is in course of erection and will likely be completed early next Spring, to provide accommodation for 125 pupils. The present Estimates provide a grant for 100 pupils only. There are requests from the various reserves in Ontario and Quebec for the admission of orphan and neglected children of the Anglican Church to this school, and there will be a sufficient number of pupils available to fill the new school to capacity. I would suggest that provision be made in our Estimates for the coming fiscal year for an increase of 25 pupils.

BRANDON (U. C.)

The Principal has requested that the pupilage at this school be increased by five, i.e., 170 instead of 165, as at present. There is ample accommodation for the increased pupilage. Requests received by the Principal from agents and parents indicate that a total of 170 pupils will be available. In some cases, the Principal has had to refuse admissions, as he had an enrolment up to the full number for which grant was provided. I submit the request for provision of grant for 170 pupils for your consideration and direction.

ROUND LAKE (U. C.)

The church authorities and the local Indian Agent have requested that grant be provided for an increase of 5 pupils. The dormitories provide accommodation for 40 boys and 40 girls, and this number of pupils are available from the reserves in the Crooked Lake agency. At present, grant is allowed for 75 pupils. This request is submitted for your consideration and instructions, whether the increase asked for be provided.

- Morley
Plans are under way for the building of an addition to this school, to provide accommodation for 100 pupils. At present, grant is only provided for 70 pupils. As the addition will, no doubt, be completed early next Spring and as there are a sufficient number of children available on the Stony reserve to fill the school, I would recommend that provision be made in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year for an increase of 25 in the pupilage. This will provide a grant for a total of 100 pupils at this school.

ST. BERNARD'S (R.C.)

His Lordship Bishop Guy has urged that grant be provided for an increase of 25 in the pupilage at this school. At present, grant is provided for 75 pupils. His Lordship wishes this to be increased to provide for 100. The parents of the children are hunting Indians, and the school management is called upon to accept their children when the parents are absent. Bishop Guy states that there is ample accommodation for 100 children in the school. This request is submitted for your consideration and direction.

WABASCA (R.C.)

Bishop Guy has requested grant for 25 extra pupils at this school. At present grant is provided for 100. The same reasons apply as in the case of the St. Bernard's School, mentioned above. His Lordship states there is accommodation for 125 pupils, and this number are available. I would ask your direction as to whether the increased pupilage, as requested by Bishop Guy, in the case of this school be provided.

ALERT RAY (C.E.)

The Missionary Society of the Church of England, under whose auspices this school is conducted; the Principal and the local Indian Agent have requested that provision be made for an increase of 10 in the pupilage. At present, provision is made for 200 pupils. The school has already the increased number of pupils in residence - there being sufficient space and accommodation for them. The local agents have many requests to place children of indigent parents, and they frequently request the Principal to take in cases of special emergency. During the past two years, this school has been handling several pupils over the number for which grant is provided. I beg to recommend that provision be made for an increase of 10 in the pupilage, providing a grant for a total of 210 pupils.

LEJAC (R.C.)

Requests have been received, during the past two years, for an increase in pupilage at this school. A new principal was appointed last April, and he and the local Indian Agent state that there is accommodation for 25 pupils more than the number for which grant is provided. The Indian Agent states that the new Principal has put new spirit into this school. It is requested that at least 15 extra pupils be allowed. The
Agent says the parents of the children uphold the school and there is a large number of Roman Catholic Indian children in British Columbia from which recruits can be obtained. There is no difficulty in keeping this school to its full accommodation. I would recommend, for your approval, that grant be provided for 15 extra pupils, making the total number for which grant is allowed 165.

ST. MARY'S (R.C.)

During last year, the church authorities who own the buildings at this school carried out alterations, repairs and extensions and can provide accommodation for 200 children. At present, grant is provided in our Estimates for 125 pupils. The Principal, who has visited the Department, has strongly urged that a grant be provided for a total of 200 children. Last year, in view of the alterations made to the building, the grant at this school was increased from 107 to 125 pupils. There are 160 children at present in the school. The Principal states he was forced to accept this extra number and that there is easily available the full number of pupils, viz.: 200, for which accommodation can be provided. I would request your favourable consideration for increasing the pupilage by at least 50, if you consider it not advisable to provide the increase asked for, viz.: 75 pupils, in our Estimates for the next fiscal year.

As shown by the figures in the summary above, it would require, approximately, the sum of $34,650.25 to provide for the increased pupilage asked for by the church authorities, principals and agents for the above mentioned schools. This would require an increase in our Appropriation for Per Capita Grants over that provided last year.

I might say, further, that the church authorities have requested that at least part of the 15% in grants be restored. I should be pleased to have your direction as to whether, in preparing our Estimates, the deduction of 15% be continued.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

I submit the following schedule of Buildings and Works, in the order of their importance, to be included in any extension of the Public Works Construction Appropriation:

Sturgeon Lake and St. Bernard's - These schools are located in the Lesser Slave Lake Residential Schools Agency, Alberta, Federal District of Peace River. They are not on reserves. It is proposed to amalgamate the two above named schools and erect a new residential school building of fireproof construction - to accommodate 200 children - to replace the present old buildings, which have outlived their usefulness. The new building will be erected on a central site, near transportation facilities, and will accommodate the Roman Catholic Indian children from both these points.

Wabasca (C.E.) and Whitefish Lake (C.E.) - These schools are located in the Lesser Slave Lake Residential Schools Agency - Federal District of Athabaska and Peace River, respectively. It is proposed to erect a new residential school building, on a central site, to replace the present old buildings at the above schools. The buildings at these points have outlived their usefulness. The new building is to accommodate the children of the Anglican Church in the Lesser Slave Lake agency and will be conducted under the auspices of that denomination.

Thunderchild (R.C.) - To install water supply system $15,000.

This school is situated at Delmas, Sask., Battleford Indian Agency (Federal District of South Battleford). It is intended to improve a spring, install pumping equipment and a pipe-line a distance of approximately one mile, to provide an ample supply of water for use of the above school.

St. Philips (R.C.) - To install electric power line $5,500.

In order to provide electric power service for school use, it is intended to install a power line, a distance of approximately 6 miles, from the nearest source of supply. This school is located at St. Philips, Sask., in the Pelly Indian Agency - federal district of Mackenzie.

- Mud Lake, Ont.
Mud Lake, Ont. - To erect two-roomed day school building on the Mud Lake Reserve, No. 35 (Federal District of Peterboro West), each classroom to accommodate 36 children. This building is required to replace the former one which was destroyed by fire. At present, classes are being conducted in the council hall. Cloakrooms and adequate heating facilities should be provided. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $600

Christian Island (U.C.) Ont. - To erect a new school building, with two classrooms, to provide seating accommodation in each for 30 pupils and also living quarters for two teachers, for the Protestant Indian children on the Christian Island Reserve, No. 30 - Federal District of Simcoe East. The present building is unsuitable for school purposes and does not accommodate the Indian children available. At the present time, it is necessary to have the second classroom in the council hall. It is also difficult to obtain suitable living accommodation for teachers. It would be necessary to provide adequate heating facilities . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $740

Oneida No. 1, Ont. - To erect a new school building with classroom accommodation for 40 pupils and teacher's living quarters, also adequate heating facilities. There are at present two schools on the Oneida Reserve, No. 41, in the Caradoc Indian Agency, and approximately 230 children of school age. There is urgent need for further school facilities, as there are a large number of children who do not attend any school. Outdoor toilets will also be required . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $100

New Credit, Ont. - To erect a new two-roomed school building, with classroom accommodation for 30 pupils in each, to replace the former building, which was destroyed by fire. This school is located on the New Credit Indian Reserve, No. 40 A, in the New Credit Indian Agency (Federal District of Haldimand). At present, classes are being conducted in the council hall, but the members of the Band have asked for a new school. Living quarters will be required for two teachers, as it is difficult to obtain suitable boarding accommodation in the neighbourhood. Outdoor toilets and heating facilities will also be necessary . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $710

Montreal Lake, Sask. - To erect a new school building and teacher's living quarters, with classroom accommodation for 32 children. This school is situated on Montreal Lake Reserve, No. 106, in the Carlton agency, Saskatchewan (Federal District of Prince Albert). The Agent has requested the erection of a new building to replace the present old one, which is in a dilapidated condition . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $600

Aide to Indians

To provide for the construction of thirty new houses for Indian families who are forced to move to higher ground as a result of the raising of the water level of Lac Seul . . . . . $25,000.

Explanation

The Lac Seul Conservation Act passed June 11th, 1928, provides for the raising of the waters of Lac Seul, for power development purposes, to a maximum level of 1,172 feet. This will result in flooding certain Indian Reserve lands to a depth of 14 feet.

It therefore becomes necessary to re-establish thirty Indian families on higher ground during the present year.

It is not considered feasible, owing to their condition, to move the houses which these families now occupy. Consequently, new houses will have to be constructed.

According to plans and estimates prepared, each of these houses will cost in the neighbourhood of $850.00. Therefore, at least $25,000.00 will be required for this purpose.

The actual expenditure incurred will be included in this Department's claim for compensation under the provisions of the Lac Seul Conservation Act, passed on June 11th, 1928.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

With reference to the communication from the Honourable the Minister of Finance to the Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs regarding the probable results of the operations for the current fiscal year, based on present estimates and programmes, I have to say in regard to the finances for Indian Education that the total Appropriation is $1,670,000. Of this amount, the sum of $1,561,225, or 79% of the total appropriation, is fixed charges, viz.:-

Per Capita Grants - $1,286,925.
Salaries, Teachers, Janitors, Truant Officers, Night Watchmen, etc. - $274,300.
Total - $1,561,225.

From the above, it will be seen that only the sum of $408,775 remains, to provide the cost of the erection of five day schools, repairs, alterations, equipment, fuel, classroom supplies and equipment, travelling expenses, freight, and miscellaneous expenditures.

The total expenditure for Indian Education, to October 31st, 1935, was $1,150,546.78, leaving the sum of $729,453.22 to cover the expenditures for five months - the balance of the present fiscal year.

From the above balance on hand, there will be required, to meet all commitments for the balance of the present fiscal year, as follows:-

Per Capita Grants - $321,700.
Salaries - $114,300.
Buildings, Repairs & Equipment - $150,000.
Supplies, Fuel, Stationery - $50,000.
Travelling Expenses of pupils and Tuition Grants - $20,000.
Miscellaneous and Unforeseen - $90,000.
Total - $746,000.

Commitments which have already been made cannot be altered. The work on construction of new day school buildings is practically completed, as is, also, the work in connection with the carrying out of repairs, alterations, improvements and the supplying of equipment.

It may, therefore, be possible to save an unexpended balance from the Appropriation for Indian Education, to the amount of, approximately, $43,000.00.

Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

To provide water supply system . . . . . . . . . 10,000.00

The present water supply is obtained from the Canadian National Railways' tank at Delmas. The source of supply is a pipeline to the Saskatchewan river. The school authorities pay the expense, approximately $100 per month, in pumping the water. The Department has spent considerable funds in drilling a well, without results. The matter of a water supply was referred to the Dominion Water Power Branch, whose engineer reports that there is a spring, with a plentiful supply of water, that could be piped to the school, and the cost of installing the system from the spring should not exceed the sum of $10,000. Grants - Per Capita Deduction 10% $130,000.00

During the period of depression, it was necessary, in the interests of economy, to make a flat decrease in per capita grants of 10%, during the fiscal year 1932-33. For the fiscal year 1933-34, per capita grants were further decreased by 5%, making a total deduction of 15%. Ten per cent. of the cut in the per capita grants was restored in the Estimates for the fiscal year 1935-36. In the cutting of the per capita grant by 10% in the Appropriation for 1936-37, it will reduce the rate to the same as was paid during the fiscal year 1934-35. The church authorities under whose auspices the residential schools are conducted, made a strong demand for the restoration of the 15% deduction in per capita grants, and the previous administration agreed to a restoration of only 10%. In preparing the Estimates for the fiscal year 1936-37, the grants were calculated on that basis - this being, as stated, the same rate as was paid during the current
the current fiscal year. There will, no doubt, be very strong objection made, on the part of the church authorities, to a cut in grants at the present time; but this will be entirely necessary if the Appropriation for the fiscal year, 1936-37, is to be reduced as requested.

Grants - Tuition Deduction $5,000.00

This will leave the amount requested in the Appropriation for 1936-37 at the same rate as was provided during the fiscal year 1935-36. Each year, more Indian children are passing their Entrance to high schools and are anxious to obtain a higher education. There are many demands, and it has been necessary to set a fairly high standard before any pupil is allowed a grant. Besides, there are more Indian children attending white schools in cases where the Department has no facilities provided. In the Estimates for 1934-35, the sum of $30,000.00 was provided for tuition grants, but this was cut in the current year's appropriation to $25,000.00. By reducing the amount asked for in the Estimates for 1936-37, it will mean that a number of deserving pupils will be deprived of the opportunity to obtain a higher education than our Indian day schools provide.

Assistance to Ex-pupils Deduction $2,400.00

In the past, very little provision has been made to assist pupils of residential schools after they graduate. It is a difficult problem to know what to do with these pupils when they return to their reserves. In cases where they marry and take up farming and housekeeping on their own account, the Department has provided a small grant to the man, to assist him in building a house, and to the woman in supplying household equipment. There are many demands to increase the assistance to our ex-pupils in becoming established on their reserves; and it has been only through lack of funds that greater assistance has not been given the ex-pupils. The time has arrived when very serious consideration will have to be given to the problem of establishing ex-pupils on their reserves.

Grants - Fall Fairs Deduction $100.00

This grant was given to encourage pupils of Indian day schools to carry out home gardening for the boys and sewing, cooking and general household duties for the girls. Fall fairs are held on a number of the reserves and small grants awarded for prizes in the various classes of the exhibits. From the appropriation provided, the Department is unable to meet the requests for grants for prizes for these school fairs.

- New Buildings -
New Buildings - Residential Schools

Deduction $90,000.00

This amount was to erect an addition to the present Crowfoot R. C. Residential School building, on the Blackfoot reserve ($50,000) and to erect a new residential school building at Whitefish Lake, Lesser Slave Lake agency, northern Alberta ($40,000).

The present building at the Crowfoot Residential School accommodates 75 children, and there are 30 children on the reserve for whom no school facilities are available. It was intended to erect an addition and make alterations in the present building, to provide for the accommodation of these children and also to provide facilities for the tubercular pupils. At present, there are 18 pupils of this school who are afflicted with active tuberculosis. By not providing the funds required to erect the addition and make alterations in the present building, it will result in a very serious menace to the health of the children at present in the school, and about 30 children will be deprived of educational facilities. This school is conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church.

The present old residential school buildings at Whitefish Lake and Wabasca, in the Lesser Slave Lake agency, are dilapidated and beyond repair. They have become unfit for use and are a menace to the health of the pupils. It is intended to amalgamate these two schools by the erection of a new modern school building on the Whitefish Lake reserve. It was proposed to forward building material and prepare a foundation during the winter of 1936-37, as all materials have to be forwarded by sleigh. If the work is not proceeded with, it may be necessary, in the interests of the children's health, to close both present buildings and send the children to their homes, pending the erection of a new building. The Church of England authorities, under whom this school is conducted, have, during the past several years, strongly urged the erection of a new building, to accommodate 80 children.

New Works - Residential Schools

Deduction $13,000.00

The above amount was to provide new out-buildings at several of the Indian residential schools. While there is need for these buildings, the schools at which they were to be erected will have to carry on the work under present conditions.

- New Buildings Day
New Buildings - Day Schools

Deduction $60,700.

It was intended to erect 13 new day school buildings, 6 of which were to replace present old buildings and 7 to establish new schools on reserves where there are at present no educational facilities provided. It was also intended to erect one teacher's residence, to provide living accommodation for a teacher. While there is necessity for the erection of new buildings, where they have been hanging on, on a number of reserves, without educational facilities, the children can continue to do without schooling. Where it was intended to erect new buildings, to replace the present ones, the work will have to be carried on under existing conditions.

Repairs - Residential Schools

Deduction $4,000.

While the repairs covered by the above amount are necessary, the schools at which it was intended to do the work can manage without the repairs being carried out until such time as it is possible to provide the funds for the purpose.

MR. ORR,-

The Estimates for Indian Education for the current fiscal year provide for the following work at the Cequaleetza Indian Residential School:

2. Supplying one - 15 h. p. high pressure boiler - 500.
3. Purchase of one hot water tank - 400.

Mr. Agent Daunt, in forwarding his Estimates, last fall, states that the installation of the two vacuum pumps in the boiler room is rendered necessary because the steam return from the upper radiators back to the boilers is so slow that condensation takes place too rapidly and pockets are formed. To overcome this, the Engineer has to resort to forcing his furnaces at full capacity. This waste of fuel does not bring results and, in consequence, the building is cold on its exposed side and radiators are frozen.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honorable the Superintendent General,

The Estimates for the fiscal year 1937-38 are now in course of preparation. I would request to be advised if you approve of including the following items for new residential school buildings:

WHITEFISH LAKE (C.E.A.) - To provide materials towards erection, new school building - $50,000.

A new residential school building is required, to provide accommodation for 50 pupils, at Whitefish Lake (Uteknook Reserve, No. 128) Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta, to replace the present old residential school building at this point, and also the residential school building on the Wabasecon Reserve, No. 166. The present buildings at these points have become unfit for use, are dilapidated and beyond repair and a menace to the health of the pupils. These schools are conducted under the auspices of the Church of England. The erection of a new modern school building will meet the needs at both points and provide school facilities for all pupils of the Anglican faith in the Lesser Slave Lake agency. On account of freighting conditions, it will be necessary to forward the building materials by winter freight, during the winter of 1937-38.

CRONFOOT (R.C.A.) - To erect addition to present building - $50,000.

This school is situated at Cluny, Alberta, on the Blackfoot reserve. His Lordship the Bishop of Calgary has strongly urged that increased accommoda-

The main building of the Old Sun Indian Residential School, on the Blackfoot Indian Reserve, was destroyed by fire in June, 1926.

The Indians, wishing to expedite replacement, petitioned the Department to take from their funds the sum of $80,000.00, which, with $40,000.00 provided by Parliament, enabled the rebuilding to proceed. Approval of the loan was granted by P.C. 307 of January 29th, 1930. It was proposed that the loan should be refunded to the band funds within the next two fiscal years, but no payments have been made. The band funds have not been credited with any interest on the above amount, and it is considered that the amount of the loan should be paid back to the band funds as soon as possible.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have your favor of the 8th and beg to say that Tremont School District No. 1127 built a new school last year without basement. The cost, including heating plant, blackboards and indoor toilets, was $3,097.65. Norwood School District No. 642 built a good school with a basement and this building, including the heating plant, blackboards and indoor toilets, cost $4,195.15. This will give you an idea of the cost of modern one-room schools. In 1937 a couple of districts built two-room schools with full-sized basement and indoor toilets, the cost in each case running a little over $5,000.00.

Decker Consolidated School District built a four-room school with basement a couple of years ago at a cost of $14,000.00. Dugald School District has a three-room school with two rooms upstairs and one in the basement at a cost of about $8,700.00. I think prices today would range a little higher as material seems to have gone up a bit.

Under separate cover I am mailing you copies of our one and two-room schools with basement and beg to say that there will be no charge. At the moment I do not think we have a four-room plan available but if you are anxious for one I can arrange to have blue prints run off at a small cost. We have a very nice four-room school with the four rooms on one floor and full-sized basement.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

R. Fletcher
Deputy Minister.

Memorandum:

DR. MCGILL -

A number of requests have reached this Division during the last two years for the installation of electrical energy at Indian day schools. The pressure exercised upon us to provide this service has become so persistent of late that I feel a definite decision with respect to the matter should be reached by the Minister.

My experience with electric lighting at public schools in Manitoba was somewhat unfortunate. I learned there that the ordinary suspended light in the classroom was not in itself sufficient to provide the light necessary on dull days and was frequently responsible for the creation of shadows. Electric light in a one room day school, in order to be effective and to meet the requests of the specialists who demand perfect lighting facilities, should be provided through several lamps which are, as you know, very costly, particularly where three or four of them are required in a single room. The main objection, however, in the case of Indian schools, is not the number of lamps or the initial cost, although these are substantial. I have learned from experience since coming here that the few schools where electric lighting has been installed - or rather the teachers in charge of these schools - are constantly requesting electrical equipment such as washing machines, electric refrigerators and electric stoves. Last year we were called upon to provide an electric washing machine at Lorette Village and I have just refused a request that reached us yesterday from the Sisters in charge of the school at Pierreville for a fully equipped and rather expensive electric refrigerator.

The Ontario Hydro Commission and private companies who supply electrical energy have refused to install this energy in Indian day schools unless the Government, as owners of the property, guarantees the payment of all charges incurred in connection with the electrical service. I am not personally opposed to the installation of this lighting equipment if the Government is prepared to supply this service. I have never been able to convince myself, however, that it is necessary, and consequently, unless I receive definite instructions to install this equipment from time to time in our Indian day schools, it is not my intention to supply this service. I should appreciate it, therefore, if I could have, at your convenience, a definite ruling on this matter.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
April 26, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Our Regina representative has recently completed an inspection trip to several Indian Residential schools and agencies in Saskatchewan and reports to us as follows:

Round Lake Indian Residential School.

Battery worn out and would recommend immediate replacement. Present battery is 16 cell, 32 volt Globelite type W15, installed August, 1939. The load at this school is far too heavy for a 32 volt plant and should be replaced with 110 volt plant. Would suggest that if another 32 volt battery is purchased, the department install at least a Globelite type W11 of 450 ampere hours.

Marieval School.

Plant and battery in excellent condition. The battery is a Globelite type GDL5, 56 cell, 110 volts, installed February, 1940.

File Hill School.

Supervised the installation of a new Globelite type W15, 16 cell, 32 volt battery. Here again the load is far too heavy for a 32 volt plant and strongly recommend that same be replaced with a 110 volt plant.

WESTERN CANADA'S LARGEST BATTERY MANUFACTURERS
File Hills Indian Agency.

Battery and plant in good condition. Battery consists of a Globelite type W13, 16 cells, 52 volts, installed September, 1940.

Muscow Indian Agency.

Battery in very poor shape. The battery and plant has been sadly neglected. Battery consists of Globelite type W12, 56 cells, 110 volts, installed November, 1928.

We might advise that in regards to the equipment at Muscow Indian Agency, the writer inspected the plant and battery some years ago and also found same to be in a very badly neglected condition. The battery cells were covered with dirt to such an extent that the elements were not even visible through the glass jars. The writer pointed this out to the operator of the plant and instructed the operator to get the battery cleaned up and to pay a little more attention to the charging of the battery and further; the operator was advised that a report would go into the government respecting the condition the plant and battery was found in. Although this matter was not reported to your department, nevertheless, it was reported to your late Mr. Robertson who was in charge of your Regina office.

Trusting that this inspection report will be of some interest to you, we remain,

Memorandum:

Equipment for Residential Schools - Hand Potato Peelers.

I have today had a visit from Mr. Whittle of the Hobart Manufacturing Company, who specialize in the construction of kitchen machines.

We had a thorough discussion on the use of hand potato peelers, both in civilian establishments and their projected use in our residential schools. Mr. Whittle pointed out that the Hobart Company no longer manufactures a hand potato peeler, for the following reasons:

(a) A mechanical peeler does the work of three hand peelers.

(b) A hand peeler is made with cast iron gears and is without ball bearings. This makes it a very difficult machine to operate. In fact, it would be almost impossible for children or school age to turn the handle.

(c) The Canadian Army discarded the use of such hand peelers after using them for about a year. They found that these machines did not stand up to the heavy usage which they were given and, in general, proved unsatisfactory. They adopted, eventually, the mechanical peeler.

Mr. Whittle has recently been discharged from the Canadian Army, in which he served as Chief Equipment Officer with the Royal Canadian Army Service Corps Catering Branch. Therefore, I feel that his recommendations can be taken as

Dear Sir:

Enclosed are 2 blueprints of the one roomed school which we showed you a few days ago and we believe this will meet the requirements of your department for this type of school in various parts of British Columbia.

This would have a number of advantages. Namely, cost of erection would be less, general appearance improved and 2' extra head room in the basement in that portion of the building beneath the living quarters.

The f.o.b. Factory price for this building including all items as shown in the specifications would be $5850.00. Approximate shipping weight 55,000 lbs. You will note that we have included in the specifications Ten/Tent for wall coverings. If gyproc is required a reduction of $73.00 from the above price can be made.

We trust the enclosed blueprint and specifications will be sufficient information for you to forward on to Ottawa for their okay.

Re: School Construction Program - B.C.

Further to my letter of April 8th, I have now received from Prefabricated Structures, Vancouver, plans and specifications of a one-room school with teacher's residence, copies of which are attached hereto, together with a letter dated April 8th from the Company giving further details and quoting a price. Plans and specifications for a two-room school with accommodation for teachers will be supplied by the Company after we receive the proposed plans for the Anaham school, reference Mr. Neary's army signals message of today, which will serve as a basis for the preparation of plans for a prefabricated structure. The one-room school with teacherage, as shown and described in the attached enclosures, is in my opinion most suitable to our needs in British Columbia and should, I believe, be adopted wherever we contemplate a building of this size. In my letter of January 9th I listed the preferred order of work for the first six school construction projects as follows:

(1) Metlakatla - The information we now have, and which we have asked the Agent to confirm, is to the effect that a two-room school is necessary here and it has been suggested that we should also provide accommodation for teachers. This matter is presently the subject of correspondence with Mr. Anfield as the need for additional accommodation for teachers is not apparent having in mind the large expenditure recently made on the present teacherage and its size which should provide ample accommodation for two teachers, either married or single.

I might mention that in early February Mr. Anfield submitted tenders covering the transfer and re-erection of two Loxstave buildings from Pillsbury Cove to Metlakatla for school use and he has been requested to advise if these tenders still stand in which case they will be referred to the Department, or otherwise we may, if the
Prefabricated Structures' plan of a two-room school is considered suitable, recommend the provision of prefabricated buildings.

(2) Klemtu - I would recommend that the Department approve the use of a prefabricated building to provide one classroom and teacherage at this point; the order to be placed as soon as possible and the necessary work preliminary to erection of the building to be carried out at once. It appears that Prefabricated Structures have agreed to provide a foreman and one or two carpenters at hourly rates to superintend erection of the prefabricated building and it is possible that we might arrange with them for the use of this crew for the construction of foundations.

(3) Bella Bella - Although we have already purchased a building at the Bella Bella Air Base from the War Assets Corporation, information received from the Lands and Development Services Branch indicates that use of this building for school purposes may not be feasible or economical. On receipt of the two-room school plan with teacherages above referred to and providing it is suitable it is intended to recommend use of a prefabricated structure of this size at Bella Bella.

(4) Seabird Island - Construction of a one-room school with teacherage at Seabird Island has been the subject of correspondence between Mr. Indian Agent Strang and the Department and I note the matter has proceeded to the point where Mr. Strang has secured a tender of $4,300 for labour, the Department to provide materials for the construction in accordance with the Department's one-room school plan. In spite of the progress made in arranging for the construction of a school at this point I feel the Department would be well advised to consider the use of a prefabricated structure and would so recommend.

(5) Pemberton - While the information available a year ago indicated that we should have a one-room addition to the Pemberton School with accommodation for an additional teacher, District School Inspector Davey is of the opinion that our requirements at this point should be investigated further before construction is proceeded with or even definite plans made. While the construction here should no doubt be carried out this year if found to be absolutely necessary, no action is indicated until a school survey has been completed.
(b) Hazelton - Construction at Hazelton was the subject of correspondence with you, reference my letter of March 24th, at which time I recommended construction of a four-classroom school for the reason that it would be better to construct a school somewhat too large than to be confronted with overcrowded conditions immediately upon completion of construction.

We will, in addition to the four classrooms at this point, require accommodation for teachers as it is doubtful if we can count on securing accommodation for them in the adjoining town of Hazelton. I do not feel, however, that the Department should proceed immediately to construct teacherages for three or four teachers, one or more of whom might be married. I feel it would be preferable this year to construct a five-room residence for the Principal and in the event that the Principal is unmarried the other teachers might be accommodated in the same building. I would recommend that the Department call for tenders covering the construction of a four-room school with manual training room and domestic science room in the basement and that authority be secured for the purchase and erection of a five-room prefabricated house to accommodate the teachers.

Chehalis - New Westminster Agency (one classroom only. There is a teacherage available).

PERSONAL:

Dear Bill:

On Friday last Charlie Buck and I went with Emmett Morris to thoroughly inspect the new Chenail School. As you know, this is the two room school built to the plan sent you recently. We found the building entirely satisfactory and the contractor has done a very good job. Mr. Morris was particularly interested in the minor modifications which can be made in the plan so that he can make these minor improvements at Lennox Island. I would say that the following minor details are ones on which improvements can be made:

(1) If steel beams are obtainable, then the posts in the basement can be eliminated and you will find that the two basement rooms will be much better for future classroom use.

(2) The windows in the kitchen and living room downstairs are rather small and Mr. Buck is going to improve them (this will take some time as they are absolutely swamped with work).

(3) The stairs from the teacher's living quarters can be straightened out to remove the landing. This will allow more space in the living room and also will give you to take furniture upstairs more easily. The contractor has been able to do this at Chenail by putting in fourteen steps and raising them to 6" apart.
The classrooms are just perfect and I am sure that Bob Davey will be very pleased with them. Of course, we installed flush toilets, running water and electricity at Chenail as a result we have a very modern and satisfactory school.

I was discussing the situation with Mr. Buck on the way home and we agreed that perhaps you would like to look at another two room school plan which has been especially developed for the Northwest Territories. There we can not put in a basement because of the perma-frost. The attached blue print is only a preliminary drawing and changes will be made. I brought to the Architect's attention the fact that the fenestration is not sufficient for our needs. This is due to the fact that Mr. McKinnon specifically asked for folding doors between the two classrooms so that it could be used as a community hall. This meant that they were unable to work in windows along the other side wall. However, I would ask you to look it over and let me have it back. If you feel that it would be better for your needs at Anaham and Hazelton then I can arrange to have you sent the final plans.

I hope everything is going well with Mrs. Arneil and yourself and that you are both finding Vancouver to your liking. As you probably know I have had Betty out visiting my people in Victoria and she is now on her way home.

As ever,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. W. S. Avisil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

School Construction Program, British Columbia.

Reference your 0-11-3 of April 15 -

Upon receipt of your letter and attached plans of one-room school, etc., these blueprints and specifications were taken over to the Lands and Development Services Branch. Study has been given by them to the submissions of Prefabricated Structures, Limited, and as I advised you, I interviewed Mr. Buck yesterday concerning the plans.

As you are probably aware, Mr. Buck feels that these prefabricated schools will not be as satisfactory in the long run as buildings constructed in the usual way. However, he realizes our serious need for these schools and the impossibility of having them built by contractors. Therefore he concurs with the proposal that we order a certain number of these schools. I have asked that one of their engineers be made available for inspection of these buildings so that our 1949-50 building plans can be laid accordingly.

Mr. Buck feels that the Prefabricated Structures Limited's plans and specifications present certain features which are superior to similar plans and specifications presented by other prefabricated manufacturing concerns.

There are a few points with regard to the construction of prefabricated buildings which we would like to draw to your attention:
FOUNDATIONS:

It is most important that the basement be put in according to the detailed specifications of the company providing the prefabricated building. The structure must fit the foundation exactly or outside air will penetrate the basement and the building will always have a cold floor. To doubly insure against this point, we are having the prefabricated schools ordered for Northern Manitoba provided with a floor insulated between the joists. While this may not be necessary in the Great schools, you may consider it necessary for the interior schools, where winter weather is severe.

Mr. Buck recommends that we try to interest Prefabricated Structures, Limited, in providing a foreman and one or two carpenters who could superintend the construction of foundations and also the erection of the building. If previous arrangements were made to have the excavation done, the cement and rough form lumber on hand and Indian labour available, this crew could do the job in a short time. It would be necessary to maintain constant liaison with the company to ensure that the prefabricated structures were on hand by the time the crew has the foundation finished. It would also be necessary for the Prefabricated Structures Limited to advise you as to the amount of cement, lumber, nails, etc., necessary so that these materials would be on hand when the construction crew arrived to begin work.

FLOOR AND SIDING:

You may find it necessary to have the construction crew also lay the floor and put on the cedar siding unless local carpenters are available.

CHIMNEY:

Here again it will be necessary to arrange for a bricklayer and a supply of bricks if a brick chimney is to be provided. In our Northern Manitoba prefabricated schools we are specifying a Yukon special insulated metal chimney.

....... Building
BUILDING SPAN:

We would prefer the 56' span as described in para 3 of Mr. MacKay's letter to you of April 8. The extra head room in the basement will make it possible to use it for an extra classroom if need arises.

INSULATION:

The substitution of Gyproc for Ten-test (Mr. MacKay's letter of April 8) depends on the location of the building. We are using Gyproc in our standard one-room school specifications but are insulating well behind it. You will note on the attached copy of Purchase Order (used with North American Buildings, Limited, for Little Grand Rapids, Man.) that we specified rock wool or other non-inflammable insulation. This may also be necessary for the interior of B.C.

WATER SUPPLY and PLUMBING:

The water supply will present a problem on most reserves where it will be necessary to dig a well before the school is built. We are suggesting to Agents building schools under local arrangements that the well be located just outside the building and that the pump be placed in the teacher's kitchen over the sink. Some prefer to leave the pump outside and to have teachers draw the water there. However, local conditions will govern procedure in each case. The bath-room provided will probably end up being used as a utility room or extra bedroom, as in most areas running water will not be available. We have been providing chemical closets for the teachers' use in certain areas.

HEATING:

It will also be necessary to arrange for a subcontract for the installation of the furnace. It is presumed that Prefabricated Structures Limited will provide a heating plan for the building and also recommend the size of furnace to be provided. You will note that North American Buildings Limited will provide the furnace as an extra to the contract.

ROOF:

We are endeavouring to provide some degree of fire protection in our new schools. We would prefer the supplying of
asbestos or other fire resistant shingles. The cost will be more than for cedar shingles and we should be advised as to the extra cost. You will also have to arrange locally for the putting on of the roof.

PAINTING: You will have to arrange for the purchase of the paint required for both the interior and exterior. Prefabricated Structures may supply the information as to the quantities provided or it can be obtained from our standard one-room school bill of materials. It will also be necessary to have this painting done.

To summarize, we have found out from past experience this last year that while prefabricated buildings do provide an answer, they are not as easy to arrange for erection as it would at first seem. You are provided with the shell of a building but you have to arrange locally for:

(a) The excavation and foundation,
(b) The brick work,
(c) The laying of the floor,
(d) The laying of the siding, etc.
(e) The laying of the roofing,
(f) The digging of the well,
(g) The installation of the pump,
(h) The installation of the furnace,
(i) The painting.

In other words your local field official will have many administrative problems in connection with the erection of the school.

However, we are not trying to discourage the ordering of these prefabricated schools but merely wish to point out the problems encountered by other field officials so that you can be guided by their experience. You will find that the total cost will add up to very close to the amount included in the estimates for a one-room school ($14,000.00).
ONE-ROOM SCHOOLS TO BE ORDERED:

A review of your letter would indicate that it is recommended that we order the following schools (a wire has already been sent re Seabird Island):

1. Klantu
2. Redstone
3. Neskaalinith
4. North Thompson
5. Stony Creek
6. Kitmancool.

(based on priority Major Davey's list January 8).

All of the above are included in our estimates with the exception of Kitmancool (for which a transfer would have to be arranged). We are prepared to recommend the ordering of the above six buildings from Prefabricated Structures, Limited. This, with Seabird Island, will provide seven new one-room schools. We can then decide in June if sufficient money is left over for others to be ordered. The Hazelton school in particular is likely to cost more than the $40,000.00 provided (a separate letter will be sent re this school).

TWO-ROOM SCHOOLS:

We will await further developments re these plans.

TEACHERAGE

Could we be advised as to the cost of providing Model F plan for the Skidgate school for use as a teacherage? This should provide satisfactory accommodation for two teachers.

Enc.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

The substitution of Gyproc for Ten-test (Mr. Mackay's letter of April 8) depends on the location of the building. We are using Gyproc in our standard one-room school specifications but are insulating all behind it. You will note on the attached copy of Purchase Order (used with North American Buildings Limited, for Little Grand Rapids, Man.) that we specified rock wool or other non-inflammable insulation. This may also be necessary for the interior of B.C.

WATER SUPPLY and PLUMBING:

The water supply will present a problem on most reserves where it will be necessary to dig a well before the school is built. We are suggesting to Agents building schools under local arrangements that the well be located just outside the building and that the pump be placed in the teacher's kitchen over the sink. Some prefer to leave the pump outside and to have teachers draw the water there. However, local conditions will govern procedure in each case. The bath-room provided will probably end up being used as a utility room or extra bedroom, as in most areas running water will not be available. We have been providing chemical closets for the teachers' use in certain areas.

HEATING:

It will also be necessary to arrange for a subcontract for the installation of the furnace. It is presumed that Prefabricated Structures Limited will provide a heating plan for the building and also recommend the size of furnace to be provided. You will note that North American Buildings Limited will provide the furnace as an extra to the contract.

ROOF:

We are endeavouring to provide some degree of fire protection in our new schools. We would prefer the supplying of
asbestos or other fire resistant shingles. The cost will be more than for cedar shingles and we should be advised as to the extra cost. You will also have to arrange locally for the putting on of the roof.

PAINTING: You will have to arrange for the purchase of the paint required for both the interior and exterior. Prefabricated Structures may supply the information as to the quantities provided or it can be obtained from our standard one-room school bill of materials. It will also be necessary to have this painting done.

To summarize, we have found out from past experience this last year that while prefabricated buildings do provide an answer, they are not as easy to arrange for erection as it would at first seem. You are provided with the shell of a building but you have to arrange locally for:

(a) The excavation and foundation,
(b) The brick work,
(c) The laying of the floor,
(d) The laying of the siding, etc.
(e) The laying of the roofing,
(f) The digging of the well,
(g) The installation of the pump,
(h) The installation of the furnace,
(i) The painting.

In other words your local field official will have many administrative problems in connection with the erection of the school.

However, we are not trying to discourage the ordering of these prefabricated schools but merely wish to point out the problems encountered by other field officials so that you can be guided by their experience. You will find that the total cost will add up to very close to the amount included in the estimates for a one-room school ($14,000.00).
ONE-ROOM SCHOOLS TO BE ORDERED:

A review of your letter would indicate that it is recommended that we order the following schools (a wire has already been sent re Seabird Island):

1. Klastu
2. Redstone
3. Neakainith
4. North Thompson
5. Stony Creek
6. Kitwancool.

(based on priority Major Davey's list January 8).

All of the above are included in our estimates with the exception of Kitwancool (for which a transfer would have to be arranged). We are prepared to recommend the ordering of the above six buildings from Prefabricated Structures, Limited. This, with Seabird Island, will provide seven new one-room schools. We can then decide in June if sufficient money is left over for others to be ordered. The Hamilton school in particular is likely to cost more than the $40,000.00 provided (a separate letter will be sent re this school).

TWO-ROOM SCHOOLS:

We will await further developments re these plans.

TEACHERAGE

Could we be advised as to the cost of providing Model F plan for the Skidegate school for use as a teachersage? This should provide satisfactory accommodation for two teachers.

Encl.

Bernard F. Neary,

I am enclosing confirmation of my Army Signals message of today's date in connection with school construction. Tentative arrangements have been made with the Agents concerned for construction of schools at Redstone, Klemtu, Stony Creek and Neskainlith and I do not anticipate any great difficulty in having the buildings completed at these points.

In view of this it is considered that construction at the North Thompson Reserve should be left in abeyance pending the revision of the Indian Act and careful consideration of the problem of the joint education of white and Indian children.

We are in a position, therefore, of having funds for two additional one-room schools, a total of $28,000, and having carefully considered all our requirements and provision made for schools of more than one room, reference Mr. Neery's letter of June 21st, I would recommend:

Memorandum:

MR. G. HICKS,
Lands and Development Services Branch.

Educational Plans - Western Provinces and Northwest Territories.

I understand that you have been requested to prepare a brief summary, for our Minister, of the school building program for the Western Provinces and the Northwest Territories.

In British Columbia, we have now an order or under construction 6 one-room Indian day schools and 2 two-room Indian day schools. Some of these buildings are prefabricated ones. We have also completed the conversion of army buildings into day schools in the Alert Bay Agency and classes are now being conducted in these buildings.

In Alberta, we have completed the day schools at Michel and Stony Plain, near Edmonton. Contracts have recently been let for a two-room day school at Smokey and a one-room day school on Alexander's Reserve, near Edmonton. Air Force buildings were moved and set up on permanent foundations to provide extra classroom blocks at the St. Paul's and Blood Residential Schools near Cardston, Alberta.

In Saskatchewan, the Nut Lake and Pearson Indian Day Schools are nearing completion. A contract has recently been let for another day school on the Meadow Lake Indian Reserve.

In Manitoba, day schools are under construction or have been completed on the following reserves: Valley River, Nelson House, Little Grand Rapids, Peguis, Fisher River, Oak River, Island Lake and Cross Lake.
In the Northwest Territories, two-room day schools are nearing completion at Fort Norman and Moosel River. A four-room day school is being erected at Hay River.

In addition to the above new schools, we have been able to open several temporary classrooms in rented church buildings and halls. In this way we have managed to provide educational facilities for some 300 Indian children for whom we were unable to provide educational facilities previously.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter of November 1st concerning the provision of school facilities at Old Fort in the Babine Agency as included on our priority list submitted to the Department some time ago.

This point is located on Babine Lake about 30 miles S.E. of Fort Babine. A school survey indicates that there are 79 children 16 years of age and under at this point. Of this number 46 are in the age group 6 to 16. The pre-school age population is 33. Although the number of school age children would appear to warrant the construction of a two room school, due to the nomadic life of many of the families it is felt that a one room would probably meet the actual need.

I might say that a school was operated at this point up until March of 1940 when the present teacher at Fort Babine was transferred from Old Fort. At the time of his transfer there were 23 pupils enrolled in the Old Fort School, with an average attendance of 11.3. The school apparently remained closed, partly because of the acute teacher shortage.

The building in use was an old structure rented from one of the natives belonging to the reserve. It is quite unsuitable for school purposes and is in very poor repair.

Re: SCHOOLS, Fort Ware, Shelley, & Nazko I.R.

Your file No. 14-11-3

I have your letter of November 3rd, 1948, inquiring as to the advisability of establishing Day Schools at the above mentioned Reserves. In reply I beg to advise as follows:

FORT WARE I.R.

Due to the remoteness of this Reserve and the nomadic tendencies of the population, a Day School would be very impracticable. The Right Reverend Anthony Jordan indicated last summer on our visit to this Reserve, that he intended to establish a Missionary at Fort Ware during the summer and his services may be utilized as a Teacher for a 3 months Seasonal term, if required. If this materializes, I intend to recommend opening a Seasonal School at this point.

FORT GEORGE I.R. (SHELLEY)

There are only 8 children of school age on this Reserve, 5 of which are attending the Lejac Residential School. A Day School is out of the question for this small group.

NAZKO I.R.

This Reserve is also located in a very remote area and the people lead a nomadic life. At present, there about 20 children of School age, 12 of which attend the Caribou Residential School. This number does not include children from Echimico and Kluskul Bands, who reside about 35 miles away from the Nazko I.R., and who would not benefit by a School established at the Nazko I.R. I do not think that these conditions warrant the erection of a Day School.

M. Howe,
Superintendent.

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of April 29th, due to a change in management personnel at Prefabricated Structures Limited we have experienced some delay in securing an acceptable plan for a two-room school with teachers' attached but anticipate that we will be in a position to submit plans, specifications and quotations within the next few days.

With regard to the six one-room schools listed in your letter it is noted that the Department is prepared to recommend ordering six buildings from Prefabricated Structures Ltd., and it is presumed that we will be advised in due course if the recommendation is approved. In my letter of April 15th I made a definite recommendation that prefabricated buildings from Prefabricated Structures be used at the six points mentioned and although we are most anxious to have the construction program proceeded with it is not seen that this office can do anything to further the matter at the moment.

Indian School Construction Projects 1949-50 Fiscal Year.

The Estimates for 1949-50 have been approved by Treasury Board, and we are in a position to advise you concerning our plans for erecting day schools in your region. Please find attached a list of the projects and amounts by agencies. Will you kindly, therefore, inform the superintendents concerning these items. We have been in correspondence concerning certain of these projects previously and have discussed some of them with you. You will find attached an information report which I would like to have completed and returned on each project which you would wish to have proceeded with immediately. If there are any projects which you wish to have delayed or wish to have transfers arranged, we would appreciate hearing from you.

Authority for Undertaking Construction

In writing to superintendents, please stress the fact that in giving them this information it is not to be interpreted to mean that this is authority for them to undertake any of the work or purchase any materials or equipment. Authority to proceed with work or incur any expenditure will be given by a letter of instruction from this Division and a financial encumbrance number to be quoted on all vouchers, accounts, etc. Until the financial encumbrance number is issued to them, they are not to undertake the work.

Information Reports

These information reports have been prepared so that there will be no misunderstanding between field officials and Departmental officials concerning each project. They
provide essential facts for our files and also indicate to field officials the procedure for carrying out a project. We would ask that they be completed by the Indian Superintendents concerned in quadruplicate; with two copies to be sent here, one to your office and one for the superintendent's office.

In writing to your superintendents would you please draw to their attention the following facts concerning these information reports:

(1) Item 3 - Day School Plans

We have standardized our plans as much as is possible, and the main types are as follows:

One-Room Schools with Attached Teacherages

(a) Plan No. 832 -

This is a one-room school with attached teacher's residence and a full basement. It is furnace-heated and is the same type of school previously erected at Seabird Island. Unfortunately, the cost of erecting this type of school has risen until it now requires an expenditure of between $18,000.00 and $20,000.00 to complete it. We feel that this is too high a cost for a one-room school.

(b) Plan No. 888 -

This is the plan discussed at our recent meeting in Ottawa. Our architects have recently completed the drafts including the changes recommended at the Regional Supervisors Conference. You will note that a sheet has been added providing for combined storage and outdoor toilets shed. This school does not have a basement and is heated by stoves. This is the plan we intend to follow for most of our one-room schools required in 1949-50. We hope it can be erected
at a sum considerably lower than that required for Plan No. 837.

(c) **Plan No. 865**

This is an adaptation of Plan No. 837 and provides for the installation of electricity and running water. It is planned for reserves on which Hydro is available near the school site.

**One-Room Schools**

**Plan No. 890**

This is a one-room school where a teacherage is not required. Copies can be obtained by writing here.

**Two-Room Schools with Attached Teacherages**

(a) **Plan No. 889**

This is for a two-room school with attached teacher's residence. It has a full basement with Manual Training and Domestic Science rooms and is furnace-heated. It is similar to the Anaham School.

(b) **Plan No. 891**

This is an adaptation of Plan No. 889 and provides electricity and running water. It is designed for reserves where Hydro is available close to the site of the school.

**Two-Room School**

**Plan No. 738**

This is for a two-room school without a teacher's residence. It has a full basement and is furnace-heated.
(2) Item 4 - Method of Construction

(a) Day Labour -

If a suitable foreman carpenter is available, we have found that this method of construction is quite satisfactory providing close supervision is maintained to ensure that the job does not take too long. Indians can be employed and they are able thus to learn building and carpentering techniques.

(b) Prefabrication -

This matter was thoroughly discussed at the Regional Supervisors Conference, and as you know, we will be experimenting with a prefabricated steel building this Spring. Additional information can be provided if you so desire.

(c) Contract -

While in the past we have been able to approach contractors directly, this will be the exception this year. It is our intention to advertise, and we would appreciate your advice in each case on the projects for which we should advertise immediately.

(d) Supervision -

Day labour construction of course entails supervision by the superintendent concerned. Contract construction also require supervision by the superintendent concerned, but we can call on the Engineering and Construction Division for any assistance required in either the siting or the erection of the building.

(3) Item 5 - Bills of Material

If the project is to be erected by day labour, we have available bills of materials for most of the above school types. Superintendents concerned can make application for these, and the Departmental Purchasing Agent is prepared to fill requirements as the information in Items 5 and 8 are provided.
(4) Items 9, 10 and 11 - Essential Services

Under no circumstances will a construction project be commenced until we are assured of a steady supply of water. We have today too many day schools to which water has to be transported and wish every precaution taken to avoid this in future.

The availability of Hydro in the vicinity of the school will naturally determine the type of building to be erected. Individual attention will have to be given to each project in this regard.

It is not our intention to provide oil furnaces or stoves unless wood is not immediately available.

(5) Item 12 - Title to School Site

Instruction as to procedure in securing title can be obtained from the Reserves and Trusts Division.

(6) Items 9 and 13 - Selection of Site

The three main factors in selecting the school site are:

(a) Proximity to main pupil supply -

(The standard ruling is that children under 10 years of age can be expected to walk up to two miles each way daily, and children of 10 can be expected to walk up to three miles.)

(b) Water Supply -

See (4) above.

(c) General Suitability -

This includes playground space (approximately an acre), nearness to roads, and last but not least, Elevation. A school must be located on a site sufficiently high to prevent any basement flooding or
water in the playground. Remember that the school will be standing for a good many years and that a careful decision now may save years of trouble later for the superintendent and his successors.

(7) Item 14 - Orientation

Our architects have carefully designed a classroom with maximum window space. Please do not orient the school so that these windows are wasted. They are meant to face in a southerly direction. We also ask that the school be situated sufficiently far from trees which might spoil this window space.

To summarize, therefore, we would like to have your entire building program under way by April or May so that the schools can be finished and we can avoid rushing projects in September and October. By presenting this information to your superintendents early, we hope that we are helping them to build as many of these schools as possible this Spring and Summer.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: School Construction Program

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of April 22nd, if it is imperative we advertise for tenders for the construction of two-room schools (Building No. 889) at Greenville, Kincolith and Hartley Bay, may I suggest that tenders be advertised for immediately so that in the event no bids are received we may still have time to carry out the erection of a prefabricated building if such is permitted. Hartley Bay Indian Day School

Lincoln Indian Day School

Specifications for One & Two Room Schools
With Attached Teacherage

1. **FRAME** - Good grade Pacific Coast Fir, Hemlock or Cedar especially selected for the purpose for which it is to be used. All material is accurately machined and code marked for identification. Fully illustrated erection procedure, blueprints and checking lists are provided.

2. **FOUNDATION** - These buildings are designed for a full basement. 2x6 beams are supplied with 6x6 and 6x8 posts, this gives a joist span of 8' centre to centre. Concrete is not supplied. Materials for forms (shiplap and 2x4) can be supplied at extra cost.

3. **BASEMENT** - Basement sash, doors, stairs, beams and posts are supplied.

4. **FLOOR** - 2x10 floor joists are supplied to be placed 16" on centre. 2x10 box sill and bridging are supplied. Shiplap subfloor is supplied in random lengths to be laid diagonally. 2x8 joists 16" on centre are supplied for teacherage.

5. **WALLS** - Walls consist of Multi-Flex sections. These sections are 4x10 and 6x10 for the school building and 2x8 to 12 x8 for the teacherage. Each section is faced with tongue and groove centre match lumber with building paper between studs and sheathing. Between each section a 4x4 pilaster is placed. These pilasters are grooved to receive tongue on outer stud of wall section. Top and bottom plates are dadoed to receive pilasters. This method of construction ensures a tight and well constructed wall. Windows are fitted in frames complete with sash balances and hardware. Outside doors are hung in frames and equipped with locks.

6. **ROOF** - Roof is of trussed construction with 2x6 ceiling joists and 2x4 rafters placed 16" on centre making a self supporting roof independent of partitions. Roof boards are cut to lengths. Wood gutter and V joint soffit are supplied in random lengths. Cedar or 16 lb. Bureau type shingles are supplied (heavier patent shingles can be supplied at extra cost).

7. **INTERIOR** - All studding is supplied cut to length. Partition plates are supplied random. Interior door frames are machined ready for assembly. Ten/Test wallboard is supplied throughout with sufficient 1/8" masonite or 1/4" P.V. hardboard for 4' high in classrooms and halls. Inside casing cut to length and mitred. Base and floor mould are supplied. Finish floor is 1 x 4 V.G. Fir throughout except kitchen and bathroom in teacherage which is flat grain.

8. **CABINETS** - Kitchen cabinets, ironing board and medicine cabinet are supplied for teacherage.

9. **EXTERIOR** - Choice of 2x8 clear cedar bevel siding, 3/4x8 or 3/4x10 Common cedar bungalow siding, 1 1/2x10 Dolly Warden pattern Common cedar siding or Capilano Cedarwall shingles for exterior walls at quoted price.

10. **HARDWARE** - All necessary locksets, hinges, sash fasteners and sash balances are supplied. Also all nails necessary for erection. Flashing for chimney is included.

11. **INSULATION AND PAPER** - 2" rock wool batts or equivalent insulation is supplied, also building paper for floors and outer walls.

12. **BLACKBOARD** - Material for blackboards with necessary mouldings are supplied.

13. Front and rear steps as shown on blueprint are included.

NOT SUPPLIED: Concrete, brick work, plumbing, electrical or heating equipment or paint.

Re: New School Programme - Kincolith, Greenville
and Hartley Bay, Skeena River Agency.

The Department has recently erected a one-room school by contract at Metlakatla, B.C. This building is a multi-flex unit with teachers' attached. Careful inspection of the completed unit (now painted and ready for occupancy on September 6th, 1949) shows that with minor adjustments by the contractor we have a practical and useful school unit. I am satisfied that it will serve well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, J. Sherrill at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teachers' attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay.

I have approached Messrs. Mitchell and Currie, Greer and Bridgen, both contracting firms of Prince Rupert and they refuse to bid on the construction of new schools at these three points, giving isolation of location and risk re transportation as the main reasons. These and other contractors in Prince Rupert have so much other work on hand that they are just not interested.

It is my firm conviction that these prefabricated schools will have to be erected by day labour and that with competent foremen available they can go up this winter. I have two top flight building foremen available for this work who are
prepared to work right through the winter on the construction of these three schools. They are presently employed at Cellulose Corporation at Port Edward but will be available when required. They will expect charges hereon on an annual scale for R.C. Arrangements have been completed for living accommodation for those men and two other badly Indian carpenters in each of these villages, as required. Storage facilities for material on all three jobs have been completed.

Full basements will be required for all three schools referred to herein. The weather is predominantly wet in the Skeena River Agency. Basements beneath classrooms will be required for playrooms and those under the teachersages for furnaces and storerooms.

Excavation required for each school will be (all sites are fairly level) based on average depth of 4 feet.

Recapitulation of costs will be approximately as follows:

(1) Foundation as listed herein $5,000.00

(2) Purchase of multi-flex bldg., f.o.b. Vancouver 10,000.00

(3) Freight on building to sites 2 (includes steamship freight and cost of transportation up river and unloading material to school site) 4,000.00
(4) Erection of building on foundation (labour cost only) $5,000.00

(5) Furnace, installed 2,000.00

(7) Lighting plant 2½ KW - to handle lights and water pump 856.00

Estimated total cost - less furnishings and equipment for classrooms and teachersage........ $32,506.00

It is recommended that this work be proceeded with on this basis: That the buildings be purchased forthwith and instructions issued to proceed with labour on foundations. Cement, lumber, nails and wire can be purchased from either Philpott-Evitt or Albert and McCaffery, both of Prince Rupert, B.C.

It will be essential that a gasoline driven concrete mixer be supplied. This might come from the Welfare Vote and be made available for the housing programme.

The job would be speeded up immensely if a jeep with platform trailer could be supplied. This equipment could be used (if equipped with power take off) for hauling all equipment in a dragline to excavation end as a hoist on the job. It could also move all gravel and material to the site.

The need for these three schools is desperate, especially Kincolith and Greenville where present buildings are actually unsafe for use. The Department's instructions will be appreciated.
