Re: Kincolith, Hartley Bay, Lakalsap and Fort Babine Schools

October 6th, 1949

We are greatly disappointed at not receiving a reply to our letter of September 6th wherein the erection of two-room prefabricated schools at the above mentioned points in the Skeena River Agency was recommended, particularly as it is only a matter of weeks until winter conditions will prohibit construction of any kind at these points.

In order to strengthen our submission covering the purchase and erection of prefabricated schools, District School Inspector Davey and Mr. Webster visited the new two-room school at Pemberton and secured photographs of the building, enlargements of which are attached. They found that the accommodation provided by this building was all that could be desired; that it was most substantially constructed and with one or two very minor changes to provide built-in storage space, was practically ideal. As a matter of fact Mr. Davey, who has only just returned from a visit to the new school at Anaham, is of the opinion that improvements such as those provided convenience of access to the various parts of the building, and appearance, the prefabricated two classroom building with teacherage is preferable to the Department's standard building. With regard to comparative costs of the two buildings, while our figures may not be absolutely accurate they are correct to within two or three hundred dollars, and it is apparent that the building at Anaham cost the Department approximately $35,000 including the lighting plant, whereas the building at Pemberton, including the lighting plant, cost the Department
approximately $26,500, a saving of $8,500.

It would appear to me that the Department cannot afford to miss the opportunity of erecting schools at the three points mentioned in the Skeena River Agency this fall and that further we should take advantage of the funds available to purchase now the prefabricated school for erection at Fort Babine next summer. As an indication of the progress made by Supt. Anfield in arranging for the erection of the three schools in his Agency I am enclosing an exchange of Army Signals messages which we have had with him; also his letter of September 27th and enclosures referred to therein. In connection with this exchange I may say that although the erection of prefabricated schools in Mr. Anfield's agency was discussed with him when he was in Vancouver recently, no authority was given to him to proceed beyond clearing of the school sites. This is emphasized in my Signals of October 4th to him.

There would appear to be no additional information which this office can provide with a view to influencing the Department's decision and consequently we have no alternative but to leave the matter in abeyance until instructions are received.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

P.S. Since the above was written Mr. Davey has brought to my attention the fact that over thirty additional classrooms will be required next year and that construction to date this year will not even meet the needs of the natural increase in the Indian population.

I would strongly urge the purchase and erection of prefabricated schools at the four points above mentioned which will reduce the number required and place us in a better position next year insofar as meeting our school construction requirements is concerned.
Mr. W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

October 15, 1949.

To: Regional Supervisors and Indian Commissioner.

DAY SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION PROGRAM - 1950-51.

As you are aware, we will shortly be preparing our estimates for the 1950-51 fiscal year. As usual, we intend to concentrate on the erection of our main requirements, namely one and two-room schools.

We have already received from Mr. Ostrander the outline of his projected building program in Saskatchewan. It would be appreciated if you would forward similar outlines for your regions.

In British Columbia Inspector Innes will of course be able to provide an outline of requirements, to conduct educational surveys and to assist with site selections. In the other districts we cannot make any definite report as to the progress being made concerning Departmental school inspectors. Major Clark is on the road in the three Prairie Provinces now and will be available for use as required by the Regional Supervisors concerned.

One-room Day Schools.

We appreciate the limitations of plan No. 386. While it provides a very satisfactory classroom, it has to be heated by a stove or space heater located in the classroom and a small heater has also to be provided in the teacher's residence. We are requesting the Departmental Architects to modify this plan somewhat by providing a sub-basement in which a small furnace can be provided.
to heat both the classroom and the teacher's residence. As soon as these plans are finished a copy will be sent to you for study.

In addition to the above type of one-room school we are also requesting the Architects to provide a new version of a one-room school building for reserves on which electricity is available and where running water can be installed. You can therefore anticipate the provision of plans for the following types of one-room schools:

(a) where electricity is not available,

(b) where electricity is available and running water can be provided.

Two-room Schools.

Our recent experience in advertising for tenders in British Columbia has convinced us that the two-room school plans will also have to be modified very considerably. We are requesting the Architects to provide a two-room school without a full basement. A small sub-basement will be located centrally in which a furnace can be installed to heat both classrooms and teachersage.

As in the case of one-room schools, two types of two-room schools will be provided:

(a) where electricity is not available,

(b) where electricity is available and running water can be provided.

Information Report.

It is our intention to use these information reports again this year as they provided a valuable source of information during the present fiscal year. We were able to avoid a great deal of unnecessary correspondence by reference to these reports.
SUMMARY.

It is requested that the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia and the Regional Supervisors for Alberta and Manitoba provide the Education Division with a list of their requirements in one and two room schools for the 1950-51 fiscal year. Many requests are made by local Indian Superintendents without sufficient investigation. This has led to embarrassment by the inclusion in the Estimates of items which should have been omitted and by the omission of items which should have been included.

New one and two-room schools are being designed and the plans and specifications and bills of materials will be available by February, 1950, when they will be mailed to you.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.
